headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you know -- I mean, I know it's been a relatively brief period then you've had the Shred-it business in house. But would you mind talking about anything perhaps surprising versus your expectations going in?
componenttext: Wondering if you know -- I mean, I know it's been a relatively brief period then you've had the Shred-it business in house. But would you mind talking about anything perhaps surprising versus your expectations going in?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Overall, I would tell you that we haven't had any major surprises. I think we -- the things that -- the common themes that we've seen is, one, the service is very complementary to our existing compliance services. So that works well for us. Two, I continu
componenttext: Overall, I would tell you that we haven't had any major surprises. I think we -- the things that -- the common themes that we've seen is, one, the service is very complementary to our existing compliance services. So that works well for us. Two, I continue to be very impressed with the people and how similar their culture is to ours. So far it's been great to work with them. I -- where I continue to get most excited is the cross-sell opportunities. We've got multiple opportunities, everywhere you look, to cross-sell their services into our customers. I was just at the national sales meeting last week. And our LQ team, who's had a great deal of success selling additional services into hospitals, like our SMS or our Rx Waste or hazardous waste, all of them now are trained and ready to go with regard to selling that service into hospitals. And again, I am very confident we'll be successful there. We also have another -- several pilots going on with regard to their sales executives and selling into our existing Stericycle medical waste customers. What they typically do is they go in and give them a compliance review, looking at how they manage all their secure information. Oftentimes, when they do that audit, we can find compliance breaches. And that's a great way for them to switch to an outsourced service, and therefore, we're selling multiple services. So overall, I would tell you that we continue to be very encouraged. And the things that we thought going into this are turning out true. And again, we think this will be a great long-term acquisition for us.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Skinner, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions]I would now like to turn the call over to our host, S
componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Skinner, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the call over to our host, Sean McMillan, Vice President of Corporate Finance.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. Our actual results coul
componenttext:
I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. Our actual results could differ significantly from the results described in the forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause such differences include: changes in governmental regulation of the collection, transportation, treatment and disposal of regulated waste or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing regulated waste collection and treatment or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; our obligations to service our substantial indebtedness and to comply with the covenants and restrictions contained in our private placement notes, term loan credit facility and revolving credit facility; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; competition and demand for services in the regulated waste and secure information destruction industries; political, economic and currency risks related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other indefinite-lived intangibles; variability in the demand for services we provide on a project or nonrecurring basis; exposure to environmental liabilities; fluctuations in the price we receive for the sale of paper; disruptions in or attacks on our information technology systems; compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements; as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K.
As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance. Investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. We make no commitments to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements.
I will now turn it over to Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sean. We are pleased to report our fourth quarter results. Overall, our business performed very well in the quarter and remains on track despite foreign exchange headwinds and lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers. In the qua
componenttext:
Thanks, Sean. We are pleased to report our fourth quarter results. Overall, our business performed very well in the quarter and remains on track despite foreign exchange headwinds and lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers. In the quarter, we've made good progress on the Shred-it integration, and our team members are working together to help realize the many synergies from this acquisition. 
Joining me on today's call will be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and Brent Arnold, COO. 
I will now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Charlie. The results for the fourth quarter are as follows: Revenues were $888.3 million, up 31.2% from $676.9 million in Q4 2014. And internal growth excluding returns and recall revenues, was up 5.2%. Domestic revenues were $651.1 million, of
componenttext:
Thank you, Charlie. The results for the fourth quarter are as follows: Revenues were $888.3 million, up 31.2% from $676.9 million in Q4 2014. And internal growth excluding returns and recall revenues, was up 5.2%. Domestic revenues were $651.1 million, of which $626.8 million was domestic-regulated waste in compliance services, and $24.3 million was recalls and returns.
Fourth quarter domestic internal growth, excluding returns and recalls, revenues was up 4%, consisting of SQ up 6% and LQ up 2%. As anticipated, growth rates were impacted by lower fuel surcharges and lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers.
International revenues were $237.2 million, and internal growth adjusted for unfavorable foreign exchange impact of $26.9 million was up 8.1%. This growth rate was also impacted by lower hazardous waste volume. 
Acquisitions contributed $200 million to growth in the quarter. Gross profit was $380.4 million or 42.8% of revenues.
SG&A expense, including amortization, was $203.6 million or 22.9% of revenues. Net interest expense was $24.9 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $78.9 million or $0.80 per share on an as-reported basis and $1.11 when adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjustments. 
Now for the balance sheet. Our covenant debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 3.45 at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $686 million.
In the quarter, we repurchased 240,468 shares of common stock on the open market in an amount of $28,646,000. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 3.7 million shares.
Our CapEx was $42.2 million, which included accelerated spending to support 2016 integration associated with Shred-it.
Our DSO was 64 days. Year-to-date, as-reported cash from operations was $390 million. When adjusted for recall reimbursement and other items, cash from operations was $501 million. 
I will now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 10 acquisitions: 6 domestic and 4 international, including Shred-it. International acquisitions were 1 in Canada, 1 in
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 10 acquisitions: 6 domestic and 4 international, including Shred-it. International acquisitions were 1 in Canada, 1 in the Netherlands, 1 in Mexico and 1 in Spain. Revenues from the 10 acquisitions were $176.4 million in the quarter, and annualized are approximately $728 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 million in annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business.
In the fourth quarter, we continue to see strong growth in our pharmaceutical waste compliance program. Both our SQ and LQ adoption rates continue to increase as customers look for a compliant solution for this waste stream. This program not only helps our customers manage their pharmaceutical waste, but it often paves the way for Stericycle to manage all of their hazardous waste.
Our Shred-it integration efforts remain a priority across the organization. The Cintas/Shred-It synergies are on track, focusing on routing efficiencies and on-site to off-site conversions. The Stericycle Shred-it integration is gaining momentum, and the team has kicked off a number of exciting cross-selling pilots.
As a reminder, less than 20% of our existing Stericycle customers use Shred-it for secure information destruction. This represents a tremendous growth opportunity for Stericycle.
To assist with the integration, we are working with a consulting firm to help us optimize our long-term organizational structure. The goal is to maximize our growth opportunities and to better serve our customers. We're anticipating implementation to start later this year.
Looking ahead, we continue to see expanding growth opportunities as Stericycle provides multiple services that help our customers improve their operations and achieve their goals. As we execute on this strategy, we can more than triple our customer revenues.
In closing, I want to thank each member of our worldwide team for their strong performance and continued commitment to our customers, our shareholders and to our core values. 
I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related and ot
componenttext:
Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related and other adjusted items. As a reminder, our 2016 EPS guidance is adjusted for amortization expense.
For 2016, we believe analyst EPS estimates will be in the range of $5.26 to $5.33, reflecting the unfavorable impact of foreign exchange and a share count of approximately 92 million, which we are comfortable with. 
We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2016 will be in the range of $3.6 billion to $3.67 billion, depending on assumptions for growth and the unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates.
We anticipate 2016 internal growth rates to be: SQ, 7% to 9%; LQ, 4% to 7%; international, 6% to 9%; and recall and return revenues, between $95 million to $120 million.
We believe analysts will have estimates for free cash flow in 2016 between $460 million to $480 million. 2016 CapEx is anticipated to be between $125 million to $135 million. We expect the 2016 full year as-reported tax rate to be in the range of 36% to 36.5%.
In closing, we are very pleased with our fourth quarter results and remain excited about our multiple growth opportunities for 2016 and beyond. 
Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. [Operator Instructions]
Skinner, you can now open the question queue.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, maybe I'll start with one for you. Just trying to get a better feel for the cadence of EPS progression through the year, given paper prices, the Shred-it integration and synergies in industrial waste work. I guess, I'm trying to figure out, might thi
componenttext: Dan, maybe I'll start with one for you. Just trying to get a better feel for the cadence of EPS progression through the year, given paper prices, the Shred-it integration and synergies in industrial waste work. I guess, I'm trying to figure out, might this be more of a back-end loaded year? Should we think of it being relatively consistent to years past?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've done a lot of looking at that. And if you were to look at where we finished the year at $1.11, when you factor in also the amortization that's going to be excluded out next year, that jump-off point really equates to $1.24. We had $0.03
componenttext: Yes, I think we've done a lot of looking at that. And if you were to look at where we finished the year at $1.11, when you factor in also the amortization that's going to be excluded out next year, that jump-off point really equates to $1.24. We had $0.03 of nonrecurring EPS that won't repeat itself. So that really brings the jump-off point to about $1.01. We have been -- I'm sorry, $1.21. And then we have about $0.03 of normal seasonality that we would expect in Q1 and additional $0.01 of headwind to tax. So I think you're best to jump off the year at about $1.17 and then ramp up throughout the course of the year, probably evenly dispersing it from there on.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And then the recent weakness in recycled paper pricing, has that impacted your kind of thoughts on how you're guiding for that going forward? Are you still assuming an uptick in the back half of the year, so using more of a blen
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And then the recent weakness in recycled paper pricing, has that impacted your kind of thoughts on how you're guiding for that going forward? Are you still assuming an uptick in the back half of the year, so using more of a blended estimate?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you remember, much like foreign exchange, we only give guidance based off the current rates. And the current rate that we had at the time was $1 -- $126 per ton. That equated to about an $0.08 impact in 2016. But from some work in the operational ef
componenttext: So if you remember, much like foreign exchange, we only give guidance based off the current rates. And the current rate that we had at the time was $1 -- $126 per ton. That equated to about an $0.08 impact in 2016. But from some work in the operational efficiencies and some favorability in depreciation, we were able to exactly offset that. So there's been no guidance change for that going forward as from an EPS perspective. And so throughout the course of the year, we really don't anticipate any change, and that just assumes that's $126.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So in effect, your fundamental earnings performance is a little bit higher, but that's being offset just by the paper pricing and some FX headwinds. Is that a good way to think about it?
componenttext: Okay. So in effect, your fundamental earnings performance is a little bit higher, but that's being offset just by the paper pricing and some FX headwinds. Is that a good way to think about it?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Ryan, I'll just take you through the EPS bridge for the $5.26 to the $5.33 that we gave you. So you remember, the jump-off point was $5.28 to $5.35. We saw $0.08 of headwinds from the paper directly offset by depreciation. The foreign exchange, th
componenttext: Yes. So Ryan, I'll just take you through the EPS bridge for the $5.26 to the $5.33 that we gave you. So you remember, the jump-off point was $5.28 to $5.35. We saw $0.08 of headwinds from the paper directly offset by depreciation. The foreign exchange, the $48 million due to the current rates, is about a $0.05 to $0.06 headwind, offset by $0.02 to $0.03 of interest favorability and about $0.01 on the acquisitions. So really, if you look at the impact of the paper and the foreign exchange, we really only changed the guidance about $0.02.

componenttextpreview: Yes. If we think about what we talked about last quarter and the reality of Q4, it was right on what we expected. We thought the full quarter impact was going to be about $18 million, that's about roughly 80% domestic, 20% international. That came in as e
componenttext: Yes. If we think about what we talked about last quarter and the reality of Q4, it was right on what we expected. We thought the full quarter impact was going to be about $18 million, that's about roughly 80% domestic, 20% international. That came in as expected, and that obviously had an impact on growth rates. The other part of the business I think you're talking to is that other part of the project in industrial waste work that's not affected by commodity. And that performed as expected, of course. We didn't see any pullback in that part of the business. I think Brent talked about it in his comments, Rx waste specifically which -- that is hazardous waste. A good portion of that's hazardous waste upon disposal. The team had a really good quarter in Q4. And again, to remind everybody, our focus in hazardous waste is on health care hazardous waste. It's on retail hazardous waste and SQ hazardous waste. And those parts of the business are doing well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just taking a step back from what's been going on with Shred-it and haz waste, I guess, your international business has had margins well below the U.S. for -- I guess, ever since you got into it. I know there are structurally probabl
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just taking a step back from what's been going on with Shred-it and haz waste, I guess, your international business has had margins well below the U.S. for -- I guess, ever since you got into it. I know there are structurally probably some reason you'll never have the scale. But what are you doing? What's on the game plan, thinking about the next couple of years to try to close that gap or improve the international profitability? And is that something that you think can happen? Are we much more focused on Shred-it getting haz waste fixed and growing in terms of the near-term opportunities?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, it's Brent. But the answer would be all of the above. We want to improve it across the globe. But I think it's good to take a step back and really just remember that usually, when we enter a new country, it's with LQ, and we usually will go there to
componenttext: Gary, it's Brent. But the answer would be all of the above. We want to improve it across the globe. But I think it's good to take a step back and really just remember that usually, when we enter a new country, it's with LQ, and we usually will go there to establish a base. Over time, we look to improve the mix via tuck-in acquisitions and new services. A good example of that would be Dosimetry. So that's usually the way we'll try to work it. We'll also trying to continue to sell things like clinical services to -- and continue to improve those margins. So the team is very focused on that. We're making some good progress in other areas. But I think you also have to take into account that these markets have been difficult markets over the last several years. The team's, I think, done a really good job to make sure that we continue to stay focused on improving our margins.

componenttext: I see. Okay. And then the $0.08 of paper impact offset by depreciation. Dan, could you tell me what that means? I'm not sure exactly what you're -- what the mechanisms you're referring to there.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we saw about a $14 change in paper prices. Actually, if you looked at the quarter, about $1.33 is what the average was. But we're looking at $1.26 going forward, our guidance was at $1.40. That equates to about an $0.08 impact. But it's part of ou
componenttext: Yes. So we saw about a $14 change in paper prices. Actually, if you looked at the quarter, about $1.33 is what the average was. But we're looking at $1.26 going forward, our guidance was at $1.40. That equates to about an $0.08 impact. But it's part of our normal process of purchase accounting and booking and opening balance sheet. After the closing, we did a fair market study of Shred-it's fixed assets, and it actually reduced the revenue expectation -- or I'm sorry, the depreciation expectation we had for the year. And it happened to directly offset the decline in paper prices. So right now, there's no EPS impact of the Shred-it business, assuming paper prices continue at $126 per ton.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. So that's kind of a onetime thing and -- but it canceled it out for the current year. Then the last question I have for you, Dan, in terms of the other income expense line, you've been reporting an other expense of about $800,000 for the past 2 or
componenttext: I see. So that's kind of a onetime thing and -- but it canceled it out for the current year. Then the last question I have for you, Dan, in terms of the other income expense line, you've been reporting an other expense of about $800,000 for the past 2 or 3 years on average. And this quarter was other income of $4.5 million. What was that?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we had the opportunity to renegotiate a seller note. And in doing that, we're also able to negotiate it into an alternative currency, and that generated some -- about $0.03, along with some favorability in the interest. So that, combined, generated a
componenttext: Yes, we had the opportunity to renegotiate a seller note. And in doing that, we're also able to negotiate it into an alternative currency, and that generated some -- about $0.03, along with some favorability in the interest. So that, combined, generated about $0.03. Neither -- the interests will repeat, but the note was obviously a onetime effect that will not repeat going forward.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next questioner is Al Kaschalk from Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: And our next questioner is Al Kaschalk from Wedbush Securities.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Want to focus on the commentary about the good progress on the synergies related to Cintas. Can you give us a little more color on that?
componenttext: Want to focus on the commentary about the good progress on the synergies related to Cintas. Can you give us a little more color on that?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Al, this is Brent. I've had an opportunity to visit a lot of Shred-it locations over the last several months, and I'm really pleased so far with the integration. And overall, everything's on track. To date, we've completed over 50% of our rero
componenttext: Absolutely. Al, this is Brent. I've had an opportunity to visit a lot of Shred-it locations over the last several months, and I'm really pleased so far with the integration. And overall, everything's on track. To date, we've completed over 50% of our reroutes, which is terrific. The team continues to improve that process and refine that as we go forward. As well as the on-site to off-site conversions are also on track. So overall, we're very pleased with the efforts. The team members are, I think, fitting in great with our company, and we're really excited about where this is headed.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you put a little more quantification around the progress on, I think you said, the first 12 months you were focusing capturing the Cintas synergies? And the commentary was you've also started to make some progress on the Stericycle synergies. So I'm j
componenttext: Can you put a little more quantification around the progress on, I think you said, the first 12 months you were focusing capturing the Cintas synergies? And the commentary was you've also started to make some progress on the Stericycle synergies. So I'm just trying to gather how much of that -- I don't know if it was $52 million or $57 million you've captured this quarter and how we're on track for the next 9 months?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When we last spoke, I think it was about 30% of the way with regard to the Cintas/Shred-it synergy. And to date, we're just shy of 50% of the way with regard to the synergies. So the team continues to make great progress.
componenttext: Yes. When we last spoke, I think it was about 30% of the way with regard to the Cintas/Shred-it synergy. And to date, we're just shy of 50% of the way with regard to the synergies. So the team continues to make great progress.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think on the Stericycle-Shred-it synergies integration, we told you that, that was going to be more on the back end of '16 now and moving forward into 2017.
componenttext: And I think on the Stericycle-Shred-it synergies integration, we told you that, that was going to be more on the back end of '16 now and moving forward into 2017.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger from Oppenheimer.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guys, on -- just circling back on the RMS question, it looks like you were right on the year. I'm just curious, but you maintained the 2016 outlook. Did something not come through in the fourth quarter? And how's the momentum entering the year to maintain
componenttext: Guys, on -- just circling back on the RMS question, it looks like you were right on the year. I'm just curious, but you maintained the 2016 outlook. Did something not come through in the fourth quarter? And how's the momentum entering the year to maintain the guidance?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you know, Scott, I mean, that's a lumpy business for us. It's really uneven. It's hard to predict. So it's hard to say coming into the first part of the year if we're going to take guidance down. Now if you'd look back, the last 3 quarters for rec
componenttext: Yes. As you know, Scott, I mean, that's a lumpy business for us. It's really uneven. It's hard to predict. So it's hard to say coming into the first part of the year if we're going to take guidance down. Now if you'd look back, the last 3 quarters for recall and returns, or RMS, part of our business has been really well. '15 was done solid. We think that will continue into next year. So there was no reason at this point to change the guidance. I mean, it all comes down to blockbuster events. If we can get larger recall events in 2016, we'll be on the higher end of the range. And if we don't see those come in, we're confident on the lower end of the range. So again, the range is around $95 million to $120 million, and that's unchanged. And that, obviously, is within -- the year finished at $102.8 million. So we were in the range, and we feel confident about the 2016 guidance there.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I know automotive was helpful this past year. Is that going to be a driving force next year? Or will -- there may be other sources in pharma? Or you just don't have that visibility yet?
componenttext: Okay. And I know automotive was helpful this past year. Is that going to be a driving force next year? Or will -- there may be other sources in pharma? Or you just don't have that visibility yet?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing to call out, Scott. I mean, there are certainly -- we entered -- we did that acquisition last year to get an entry into the auto recall space that [indiscernible] a lot of heightened sensitivity to our recalls. We can offer a turnkey solution to m
componenttext: Nothing to call out, Scott. I mean, there are certainly -- we entered -- we did that acquisition last year to get an entry into the auto recall space that [indiscernible] a lot of heightened sensitivity to our recalls. We can offer a turnkey solution to manufacturers that helps them assist their customers with both notification and increasing their response rate. So still early stages with respect to our automotive recall capabilities. We're doing a great job. The team continues to win some deals in that space. And we feel really good about that acquisition and about the outlook for 2016.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Could you guys just hit on real quick the -- your ability to surcharge on used paper price? How much has that been rolled out? And how is that influencing the guidance update?
componenttext: All right. Could you guys just hit on real quick the -- your ability to surcharge on used paper price? How much has that been rolled out? And how is that influencing the guidance update?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we already have that factored into the guidance update. Our plan, though, is over time is to mitigate the assorted office paper revenue fluctuations through contracts' terms and conditions. This is going to take time. This is going to be addressed
componenttext: Yes. So we already have that factored into the guidance update. Our plan, though, is over time is to mitigate the assorted office paper revenue fluctuations through contracts' terms and conditions. This is going to take time. This is going to be addressed on a customer-by-customer basis. Certainly, Shred-it, the average contract is between 2 and 4 years. So this will take us several years to get through all the customers, but we think we'll make progress as we get further into the integration.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next questioner comes from Scott Levine at Imperial Capital.
componenttext: And our next questioner comes from Scott Levine at Imperial Capital.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know if you gave the gross margin bridge, Dan. But I was hoping you might be able to go over that the margins rebounded nicely on the gross line. And then also quantify the impact of fuel and how much of a positive that was in the quarter.
componenttext: I don't know if you gave the gross margin bridge, Dan. But I was hoping you might be able to go over that the margins rebounded nicely on the gross line. And then also quantify the impact of fuel and how much of a positive that was in the quarter.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me take you through the gross margin. And I want to remind you that as we went -- as we spoke last time and we are going to integrate Shred-it into the business, we fully expected that they were going to see some puts and takes. You'd see favorab
componenttext: Yes. Let me take you through the gross margin. And I want to remind you that as we went -- as we spoke last time and we are going to integrate Shred-it into the business, we fully expected that they were going to see some puts and takes. You'd see favorability on the gross margin line. And then you'd also see a little bit higher of an SG&A as a result. And that there was going to be a lot of moving parts on that. So I think it's probably more appropriate if I take you through the EBIT bridge, and that will take a little bit of the noise out. But certainly, we did see favorability on the gross margin line that was nice. But from an EBIT perspective, Q3's EBIT was 22.6%. Shred-it impacted the EBIT by about 245 basis points, which is actually better than what we had anticipated. And then improvements in the overall business really offset the lower revenue -- slightly lower revenues that we saw and some of the challenging economic conditions in Latin America. So those offset each other. And I would say that their performance, we are very pleased with the results of EBIT and the gross margin for that matter.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Scott, with regard to the impact of fuel with regard to our profitability, as you recall, we're on the fuel surcharge for a great portion of our business. So what we typically will see is as fuel comes down, so will the surcharges for that. And
componenttext: And then, Scott, with regard to the impact of fuel with regard to our profitability, as you recall, we're on the fuel surcharge for a great portion of our business. So what we typically will see is as fuel comes down, so will the surcharges for that. And that's as an offsetting effect with regard to the lower cost. So really, it's a net push with regard to the benefit to the business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wash it out in the EBIT line.
componenttext: Wash it out in the EBIT line.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Scott, since -- what you'll see on the gross margin and the SG&A line is that those puts and takes have ironed out a little bit. Those are pretty good jump-off points for building the bridge and going forward on that.
componenttext: And Scott, since -- what you'll see on the gross margin and the SG&A line is that those puts and takes have ironed out a little bit. Those are pretty good jump-off points for building the bridge and going forward on that.

componenttext: Got it. And then as a follow-up. Given the comments you made about the reduction in D&A associated with the change in accounting, can you give us a sense of what we should be assuming in our models on a go-forward basis? Is the add-back to arrive at cash EPS on a quarterly basis in 2016?

componenttext: Yes, I think for depreciation, about $44 million, and for amortization, about $36 million.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Barbara Noverini.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Barbara Noverini.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you've guided organic growth rates -- organic revenue growth rates in 2016 that are pretty similar to business as usual. So what gives you the confidence that the weakness in the industrial hazardous waste volumes won't accelerate through the year? How
componenttext: So you've guided organic growth rates -- organic revenue growth rates in 2016 that are pretty similar to business as usual. So what gives you the confidence that the weakness in the industrial hazardous waste volumes won't accelerate through the year? How good is your visibility into those project pipelines?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Barb, I think when we give -- it's important when we gave guidance, it's an annual guidance for our growth rates. So if you think about where we are today with growth rate, flat quarter of 62%, had we normalized that for fuel surcharges and a reducti
componenttext: Yes. Barb, I think when we give -- it's important when we gave guidance, it's an annual guidance for our growth rates. So if you think about where we are today with growth rate, flat quarter of 62%, had we normalized that for fuel surcharges and a reduction in hazardous waste volume, we would have been at SQ at about 8%; LQ at about 7%. When we look forward to next year, we know that we'll have a tough comparable in Q1 and Q2 and part of Q3, but then we won't have that in the back-end of the year. So as far as confidence, we think obviously we'll be at the lower end of the range for growth rates in the first half of the year, and then we'll improvement in the latter part of the year. But overall, when you look at the annual growth rates, we think we'll be between that SQ of 7% to 9% and the LQ of 4% to 7%.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then can you remind us what the business mix is in hazardous waste? What percentage of sales is associated with industrial versus retail versus health care hazardous waste?
componenttext: Got it. And then can you remind us what the business mix is in hazardous waste? What percentage of sales is associated with industrial versus retail versus health care hazardous waste?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When you think about our business, hazardous waste worldwide, it's roughly $650 million. And we called out that we have project work in large industrial waste customers of anywhere between $125 million to $200 million. So that portion of the business
componenttext: Yes. When you think about our business, hazardous waste worldwide, it's roughly $650 million. And we called out that we have project work in large industrial waste customers of anywhere between $125 million to $200 million. So that portion of the business. We don't really break out the other portion of the business, but retail hazardous waste, certainly, is a major contributor, as is our health care hazardous waste in our SQ business as well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Isaac Ro from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Isaac Ro from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Joel in for Isaac. So how should we be thinking about the incremental opportunities for M&A in the paper shredding business? Is it too soon to be thinking about how you guys are going to be? Are you guys doing any major deals here? And then
componenttext: It's actually Joel in for Isaac. So how should we be thinking about the incremental opportunities for M&A in the paper shredding business? Is it too soon to be thinking about how you guys are going to be? Are you guys doing any major deals here? And then what types of assets in terms of size or capability or geographic footprint would you be looking for?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think one thing that we did this quarter is besides the Shred-it acquisition, we made 4 acquisitions of other secure information destruction companies. So we -- certainly, it's part of our game plan. Shred-it, obviously, had a pipeline, and we were
componenttext: Yes. I think one thing that we did this quarter is besides the Shred-it acquisition, we made 4 acquisitions of other secure information destruction companies. So we -- certainly, it's part of our game plan. Shred-it, obviously, had a pipeline, and we were able to complete those deals in Q4. From a geography line, certainly, any country where we currently have operations both have the best returns, and that's where the focus will be. And then we'll also look at countries that Stericycle is currently in on the wayside of the business and see if there are opportunities to enter into those secure information destruction markets as well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I think it's been about 6 months since you guys went live with the Title V-compliant incinerators. Any change to the plans to push those incremental operating costs to your customer base as the contracts roll over? And if so, to what exten
componenttext: Great. And then I think it's been about 6 months since you guys went live with the Title V-compliant incinerators. Any change to the plans to push those incremental operating costs to your customer base as the contracts roll over? And if so, to what extent do you think this would be somewhat of a competitive disadvantage as these contracts expire?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, with regard to competitive advantage, I don't really see that happening because this is -- our incineration and the fact that we're vertically integrated there really helps us provide the best possible value for our customers to manage their pharmac
componenttext: Well, with regard to competitive advantage, I don't really see that happening because this is -- our incineration and the fact that we're vertically integrated there really helps us provide the best possible value for our customers to manage their pharmaceutical waste. So from -- with regard to overall cost, as we talked about before, as those contracts renew, we're able to accelerate those. And if there are regulatory changes, we're also able to oftentimes go back and renegotiate those with our customers.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Sean Dodge from Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Sean Dodge from Jefferies.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: On -- Charlie, on the core hazardous waste business, if we strip away the $125 million to $200 million of project-based and industrial exposure there that you had mentioned, can you give us an idea of how organic growth rates in that core part of the haza
componenttext: On -- Charlie, on the core hazardous waste business, if we strip away the $125 million to $200 million of project-based and industrial exposure there that you had mentioned, can you give us an idea of how organic growth rates in that core part of the hazardous waste business have trended over the last few quarters?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sean, we didn't strip out the whole $125 million to $200 million. We roughly thought, and I think we're fairly accurate, that about 50% -- between the $125 million and $200 million. So about $80 million of that was project or industrial waste related
componenttext: Yes. Sean, we didn't strip out the whole $125 million to $200 million. We roughly thought, and I think we're fairly accurate, that about 50% -- between the $125 million and $200 million. So about $80 million of that was project or industrial waste related. I will tell you there are parts of those business, like retail hazardous waste, that have growth rates that are actually higher than our current growth rates, our organic growth rates. So it varies by business line. But the business itself, if you take out the project in the industrial waste parts of the business, it's growing at or above our company average.

componenttext: Okay. And then Rich had mentioned in the prepared remarks that acquisitions contributed about $176.4 million of revenue to the quarter. How much of that was Shred-it?

componenttext: There was only about $1.6 million outside of Shred-it. So with those -- with the acquisitions that we did outside of that were more towards the end of the month.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Larry Keusch from Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Larry Keusch from Raymond James.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you know -- I mean, I know it's been a relatively brief period that you've had the Shred-it business in house. But would you mind talking about anything perhaps surprising versus your expectations going in?
componenttext: Wondering if you know -- I mean, I know it's been a relatively brief period that you've had the Shred-it business in house. But would you mind talking about anything perhaps surprising versus your expectations going in?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Overall, I would tell you that we haven't had any major surprises. I think we -- the things that -- the common themes that we've seen is, one, the service is very complementary to our existing compliance services. So that works well for us. Two, I continu
componenttext: Overall, I would tell you that we haven't had any major surprises. I think we -- the things that -- the common themes that we've seen is, one, the service is very complementary to our existing compliance services. So that works well for us. Two, I continue to be very impressed with the people and how similar their culture is to ours. So far it's been great to work with them. I -- where I continue to get most excited is the cross-sell opportunities. We've got multiple opportunities, everywhere you look, to cross-sell their services into our customers. I was just at the national sales meeting last week. And our LQ team, who's had a great deal of success selling additional services into hospitals, like our SMS or our Rx Waste or hazardous waste, all of them now are trained and ready to go with regard to selling that service into hospitals. And again, I am very confident we'll be successful there. We also have another -- several pilots going on with regard to their sales executives and selling into our existing Stericycle medical waste customers. What they typically do is they go in and give them a compliance review, looking at how they manage all their secure information. Oftentimes, when they do that audit, we can find compliance breaches. And that's a great way for them to switch to an outsourced service, and therefore, we're selling multiple services. So overall, I would tell you that we continue to be very encouraged. And the things that we thought going into this are turning out true. And again, we think this will be a great long-term acquisition for us.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, terrific. And then just one other one. I just want to make sure I've got my math right. I'm pretty sure on the third quarter call, you indicated in the '16 guidance that you're assuming $760 million in revenues for Shred-it. So a, I want to make sur
componenttext: Okay, terrific. And then just one other one. I just want to make sure I've got my math right. I'm pretty sure on the third quarter call, you indicated in the '16 guidance that you're assuming $760 million in revenues for Shred-it. So a, I want to make sure that was accurate. And b, is that still the case as you think about 2016?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that was accurate for the guidance that we gave last time. We discussed the paper impact, which will be about $12 million. They also have about 25% of their business which is international, so they saw about an $8 million foreign exchange impact. And
componenttext: Yes, that was accurate for the guidance that we gave last time. We discussed the paper impact, which will be about $12 million. They also have about 25% of their business which is international, so they saw about an $8 million foreign exchange impact. And they gave also on the lower fuel prices, they lose a little there. I think you're better to look at about $738 million now next year. But the great thing is with some of that benefit we saw in depreciation from an EBITDA view that we gave you last time was at about $20.7 million. The new guidance is about 21.1 million. So really, only about $1 million difference from EBITDA line.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

Have a great evening. We'll see everybody on the road in the next couple of months. Thanks for joining, everybody. Take care.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Skinner, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions]I would now like to turn the call over to our host, S
componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Skinner, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the call over to our host, Sean McMillan, Vice President of Corporate Finance.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. Our actual results coul
componenttext:
I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. Our actual results could differ significantly from the results described in the forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause such differences include: changes in governmental regulation of the collection, transportation, treatment and disposal of regulated waste or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing regulated waste collection and treatment or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; our obligations to service our substantial indebtedness and to comply with the covenants and restrictions contained in our private placement notes, term loan credit facility and revolving credit facility; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; competition and demand for services in the regulated waste and secure information destruction industries; political, economic and currency risks related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other indefinite-lived intangibles; variability in the demand for services we provide on a project or nonrecurring basis; exposure to environmental liabilities; fluctuations in the price we receive for the sale of paper; disruptions in or attacks on our information technology systems; compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements; as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K.
As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance. Investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. We make no commitments to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements.
I will now turn it over to Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sean. We are pleased to report our fourth quarter results. Overall, our business performed very well in the quarter and remains on track despite foreign exchange headwinds and lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers. In the qua
componenttext:
Thanks, Sean. We are pleased to report our fourth quarter results. Overall, our business performed very well in the quarter and remains on track despite foreign exchange headwinds and lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers. In the quarter, we've made good progress on the Shred-it integration, and our team members are working together to help realize the many synergies from this acquisition. 
Joining me on today's call will be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and Brent Arnold, COO. 
I will now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Charlie. The results for the fourth quarter are as follows: Revenues were $888.3 million, up 31.2% from $676.9 million in Q4 2014. And internal growth excluding returns and recall revenues, was up 5.2%. Domestic revenues were $651.1 million, of
componenttext:
Thank you, Charlie. The results for the fourth quarter are as follows: Revenues were $888.3 million, up 31.2% from $676.9 million in Q4 2014. And internal growth excluding returns and recall revenues, was up 5.2%. Domestic revenues were $651.1 million, of which $626.8 million was domestic-regulated waste in compliance services, and $24.3 million was recalls and returns.
Fourth quarter domestic internal growth, excluding returns and recalls, revenues was up 4%, consisting of SQ up 6% and LQ up 2%. As anticipated, growth rates were impacted by lower fuel surcharges and lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers.
International revenues were $237.2 million, and internal growth adjusted for unfavorable foreign exchange impact of $26.9 million was up 8.1%. This growth rate was also impacted by lower hazardous waste volume. 
Acquisitions contributed $200 million to growth in the quarter. Gross profit was $380.4 million or 42.8% of revenues.
SG&A expense, including amortization, was $203.6 million or 22.9% of revenues. Net interest expense was $24.9 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $78.9 million or $0.80 per share on an as-reported basis and $1.11 when adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjustments. 
Now for the balance sheet. Our covenant debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 3.45 at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $686 million.
In the quarter, we repurchased 240,468 shares of common stock on the open market in an amount of $28,646,000. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 3.7 million shares.
Our CapEx was $42.2 million, which included accelerated spending to support 2016 integration associated with Shred-it.
Our DSO was 64 days. Year-to-date, as-reported cash from operations was $390 million. When adjusted for recall reimbursement and other items, cash from operations was $501 million. 
I will now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 10 acquisitions: 6 domestic and 4 international, including Shred-it. International acquisitions were 1 in Canada, 1 in
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 10 acquisitions: 6 domestic and 4 international, including Shred-it. International acquisitions were 1 in Canada, 1 in the Netherlands, 1 in Mexico and 1 in Spain. Revenues from the 10 acquisitions were $176.4 million in the quarter, and annualized are approximately $728 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 million in annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business.
In the fourth quarter, we continue to see strong growth in our pharmaceutical waste compliance program. Both our SQ and LQ adoption rates continue to increase as customers look for a compliant solution for this waste stream. This program not only helps our customers manage their pharmaceutical waste, but it often paves the way for Stericycle to manage all of their hazardous waste.
Our Shred-it integration efforts remain a priority across the organization. The Cintas/Shred-It synergies are on track, focusing on routing efficiencies and on-site to off-site conversions. The Stericycle Shred-it integration is gaining momentum, and the team has kicked off a number of exciting cross-selling pilots.
As a reminder, less than 20% of our existing Stericycle customers use Shred-it for secure information destruction. This represents a tremendous growth opportunity for Stericycle.
To assist with the integration, we are working with a consulting firm to help us optimize our long-term organizational structure. The goal is to maximize our growth opportunities and to better serve our customers. We're anticipating implementation to start later this year.
Looking ahead, we continue to see expanding growth opportunities as Stericycle provides multiple services that help our customers improve their operations and achieve their goals. As we execute on this strategy, we can more than triple our customer revenues.
In closing, I want to thank each member of our worldwide team for their strong performance and continued commitment to our customers, our shareholders and to our core values. 
I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related and ot
componenttext:
Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related and other adjusted items. As a reminder, our 2016 EPS guidance is adjusted for amortization expense.
For 2016, we believe analyst EPS estimates will be in the range of $5.26 to $5.33, reflecting the unfavorable impact of foreign exchange and a share count of approximately 92 million, which we are comfortable with. 
We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2016 will be in the range of $3.6 billion to $3.67 billion, depending on assumptions for growth and the unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates.
We anticipate 2016 internal growth rates to be: SQ, 7% to 9%; LQ, 4% to 7%; international, 6% to 9%; and recall and return revenues, between $95 million to $120 million.
We believe analysts will have estimates for free cash flow in 2016 between $460 million to $480 million. 2016 CapEx is anticipated to be between $125 million to $135 million. We expect the 2016 full year as-reported tax rate to be in the range of 36% to 36.5%.
In closing, we are very pleased with our fourth quarter results and remain excited about our multiple growth opportunities for 2016 and beyond. 
Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. [Operator Instructions]
Skinner, you can now open the question queue.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ryan Daniels from William Blair.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, maybe I'll start with one for you. Just trying to get a better feel for the cadence of EPS progression through the year, given paper prices, the Shred-it integration and synergies in industrial waste work. I guess, I'm trying to figure out, might thi
componenttext: Dan, maybe I'll start with one for you. Just trying to get a better feel for the cadence of EPS progression through the year, given paper prices, the Shred-it integration and synergies in industrial waste work. I guess, I'm trying to figure out, might this be more of a back-end loaded year? Should we think of it being relatively consistent to years past?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've done a lot of looking at that. And if you were to look at where we finished the year at $1.11, when you factor in also the amortization that's going to be excluded out next year, that jump-off point really equates to $1.24. We had $0.03
componenttext: Yes, I think we've done a lot of looking at that. And if you were to look at where we finished the year at $1.11, when you factor in also the amortization that's going to be excluded out next year, that jump-off point really equates to $1.24. We had $0.03 of nonrecurring EPS that won't repeat itself. So that really brings the jump-off point to about $1.01. We have been -- I'm sorry, $1.21. And then we have about $0.03 of normal seasonality that we would expect in Q1 and additional $0.01 of headwind to tax. So I think you're best to jump off the year at about $1.17 and then ramp up throughout the course of the year, probably evenly dispersing it from there on.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And then the recent weakness in recycled paper pricing, has that impacted your kind of thoughts on how you're guiding for that going forward? Are you still assuming an uptick in the back half of the year, so using more of a blen
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And then the recent weakness in recycled paper pricing, has that impacted your kind of thoughts on how you're guiding for that going forward? Are you still assuming an uptick in the back half of the year, so using more of a blended estimate?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you remember, much like foreign exchange, we only give guidance based off the current rates. And the current rate that we had at the time was $1 -- $126 per ton. That equated to about an $0.08 impact in 2016. But from some work in the operational ef
componenttext: So if you remember, much like foreign exchange, we only give guidance based off the current rates. And the current rate that we had at the time was $1 -- $126 per ton. That equated to about an $0.08 impact in 2016. But from some work in the operational efficiencies and some favorability in depreciation, we were able to exactly offset that. So there's been no guidance change for that going forward as from an EPS perspective. And so throughout the course of the year, we really don't anticipate any change, and that just assumes that's $126.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So in effect, your fundamental earnings performance is a little bit higher, but that's being offset just by the paper pricing and some FX headwinds. Is that a good way to think about it?
componenttext: Okay. So in effect, your fundamental earnings performance is a little bit higher, but that's being offset just by the paper pricing and some FX headwinds. Is that a good way to think about it?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Ryan, I'll just take you through the EPS bridge for the $5.26 to the $5.33 that we gave you. So you remember, the jump-off point was $5.28 to $5.35. We saw $0.08 of headwinds from the paper directly offset by depreciation. The foreign exchange, th
componenttext: Yes. So Ryan, I'll just take you through the EPS bridge for the $5.26 to the $5.33 that we gave you. So you remember, the jump-off point was $5.28 to $5.35. We saw $0.08 of headwinds from the paper directly offset by depreciation. The foreign exchange, the $48 million due to the current rates, is about a $0.05 to $0.06 headwind, offset by $0.02 to $0.03 of interest favorability and about $0.01 on the acquisitions. So really, if you look at the impact of the paper and the foreign exchange, we really only changed the guidance about $0.02.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes. If we think about what we talked about last quarter and the reality of Q4, it was right on what we expected. We thought the full quarter impact was going to be about $18 million, that's about roughly 80% domestic, 20% international. That came in as expected, and that obviously had an impact on growth rates. The other part of the business I think you're talking to is that other part of the project in industrial waste work that's not affected by commodity. And that performed as expected, of course. We didn't see any pullback in that part of the business. I think Brent talked about it in his comments, Rx waste specifically which -- that is hazardous waste. A good portion of that's hazardous waste upon disposal. The team had a really good quarter in Q4. And again, to remind everybody, our focus in hazardous waste is on health care hazardous waste. It's on retail hazardous waste and SQ hazardous waste. And those parts of the business are doing well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just taking a step back from what's been going on with Shred-it and haz waste, I guess, your international business has had margins well below the U.S. for -- I guess, ever since you got into it. I know there are structurally probabl
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just taking a step back from what's been going on with Shred-it and haz waste, I guess, your international business has had margins well below the U.S. for -- I guess, ever since you got into it. I know there are structurally probably some reason you'll never have the scale. But what are you doing? What's on the game plan, thinking about the next couple of years to try to close that gap or improve the international profitability? And is that something that you think can happen? Are we much more focused on Shred-it getting haz waste fixed and growing in terms of the near-term opportunities?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, it's Brent. But the answer would be all of the above. We want to improve it across the globe. But I think it's good to take a step back and really just remember that usually, when we enter a new country, it's with LQ, and we usually will go there to
componenttext: Gary, it's Brent. But the answer would be all of the above. We want to improve it across the globe. But I think it's good to take a step back and really just remember that usually, when we enter a new country, it's with LQ, and we usually will go there to establish a base. Over time, we look to improve the mix via tuck-in acquisitions and new services. A good example of that would be Dosimetry. So that's usually the way we'll try to work it. We'll also trying to continue to sell things like clinical services to -- and continue to improve those margins. So the team is very focused on that. We're making some good progress in other areas. But I think you also have to take into account that these markets have been difficult markets over the last several years. The team's, I think, done a really good job to make sure that we continue to stay focused on improving our margins.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we saw about a $14 change in paper prices. Actually, if you looked at the quarter, about $133 is what the average was. But we're looking at $126 going forward, our guidance was at $140. That equates to about an $0.08 impact. But it's part of our n
componenttext: Yes. So we saw about a $14 change in paper prices. Actually, if you looked at the quarter, about $133 is what the average was. But we're looking at $126 going forward, our guidance was at $140. That equates to about an $0.08 impact. But it's part of our normal process of purchase accounting and booking and opening balance sheet. After the closing, we did a fair market study of Shred-it's fixed assets, and it actually reduced the revenue expectation -- or I'm sorry, the depreciation expectation we had for the year. And it happened to directly offset the decline in paper prices. So right now, there's no EPS impact of the Shred-it business, assuming paper prices continue at $126 per ton.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. So that's kind of a onetime thing and -- but it canceled it out for the current year. Then the last question I have for you, Dan, in terms of the other income expense line, you've been reporting an other expense of about $800,000 for the past 2 or
componenttext: I see. So that's kind of a onetime thing and -- but it canceled it out for the current year. Then the last question I have for you, Dan, in terms of the other income expense line, you've been reporting an other expense of about $800,000 for the past 2 or 3 years on average. And this quarter was other income of $4.5 million. What was that?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we had the opportunity to renegotiate a seller note. And in doing that, we're also able to negotiate it into an alternative currency, and that generated some -- about $0.03, along with some favorability in the interest. So that, combined, generated a
componenttext: Yes, we had the opportunity to renegotiate a seller note. And in doing that, we're also able to negotiate it into an alternative currency, and that generated some -- about $0.03, along with some favorability in the interest. So that, combined, generated about $0.03. Neither -- the interests will repeat, but the note was obviously a onetime effect that will not repeat going forward.

componenttext: Absolutely. Al, this is Brent. I've had an opportunity to visit a lot of Shred-it locations over the last several months, and I'm really pleased so far with the integration. The team members are, I think, fitting in great with our company, and we're really excited about where this is headed.

componenttextpreview: Guys, on -- just circling back on the RMS question, it looks like you were right on the year. I'm just curious, but you maintained the 2016 outlook. Did something not come through in the fourth quarter? And how's the momentum entering the year to maintain
componenttext: Guys, on -- just circling back on the RMS question, it looks like you were right on the year. I'm just curious, but you maintained the 2016 outlook. Did something not come through in the fourth quarter? And how's the momentum entering the year to maintain the guidance?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you know, Scott, I mean, that's a lumpy business for us. It's really uneven. It's hard to predict. So it's hard to say coming into the first part of the year if we're going to take guidance down. Now if you'd look back, the last 3 quarters for rec
componenttext: Yes. As you know, Scott, I mean, that's a lumpy business for us. It's really uneven. It's hard to predict. So it's hard to say coming into the first part of the year if we're going to take guidance down. Now if you'd look back, the last 3 quarters for recall and returns, or RMS, part of our business has been really well. '15 was done solid. We think that will continue into next year. So there was no reason at this point to change the guidance. I mean, it all comes down to blockbuster events. If we can get larger recall events in 2016, we'll be on the higher end of the range. And if we don't see those come in, we're confident on the lower end of the range. So again, the range is around $95 million to $120 million, and that's unchanged. And that, obviously, is within -- the year finished at $102.8 million. So we were in the range, and we feel confident about the 2016 guidance there.

componenttext: Nothing to call out, Scott. I mean, there are certainly -- we entered -- we did that acquisition last year to get an entry into the auto recall space that [indiscernible] a lot of heightened sensitivity to our recalls. We can offer a turnkey solution to manufacturers that helps them assist their customers with both notification and increasing their response rate. So still early stages with respect to our automotive recall capabilities. We're doing a great job. The team continues to win some deals in that space. And we feel really good about that acquisition and about the outlook for 2016.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Could you guys just hit on real quick the -- your ability to surcharge on used paper price? How much has that been rolled out? And how is that influencing the guidance update?
componenttext: All right. Could you guys just hit on real quick the -- your ability to surcharge on used paper price? How much has that been rolled out? And how is that influencing the guidance update?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we already have that factored into the guidance update. Our plan, though, is over time is to mitigate the assorted office paper revenue fluctuations through contracts' terms and conditions. This is going to take time. This is going to be addressed
componenttext: Yes. So we already have that factored into the guidance update. Our plan, though, is over time is to mitigate the assorted office paper revenue fluctuations through contracts' terms and conditions. This is going to take time. This is going to be addressed on a customer-by-customer basis. Certainly, Shred-it, the average contract is between 2 and 4 years. So this will take us several years to get through all the customers, but we think we'll make progress as we get further into the integration.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next questioner comes from Scott Levine at Imperial Capital.
componenttext: And our next questioner comes from Scott Levine at Imperial Capital.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know if you gave the gross margin bridge, Dan. But I was hoping you might be able to go over that the margins rebounded nicely on the gross line. And then also quantify the impact of fuel and how much of a positive that was in the quarter.
componenttext: I don't know if you gave the gross margin bridge, Dan. But I was hoping you might be able to go over that the margins rebounded nicely on the gross line. And then also quantify the impact of fuel and how much of a positive that was in the quarter.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me take you through the gross margin. And I want to remind you that as we went -- as we spoke last time and we are going to integrate Shred-it into the business, we fully expected that they were going to see some puts and takes. You'd see favorab
componenttext: Yes. Let me take you through the gross margin. And I want to remind you that as we went -- as we spoke last time and we are going to integrate Shred-it into the business, we fully expected that they were going to see some puts and takes. You'd see favorability on the gross margin line. And then you'd also see a little bit higher of an SG&A as a result. And that there was going to be a lot of moving parts on that. So I think it's probably more appropriate if I take you through the EBIT bridge, and that will take a little bit of the noise out. But certainly, we did see favorability on the gross margin line that was nice. But from an EBIT perspective, Q3's EBIT was 22.6%. Shred-it impacted the EBIT by about 245 basis points, which is actually better than what we had anticipated. And then improvements in the overall business really offset the lower revenue -- slightly lower revenues that we saw and some of the challenging economic conditions in Latin America. So those offset each other. And I would say that their performance, we are very pleased with the results of EBIT and the gross margin for that matter.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Scott, with regard to the impact of fuel with regard to our profitability, as you recall, we're on the fuel surcharge for a great portion of our business. So what we typically will see is as fuel comes down, so will the surcharges for that. And
componenttext: And then, Scott, with regard to the impact of fuel with regard to our profitability, as you recall, we're on the fuel surcharge for a great portion of our business. So what we typically will see is as fuel comes down, so will the surcharges for that. And that's as an offsetting effect with regard to the lower cost. So really, it's a net push with regard to the benefit to the business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wash it out in the EBIT line.
componenttext: Wash it out in the EBIT line.

componenttext: And Scott, since -- what you'll see on the gross margin and the SG&A line is that those puts and takes have ironed out a little bit. Those are pretty good jump-off points for building the bridge and going forward on that.
