componenttext: And our next question comes from Barbara Noverini.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you've guided organic growth rates -- organic revenue growth rates in 2016 that are pretty similar to business as usual. So what gives you the confidence that the weakness in the industrial hazardous waste volumes won't accelerate through the year? How
componenttext: So you've guided organic growth rates -- organic revenue growth rates in 2016 that are pretty similar to business as usual. So what gives you the confidence that the weakness in the industrial hazardous waste volumes won't accelerate through the year? How good is your visibility into those project pipelines?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Barb, I think when we give -- it's important when we gave guidance, it's an annual guidance for our growth rates. So if you think about where we are today with growth rate, flat quarter of 62%, had we normalized that for fuel surcharges and a reducti
componenttext: Yes. Barb, I think when we give -- it's important when we gave guidance, it's an annual guidance for our growth rates. So if you think about where we are today with growth rate, flat quarter of 62%, had we normalized that for fuel surcharges and a reduction in hazardous waste volume, we would have been at SQ at about 8%; LQ at about 7%. When we look forward to next year, we know that we'll have a tough comparable in Q1 and Q2 and part of Q3, but then we won't have that in the back-end of the year. So as far as confidence, we think obviously we'll be at the lower end of the range for growth rates in the first half of the year, and then we'll improvement in the latter part of the year. But overall, when you look at the annual growth rates, we think we'll be between that SQ of 7% to 9% and the LQ of 4% to 7%.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes. When you think about our business, hazardous waste worldwide, it's roughly $650 million. And we called out that we have project work in large industrial waste customers of anywhere between $125 million to $200 million. So that portion of the business. We don't really break out the other portion of the business, but retail hazardous waste, certainly, is a major contributor, as is our health care hazardous waste in our SQ business as well.

Is it too soon to be thinking about how you guys are going to be? Are you guys doing any major deals here? headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think one thing that we did this quarter is besides the Shred-it acquisition, we made 4 acquisitions of other secure information destruction companies. So we -- certainly, it's part of our game plan. Shred-it, obviously, had a pipeline, and we were
componenttext: Yes. I think one thing that we did this quarter is besides the Shred-it acquisition, we made 4 acquisitions of other secure information destruction companies. So we -- certainly, it's part of our game plan. Shred-it, obviously, had a pipeline, and we were able to complete those deals in Q4. From a geography line, certainly, any country where we currently have operations both have the best returns, and that's where the focus will be. And then we'll also look at countries that Stericycle is currently in on the wayside of the business and see if there are opportunities to enter into those secure information destruction markets as well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I think it's been about 6 months since you guys went live with the Title V-compliant incinerators. Any change to the plans to push those incremental operating costs to your customer base as the contracts roll over? And if so, to what exten
componenttext: Great. And then I think it's been about 6 months since you guys went live with the Title V-compliant incinerators. Any change to the plans to push those incremental operating costs to your customer base as the contracts roll over? And if so, to what extent do you think this would be somewhat of a competitive disadvantage as these contracts expire?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, with regard to competitive advantage, I don't really see that happening because this is -- our incineration and the fact that we're vertically integrated there really helps us provide the best possible value for our customers to manage their pharmac
componenttext: Well, with regard to competitive advantage, I don't really see that happening because this is -- our incineration and the fact that we're vertically integrated there really helps us provide the best possible value for our customers to manage their pharmaceutical waste. So from -- with regard to overall cost, as we talked about before, as those contracts renew, we're able to accelerate those. And if there are regulatory changes, we're also able to oftentimes go back and renegotiate those with our customers.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sean, we didn't strip out the whole $125 million to $200 million. We roughly thought, and I think we're fairly accurate, that about 50% -- between the $125 million and $200 million. So about $80 million of that was project or industrial waste related
componenttext: Yes. Sean, we didn't strip out the whole $125 million to $200 million. We roughly thought, and I think we're fairly accurate, that about 50% -- between the $125 million and $200 million. So about $80 million of that was project or industrial waste related. I will tell you there are parts of those business, like retail hazardous waste, that have growth rates that are actually higher than our current growth rates, our organic growth rates. So it varies by business line. But the business itself, if you take out the project in the industrial waste parts of the business, it's growing at or above our company average.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you know -- I mean, I know it's been a relatively brief period that you've had the Shred-it business in house. But would you mind talking about anything perhaps surprising versus your expectations going in?
componenttext: Wondering if you know -- I mean, I know it's been a relatively brief period that you've had the Shred-it business in house. But would you mind talking about anything perhaps surprising versus your expectations going in?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Overall, I would tell you that we haven't had any major surprises. I think we -- the things that -- the common themes that we've seen is, one, the service is very complementary to our existing compliance services. So that works well for us. Two, I continu
componenttext: Overall, I would tell you that we haven't had any major surprises. I think we -- the things that -- the common themes that we've seen is, one, the service is very complementary to our existing compliance services. So that works well for us. Two, I continue to be very impressed with the people and how similar their culture is to ours. So far it's been great to work with them. I -- where I continue to get most excited is the cross-sell opportunities. We've got multiple opportunities, everywhere you look, to cross-sell their services into our customers. I was just at the national sales meeting last week. And our LQ team, who's had a great deal of success selling additional services into hospitals, like our SMS or our Rx Waste or hazardous waste, all of them now are trained and ready to go with regard to selling that service into hospitals. And again, I am very confident we'll be successful there. We also have another -- several pilots going on with regard to their sales executives and selling into our existing Stericycle medical waste customers. What they typically do is they go in and give them a compliance review, looking at how they manage all their secure information. Oftentimes, when they do that audit, we can find compliance breaches. And that's a great way for them to switch to an outsourced service, and therefore, we're selling multiple services. So overall, I would tell you that we continue to be very encouraged. And the things that we thought going into this are turning out true. And again, we think this will be a great long-term acquisition for us.

componenttext: Okay, terrific. And then just one other one. I just want to make sure I've got my math right. componenttext: Yes, that was accurate for the guidance that we gave last time. We discussed the paper impact, which will be about $12 million. They also have about 25% of their business which is international, so they saw about an $8 million foreign exchange impact. And they gave also on the lower fuel prices, they lose a little there. I think you're better to look at about $738 million now next year. But the great thing is with some of that benefit we saw in depreciation from an EBITDA view that we gave you last time was at about $20.7 million. The new guidance is about 21.1 million. So really, only about $1 million difference from EBITDA line.

componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, again for participating on our call. Depending on analyst models, revenues, adjusted EBIT and EBITDA will all show growth in excess of 20%. It's going to be an exciting 2016. 
Have a great evening. We'll see everybody on the road in the next couple of months. Thanks for joining, everybody. Take care.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Steve, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. VP of corporate finance, Sean McMillan, you may begin your conference.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle's first quarter 2016  conference call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, ge
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle's first quarter 2016  conference call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. 
Our actual results could differ significantly from the results described in the forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause such differences include: changes in governmental regulation of the collection, transportation, treatment and disposal of regulated waste or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing regulated waste collection and treatment or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; our obligations to service our substantial indebtedness and to comply with the covenants and restrictions contained in our private placement notes, term loan credit facility and revolving credit facility; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; competition and demand for services in the regulated waste and secure information destruction industries; political, economic and currency risks related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other indefinite-lived intangibles; variability in the demand for services we provide on a project or nonrecurring basis; exposure to environmental liabilities; fluctuations in the price we receive for the sale of paper; disruptions in or attacks on our information technology systems; compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements; as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K.
As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance. Investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. We make no commitments to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements.
I will now turn it over to Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us on today's call. In the first quarter, we experienced strong revenue growth, strong cash flow and solid sequential growth for the Shred-it acquisition. Results in the quarter were unfavorably impacted by the timing of the Shred-it
componenttext: Thank you for joining us on today's call. In the first quarter, we experienced strong revenue growth, strong cash flow and solid sequential growth for the Shred-it acquisition. Results in the quarter were unfavorably impacted by the timing of the Shred-it synergies and lower industrial waste revenues. Despite the challenges in the quarter, we remain confident about our business. Joining me on the today's call be Dan Ginnetti, CFO and CEO. I will now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you [Audio Gap]First quarter domestic internal growth, excluding recalls and returns revenues was up 5%, consisting of SQ up 6%, and LQ up 4%. As anticipated, growth rates were impacted by lower fuel surcharges and lower hazardous waste volumes
componenttext:
Thank you 
[Audio Gap]
First quarter domestic internal growth, excluding recalls and returns revenues was up 5%, consisting of SQ up 6%, and LQ up 4%. As anticipated, growth rates were impacted by lower fuel surcharges and lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers. International revenues were $224.5 million, and internal growth adjusted for unfavorable foreign exchange impact of $23.8 million was up 7%. 
This growth rate was also impacted by lower hazardous waste volume. Acquisitions contributed $194.5 million to growth in the quarter. Gross profit was $369.2 million or 42.2% of revenues. 
SG&A expense, including amortization was $207.3 million or 23.7% of revenues. 
Net interest expense was $24 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $66.7 million or $0.78 per share on an as reported basis, and $1.11 when adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjustments. 
Our covenants, debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 3.41 at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $584 million. In the quarter, we repurchased 327,952 shares of common stock on the open market in an amount of $37,693,000. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 3.4 million shares.
Our CapEx was $34.2 million or 3.9% of revenues. Our DSO was 63 days. Year-to-date, cash from operations was $156.9 million, when adjusted for recall reimbursement and other items, cash from operations was $163.6 million. I will now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 7 acquisitions, 5 domestic and 2 international. International acquisitions were 1 in Spain, and 1 in Romania. Revenues
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 7 acquisitions, 5 domestic and 2 international. International acquisitions were 1 in Spain, and 1 in Romania. Revenues in the 7 acquisitions were approximately $1 million in the quarter, and annualized are approximately $12.4 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 billion annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business. 
In the quarter, the Shred-it sales team deliver strong new sales growth. As a reminder, Shred-it has over 350 sales professionals across North America focused on converting customers that either do not shred or shred themselves. This unwinded market represents at $2.5 billion growth opportunity for Stericycle. 
We also encouraged by the progress the combined sales teams are having and selling Shred-it solution. This quarter, the team closed 8 health systems in multiple national accounts. Today, less than 20% of our current Stericycle healthcare customers use Shred-it is a secure information instruction provider, representing a nice growth opportunity for Stericycle. 
Our Shred-it integration efforts remain a priority across the organization. We are confident in our ability to achieve the full $73 million in Cintas Shred-it synergies, and our team has either completed or made solid progress on many of the integration projects. 
However, we have reassessed the original time line associated with the rebound and on-site to on-site conversion. While several regions have successfully made this conversion, the time to convert each region is taking longer than previously anticipated. 
In order to ensure high service levels and support ongoing new customer growth, we have decided to extend the rollout schedule going forward. 
The new timeline enables the rebound teams to provide the necessary support and assistance without negatively impacting our customers. 
Based on these changes, approximately $20 million of $1 of the anticipated rebound and on-site to off-site synergies will be extended into 2017, with a full impact in 2018. 
And our retail and healthcare has this waste compliance program, we continue to experience strong growth. The growth is fueled by increase in enforcement of existing regulation and by Stericycle strong customer relationships in both retail and the healthcare industry. 
Looking ahead, we continue to see expanding growth opportunities. Stericycle provides multiple services that help our customers improve their operations and achieve their goal. 
As we execute on the strategy, we can more than triple our customers revenue. 
We would like to congratulate Stericycle's partners for West Virginia facility for receiving congressional recognition as a star status site in Osho's voluntary protection program. This was the first medical waste facility to earn the VPP award, and it demonstrates the team's dedication to our corporate values. 
In closing, I want to thank each member of our worldwide team for their continued commitment to our customers, our shareholders and our core values. I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related expe
componenttext:
Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016. 
Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related expenses and other adjusted items. As a reminder, our 2016 EPS guidance is adjusted for amortization expense.
For 2016, we believe analyst EPS estimates will be in the range of $4.90 to $5.05, reflecting the unfavorable impact of the timing of the Shred-it synergies, software industrial hazardous waste volume, and higher costs associated with our international operations. 
We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2016 will be in the range of $3.6 billion to $3.66 billion, depending on assumptions for growth and the impact of foreign exchange rates. 
We anticipate 2016 internal growth rates to be: SQ, 7% to 9%; LQ 4% to 7%; international, 6% to 9%; and recall and returns revenues between $95 million and $115 million. 
We believe analyst will estimates for free cash flow in 2016 between $435 million and $455 million. 
2016 CapEx is anticipated to be between $125 million to $135 million. We expect the 2016 full year as reported tax rate to be approximately 35.5%. 
In closing, although disappointed with our results in Q1, we are confident about the long-term fundamentals in our business and remain excited about the growth opportunities in 2016 and beyond. Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. Steve, you can open the queue.

componenttext:
Yes. Ryan, I'd be happy to do that. So the prior guidance was $5.26 to $5.33. We had a 0.05 miss in the quarter, so that's obviously going to roll into the next guidance. 
There were some strength in paper prices and slightly lower interest rate, and we had some acquisition contribution and that was offset by some higher depreciation expense, that les to about $0.01 to $0.02 of favorable expand -- favorable EPS. 
The delay as -- Brent mentioned in his dialogue in recognition of Shred-it synergy is anywhere between $0.07 to $0.12 unfavorable. International, cost pressures in Latin America and the U.K. is between $0.07 to $0.10 unfavorable. And we had some softness in the industrial market and the mix of customers in ethyl business, that will be anywhere from $0.10 to $0.11 on the year unfavorable. So the new guidance from there will bridge to $4.90 to $5.05. And I think when you're looking at Q2, I think it's best to pick a range between $1.16 to $1.20, and I think you be in good position for the quarter.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then, it's my follow-up, can you go into a little bit more detail on the elongation of the Shred-it synergies. Do you think that's just going through 2 separate mergers, it's kind of distracting that workforce or is it as you pushed some of the changes to route density improvements and moving to off-site, it's impacted customer churn or anything of that nature. So is that you're trying to slow it down and kind of elongate that, just any color there would be helpful?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, this is Brent. Absolutely. this is not about, yes, we can get the on-site to off-site, and re-round synergies, but rather when we will get these. All of us either want to get these synergies as soon as possible. We just need to make sure, we do it i
componenttext:
Ryan, this is Brent. Absolutely. this is not about, yes, we can get the on-site to off-site, and re-round synergies, but rather when we will get these. All of us either want to get these synergies as soon as possible. We just need to make sure, we do it in a time frame that does not negatively impact our customers. It probably make sense to give a little bit of description of what we're talking about, and what really goes into and on-site to off-site conversions. First, with all of the conversions of this type, you have to have clean data, you need to know things like, service location, number of counsels, hours of operation, key contact information. Let me remind you that the team recently went through a merger of operating systems, when Cintas joins Shred-it. And while that went well, they're definitely some items that still need to be cleaned up as part of that data cleanup. 
Then you notify the customers, so you're notifying all the customers that are currently on-site, and you're lying to know that we're going to be searching their service from on-site shredding with a truck that has shredder on it. To taking that back to our facility and shredding it back at our facility. So you have to make sure you have all the supplies right, because you're switching trucks, you have to have the right number of box trucks with gates, consuls, the transport, the materials, so all of those things needed to be in place, 
Ultimately though, and this is really where we're noticing the biggest challenge is when you make the change, our team members now are going to new sites. So imagine, Ryan, if a CSR is coming to your facility, the number of consuls you have across William Blair, and they're not serviced it before, you now are, while they have a description of location in their handheld, you still need to find those, you needed to find your the best way to kind of wrap through your office to find all those consuls. So there is a learning curve that our CSRs or drivers need to go through, when we make this changes of the ground. Believe it or not, the first probably several weeks after re-route, we're actually less efficient than we were before the re-route. But as they go to their learning cover and that settles down, we start to get efficiencies, and we ultimately, we'll do a final kind of polishing re-route to really put as many stops on those routes as possible. 
So again, our focus here is about how do we do this without impacting the customer, recognizing the synergies and ultimately doing it in the way that allows us to continue to close new business. 
The reason we're confident that we're going to get that $73 million, we've done this many times before, our pilot market in Toronto, in Cleveland, in Charlotte, in Boston, in Detroit is the number of markets, where we have successfully done this, but what we've decided to do is you know what, this needs to be more of a 16 week process than an 8 with process in the time line we're just too aggressive. So when assessing that, we decided to extended out ultimately, because we do not want to disrupt the service with our customers.

I appreciate the bridge on the EPS, but I guess, I want to look at take a maybe different angle at the mix of revenue that you have and maybe the profitability of that. And maybe, there is some color you can provide us in terms of the percentage of industrial revenue, that's international versus domestic, kind of is there any margin impact there? 
It appears to me just on again on the surface that the business you added isn't as profitable as you think it was, or thought it was or they really the piece that's coming of on the industrial side is really pretty significant. 
So is there any color you can provide on that. And then second, I guess, the follow-up to that would be, was there further lag down in the first quarter on the industrial pieces, specifically, from when you exited '14 -- '15?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Charlie. I'll take that. I think hen you think about how is this waste with Stericycle roughly 80% domestic, 20% is international. But if we dig down to the Q1 impact on what we call our environmental solutions business, hazardous waste volum
componenttext:
Yes. This is Charlie. I'll take that. I think hen you think about how is this waste with Stericycle roughly 80% domestic, 20% is international. But if we dig down to the Q1 impact on what we call our environmental solutions business, hazardous waste volumes that is excluding retail hazard waste and healthcare hazard waste, we're anticipating that to grow at seasonally -- seasonably adjusted rate of about 3%, it actually came in at a negative 4% for the quarter. So roughly speaking about $5.5 million soft on our industrial or hazardous waste volumes. In addition, the mix of the waste that we bid actually pick up in our projects resulting in a higher anticipated disposal expense of roughly about $1.5 million, and that has to do with some of the larger projects we did, where direct disposal and we have direct disposal as opposed going through our facilities we do incur higher disposal expense for those accounts, and that's what Dan was referring to when he's talking about mix in the environmental solutions business or hazardous waste business. 
So certainly, we did see a lower hazardous waste volume. The good news I think though, and Brent talked about in his opening is, where we're focused, that's the healthcare hazardous waste, that's the retail hazardous waste, that's the SQ hazardous waste. We had really strong growth there, but unfortunately, we have a mix issue when it comes to the facilities that we've acquired to support this growth. And that has a very high fixed cost to it and that's what you see hurting us not only on the revenue line, but also on the profit line.

componenttext: I guess, I want to ask about the international business. Just looking at the 10-K, you in obviously given more detail, and the margins there relative to U.S. business are like less than 1/3 the amount. I know that got hurt last year by half, but the question is this, is there a credible plan and strategy to narrow that gap in the next 2 to 3 years. And for years, you've talked about, if you can move the mix more to SQ that will take care of it, but it doesn't seem to me that you had much success with that at least overall, because those margins are down several years in a row. And that level of profitability, can you justify continue to do M&A in the international waste business, it just seems like, there's no way you're getting good returns, if you can't really improve the profitability?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think I'm going to take that 2, 1, I want to walk you through what are some of the pressures that we're facing currently Gary, and then I'll take a that your question around long-term what I think we can do there. The pressure points, and we feel b
componenttext: Yes. I think I'm going to take that 2, 1, I want to walk you through what are some of the pressures that we're facing currently Gary, and then I'll take a that your question around long-term what I think we can do there. The pressure points, and we feel be the pressure points for the rest of the year are in 2 distinct lines. It's first of all, guts of view with our patient transport business in the U.K., and one of our biggest contributors to our international cost pressures because it has rapidly grown over the last several years. We then did experience, an increase and a cost to operates certain contracts. And as a result, that has had their pressure on the overall international margins. Most of that work was previously performed by the hospital and as a result, there was difficult to get historical data prior to bidding. And what we're doing about that, how we're going to try on team is working diligently working on the cost overall, working on contract by contract basis, see if this cause some of them pastor our customers and be made some of those agreements. So that's certainly, something that's been, at the headwind in Q1, we think it will be a headwind for the rest of the year. And the other issue we're facing is in Latin America, obviously, the economic pressures and Latin America especially Brazil are impacting our business, the economic pressure most things in pricing pressure on government accounts. Just in Brazil alone 50% of our medical waste volumes are tied to government contract, when you think about Latin America, kind of for us, we had increased cost, we talked about that last year. Usually, in Latin America, we can pass those cost along, but now we're experiencing some headwinds with respect to government accounts and being able to pass along those prices. So we'll continue to work on that certainly, the team is working on all fronts to improve margins over a longer period of time. Acquisitions, we looked at certain markets, and we'll take a cautious stand in acquisitions, it's a good and that can acquisition that has a good return in our core business, certainly, willing to complete that. We're not looking to add a new services though at this point until we can get that base business stabilizes in some of the international countries.

componenttext: Sure. Scott. On the your recall and returns question. We had solid growth this quarter versus the prior year's quarter, greater than 20% year-over-year. So the 24 compared to 20 in Q1 of last year, so the team had a very good quarter obviously, continues to be an uneven business difficult for us to even forecast. The only reason to your question of why we brought the top end of the range now, after 1 quarter, see that one blockbuster really large recall, we did a couple of those to get to the high end of the range, so we experienced to shave the top end of the range down a little bit, team delivered a solid quarter and all the industry, auto, food and beverage, Pharma, med devices and consumer products. The team continues to do a really good job for us there. And we're exited about the opportunities in the quarters ahead. With respect to the consultant, and we'll talk about that in Q2, how many obviously, we looking at how that's organized the North American business and it's all consul and expert, it's a solutions and more importantly, how do we take Shred-it and integrate that into all of our businesses and leverage the information structure that we have really set us up for long-term growth. So I think when the Q2 calls comes along with talk about what the final outcome was, how do we structure ourselves, how we're going to have a better go-to-market strategy, to your life the better way to cross-sell our businesses and at the same time, in the financial we look at how we are measuring success in the new organizational structure, internally and then how externally we talk to our shareholders and analysts about the different metrics on our business. So that's our anticipation to track for, I think we set up well to talk about that on the July call, and those will be some of the topics we touch upon on our next earnings call.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle's First Quarter 2016  Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, ge
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle's First Quarter 2016  Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. 
Our actual results could differ significantly from the results described in the forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause such differences include: changes in governmental regulation of the collection, transportation, treatment and disposal of regulated waste or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing regulated waste collection and treatment or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; our obligations to service our substantial indebtedness and to comply with the covenants and restrictions contained in our private placement notes, term loan credit facility and revolving credit facility; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; competition and demand for services in the regulated waste and secure information destruction industries; political, economic and currency risks related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other indefinite-lived intangibles; variability in the demand for services we provide on a project or nonrecurring basis; exposure to environmental liabilities; fluctuations in the price we receive for the sale of paper; disruptions in or attacks on our information technology systems; compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements; as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K.
As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance. Investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. We make no commitments to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements.
I will now turn it over to Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us on today's call. In the first quarter, we experienced strong revenue growth, strong cash flow and solid sequential growth for the Shred-it acquisition. Results in the quarter were unfavorably impacted by the timing of the Shred-it
componenttext: Thank you for joining us on today's call. In the first quarter, we experienced strong revenue growth, strong cash flow and solid sequential growth for the Shred-it acquisition. Results in the quarter were unfavorably impacted by the timing of the Shred-it synergies and lower industrial hazardous waste revenues. Despite the challenges in the quarter, we remain confident about our business. Joining me on today's call be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and Brent Arnold, COO. I will now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Charlie. The results for the first quarter are as follows. Revenues were $874.2 million, up 31.8% from $663.3 million in Q1 2015 and internal growth excluding returns and [indiscernible] revenues with 5.6%. Domestic revenues were $649.7 million
componenttext:
Thank you, Charlie. The results for the first quarter are as follows. Revenues were $874.2 million, up 31.8% from $663.3 million in Q1 2015 and internal growth excluding returns and [indiscernible] revenues with 5.6%. Domestic revenues were $649.7 million of which $624.9 million was domestic regulated waste in compliance services and $24.8 million was recalls and returns.
First quarter domestic internal growth, excluding recalls and returns revenues was up 5%, consisting of SQ up 6%, and LQ up 4%. As anticipated, growth rates were impacted by lower fuel surcharges and lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers. International revenues were $224.5 million, and internal growth adjusted for unfavorable foreign exchange impact of $23.8 million was up 7%.
This growth rate was also impacted by lower hazardous waste volume. Acquisitions contributed to $194.5 million to growth in the quarter. Gross profit was $369.2 million or 42.2% of revenues. 
SG&A expense, including amortization was $207.3 million or 23.7% of revenues. 
Net interest expense was $24 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $66.7 million, or $0.78 per share on an as-reported basis, and $1.11 when adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjustments.
Our covenants, debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 3.41 at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $584 million. In the quarter, we repurchased 327,952 shares of common stock on the open market in an amount of $37,693,000. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 3.4 million shares.
Our CapEx was $34.2 million or 3.9% of revenues. Our DSO was 63 days. Year-to-date, cash from operations was $156.9 million, when adjusted for recall reimbursement and other items. Cash from operations was $163.6 million. I will now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 7 acquisitions, 5 domestic and 2 international. International acquisitions were 1 in Spain, and 1 in Romania. Revenues
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 7 acquisitions, 5 domestic and 2 international. International acquisitions were 1 in Spain, and 1 in Romania. Revenues in the 7 acquisitions were approximately $1 million in the quarter, and annualized are approximately $12.4 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 million [ph] annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business.
In the quarter, the Shred-it sales team delivered strong new sales growth. As a reminder, Shred-it has over 350 sales professionals across North America focused on converting customers that either do not shred or shred themselves. This unvended market represents at $2.5 billion growth opportunity for Stericycle.
We also are encouraged by the progress the combined sales teams are having and selling Shred-it solution. This quarter, the team closed 8 health systems in multiple national accounts. Today, less than 20% of our current Stericycle health care customers use Shred-it as a secure information instruction provider, representing a nice growth opportunity for Stericycle.
Our Shred-it integration efforts remain a priority across the organization. We are confident in our ability to achieve the full $73 million in Cintas/Shred-it synergies, and our team has either completed or made solid progress on many of the integration projects. 
However, we have reassessed the original time line associated with the re-routes and on-site to on-site conversion. While several regions have successfully made this conversion, the time to convert each region is taking longer than previously anticipated.
In order to ensure high service levels and support ongoing new customer growth, we have decided to extend the rollout schedule going forward.
The new time line enables the re-route teams to provide the necessary support and assistance without negatively impacting our customers. 
Based on these changes, approximately $20 million of dollars of the anticipated re-route and on-site to off-site synergies will be extended into 2017, with a full impact in 2018.
And our retail and healthcare hazardous waste compliance program, we continue to experience strong growth. The growth is fueled by increase in enforcement of existing regulation and by Stericycle strong customer relationships in both retail and the healthcare industry. 
Looking ahead, we continue to see expanding growth opportunities, as Stericycle provides multiple services that help our customers improve their operations and achieve their goal. 8
As we execute on the strategy, we can more than triple our customer's revenues.
We would like to congratulate Stericycle's partners for West Virginia facility for receiving congressional recognition as a star status site in Osho's voluntary protection program. This was the first medical waste facility to earn the VPP award, and it demonstrates the team's dedication to our corporate values.
In closing, I want to thank each member of our worldwide team for their continued commitment to our customers, our shareholders and our core values. I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016.Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related expen
componenttext:
Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016.
Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related expenses and other adjusted items. As a reminder, our 2016 EPS guidance is adjusted for amortization expense.
For 2016, we believe analyst EPS estimates will be in the range of $4.90 to $5.05, reflecting the unfavorable impact of the timing of the Shred-it synergies, software industrial hazardous waste volume and higher costs associated with our international operations.
We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2016 will be in the range of $3.6 billion to $3.66 billion, depending on assumptions for growth and the impact of foreign exchange rates. 
We anticipate 2016 internal growth rates to be: SQ, 7% to 9%; LQ 4% to 7%; International, 6% to 9%; and recall and returns revenues between $95 million and $115 million.
We believe analyst who have estimates for free cash flow in 2016 between $435 million and $455 million.
2016 CapEx is anticipated to be between $125 million to $135 million. We expect the 2016 full year as reported tax rate to be approximately 35.5%.
In closing, although disappointed with our results in Q1, we are confident about the long-term fundamentals in our business and remain excited about the growth opportunities in 2016 and beyond.
Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. Steve, you can open the queue.

componenttext: Yes. Ryan, I'd be happy to do that. So the prior guidance was $5.26 to $5.33. We had a $0.05 miss in the quarter, so that's obviously going to roll into the next guidance. There were some strength in paper prices and slightly lower interest rates, and we had some acquisition contribution, and that was offset by some higher depreciation expense, and that is to about $0.01 to $0.02 of favorable expense -- favorable EPS. The delay as -- Brent mentioned in his dialogue in recognition of Shred-it synergy is anywhere between $0.07 to $0.12 unfavorable. International, cost pressures in Latin America and the U.K. is between $0.07 to $0.10 unfavorable. And we had some softness in the industrial market and a mix of customers in [indiscernible] business, that will be anywhere from $0.10 to $0.11 on the year unfavorable. So the new guidance from there will bridge to $4.90 to $5.05. And I think when you're looking at Q2, I think it's best to pick a range between $1.16 and $1.20, and I think you'd be in good position for the quarter.

componenttext: Okay. And then, it's my follow-up. Can you go onto a little bit more detail on the elongation of the Shred-it synergies. Do you think that's just going through 2 separate mergers, it's kind of distracting that workforce? Or is it as you pushed some of the changes to route density improvements and moving to off-site, it's impacted customer churn or anything of that nature, such that you're trying to slow it down and kind of elongate that? headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, this is Brent. Absolutely. This is not about -- yes, we can get the on-site to off-site, and re-route synergies, but rather when we will get these. All of us either want to get these synergies as soon as possible. We just need to make sure we do it
componenttext: Ryan, this is Brent. Absolutely. This is not about -- yes, we can get the on-site to off-site, and re-route synergies, but rather when we will get these. All of us either want to get these synergies as soon as possible. We just need to make sure we do it in a time frame that does not negatively impact our customers. It probably makes sense to give a little bit of description of what we're talking about, and what really goes into and on-site to off-site conversion. First, with all of the conversions of this type, you have to have clean data, you need to know things like service location, number of consoles, hours of operation, key contact information. Let me remind you that the team recently went through a merger of operating systems, when Cintas joined Shred-it. And while that went well, they're definitely some items that still need to be cleaned up as part of that data cleanup. Then you notify the customers. So you're notifying all the customers that are currently on-site, and you're letting to know that we're going to be switching their service from on-site shredding with a truck that has a shredder on it. To taking that back to our facility and shredding it back at our facility. So you have to make sure you have all the right supplies, right, because you're switching trucks. So you have to have the right number of box trucks, liftgates, consoles, the transport, the materials. So all of those things needed to be in place. Ultimately though -- and this is really where we're noticing the biggest challenge is when you make the change, our team members now are going to new sites. So imagine, Ryan, if a CSR is coming to your facility, the number of consoles you have across William Blair, they're not serviced it before, you now are -- while they have a description of location in the handheld, you still need to find those. We needed to find you the best way to kind of wrap through your office to find all those consoles. So there is a learning curve that our CSRs or drivers need to go through, when we make these changes around. Believe it or not, the first probably several weeks after re-route, we're actually less efficient than we were before the re-route. But as they go to their learning cover and that settles down, we start to get efficiencies, and we ultimately, we'll do a final kind of polishing re-route to really put as many stops on those routes as possible. So again, our focus here is about how do we do this without impacting the customer, recognizing the synergies and ultimately doing it in the way that allows us to continue to close new business. The reason we're confident that we're going to get that $73 million, we've done this many times before. Our pilot market in Toronto, in Cleveland, in Charlotte, in Boston, in Detroit is the number of markets where we have successfully done this, but what we've decided to do is, you know what, this needs to be more of a 16-week process than an 8-week process, and the time line, we're just too aggressive. So when assessing that, we decided to extended out ultimately, because we do not want to disrupt the service with our customers.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Charlie. I'll take that. I think when you think about how is this waste with Stericycle roughly 80% is domestic, 20% is international, but if we dig down to the Q1 impact on what we call our environmental solutions business, hazardous waste v
componenttext: Yes. This is Charlie. I'll take that. I think when you think about how is this waste with Stericycle roughly 80% is domestic, 20% is international, but if we dig down to the Q1 impact on what we call our environmental solutions business, hazardous waste volumes that is excluding retail hazard waste and healthcare hazard waste, we're anticipating that to grow at seasonally -- seasonably adjusted rate of about 3%. It actually came in at a negative 4% for the quarter. So roughly speaking about $5.5 million soft on our industrial or hazardous waste volumes. In addition, the mix of the waste that we bid actually pick up in our project resulting in a higher-anticipated disposal expense of roughly about $1.5 million, and that has to do with some of the larger projects we did where direct disposal and we have direct disposal as opposed going through our facilities we do incur a higher disposal expense for those accounts, and that's what Dan was referring to when he was talking about mix in the environmental solutions business or hazardous waste business. So certainly, we did see a lower hazardous waste volume. The good news I think though, and Brent talked about in his opening is, where we are focused, that's the healthcare hazardous waste, that's the retail hazardous waste, that's the SQ hazardous waste. We had really strong growth there, but unfortunately, we have a mix issue when it comes to the facilities that we've acquired to support this growth. And that has a very high fixed cost to it and that's what you see hurting us not only on the revenue line but also on the profit line.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I just want to ask about the international business. Just looking at the 10-K, you indicated [indiscernible] obviously you have given more detail, and the margins there relative to U.S. business are like less than 1/3 the amount. I know that got
componenttext: I guess, I just want to ask about the international business. Just looking at the 10-K, you indicated [indiscernible] obviously you have given more detail, and the margins there relative to U.S. business are like less than 1/3 the amount. I know that got hurt last year by [indiscernible] like the U.S. did, but I guess the question is this, is there a credible plan and strategy to narrow that gap in the next 2 to 3 years. And for years, you've talked about, if you can move the mix more to SQ that will take care of it, but it doesn't seem to me that you had much success with that at least overall, because those margins are down several years in a row. And that level of profitability, can you justify continue to do M&A in the international waste business. It just seems like there's no way you're getting good returns if you can't really improve the profitability?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think I'm going to take that 2 sets. I want to walk you through what are some of the pressures that we're facing currently Gary, and then walking out I'll take a stab at your question around long term what I think we can do there. But the pressure
componenttext: Yes. I think I'm going to take that 2 sets. I want to walk you through what are some of the pressures that we're facing currently Gary, and then walking out I'll take a stab at your question around long term what I think we can do there. But the pressure points -- and we feel will be the pressure points for the rest of the year are in 2 distinct lines. It's first of all, that's the view with our patient transport business in the U.K., and obviously, that's been one of our biggest contributors to our international cost pressures because it has rapidly grown over the last several years. We continued to experience an increase in the cost to operate certain contracts. And as a result, that has had a pressure on the overall international margins. Just educating, most of that work was previously performed by the hospital, and as a result, there was difficult to get historical data prior to bidding. And what we're doing about that, how we're going to try to work on that. Well, the team is working diligently. They are working on these cost overrides. They are working on a contract-by-contract basis, to see if these costs some of them to be passed to our customers and we made [indiscernible] exiting some of those agreements. So that's certainly is something that's been a headwind in Q1. We think it will be a headwind for the rest of the year. The other issue we're facing is in Latin America, obviously, the economic pressures in Latin America, especially in Brazil, are impacting our business. The economic pressures are mostly in the form of now pricing pressure on government accounts. Just in Brazil alone 58% of our medical waste volumes are tied to government contracts. When you think about Latin America, kind of, a perfect storm for us. We had increased cost, we talked about that last year. Usually, in Latin America, we can pass those costs along, but now we're experiencing some headwinds with respect to government accounts and being able to pass along those prices. So we'll continue to work on that certainly. The team is working on all fronts to improve margins over a longer period of time. Acquisitions, we looked at certain markets, and we'll take a cautious stand on acquisitions. If it's a good tuck-in acquisition that has a good return in our core business, certainly, we'll look to complete that. To add, we're not looking to add any new services though at this point until we can get the base business stabilized in some of the international countries.

componenttext: Yes. Let me take you through that, because I can see how you can get to that number. Remember, as a mandatory convertible there is a range on this. So anything below $136 or let's put it this way, a $136.25 is the maximum dilution of this, and that translates into 5.6 million shares. No matter where the price is below that, you will not see a greater converted share count, anything above $136 at the door $170, we'll then being to become less diluted, and can actually go to low as 4.5 million shares, and never less diluted than that. So Gary, at the level we're at right now, you will see no greater dilution with that in 91.8 million shares for the year as a good estimate to you.

componenttext: Okay. And if I could ask, kind of, a 2-part follow-up. The -- Could you speak to RMS in the quarter. It looked like nothing too dramatic there versus trend. I saw you took down the high-end of the guidance range for the year by $5 million. Just what trends you're seeing. And then I'll ask my third question now with it. Just with what -- what should we expect to hear on the second quarter call, when you talk about working with the consultants and what you're assessing. What type of outputs are we going to hear? I know you're not going to quantify today, but what are the changes that are coming, just if you could give us a taste?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Scott. On the your recall and returns question. We had solid growth this quarter versus the prior year's quarter, greater than 20% year-over-year. So the 24 compared to 20 in Q1 of last year, so the team had a very good quarter. Obviously, it contin
componenttext: Sure, Scott. On the your recall and returns question. We had solid growth this quarter versus the prior year's quarter, greater than 20% year-over-year. So the 24 compared to 20 in Q1 of last year, so the team had a very good quarter. Obviously, it continues to be an uneven business, difficult for us to even forecast. The only reason to your question of why we brought the top end of the range now, we just -- after 1 quarter, still haven't seen that one blockbuster really large recall. We need a couple of those to get to the high end of the range, so we probably just to shave the top end of the range down a little bit. But the team delivered solid quarter on all the industries, auto, food and beverage, Pharma, med devices, consumer products. The team continues to do a really good job for us there, and we're exited about the opportunities in the quarters ahead. With respect to the consultant -- and we'll talk about on Q2. I mean, obviously, we are looking at how best or organized the North American business. And it's all the business, it is console and expert, it's environmental solutions, and more importantly, how do we take Shred-it and integrate that into all of our businesses and leverage, the infrastructure that we have, it really set us up for long-term growth. So I think when the Q2 calls comes along, we'll talk about what the final outcome was, how do we structure ourselves, how we're going to have a better go-to-market strategy to utilize a better way to cross-sell our businesses. And at the same time, Dan and the finance team will look at, well, how are we measuring success in the new organizational structure internally, and then how externally we talk to our shareholders and our analysts about the different matrix on our business. So that's our anticipation I will track for. I think we are set up well to talk about that on the July call, and those will be some of the topics we touch upon on our next earnings call.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First one just on the synergies. So you're looking at now $53 million in synergies in 2016. How does that play out over the quarters. And what is baked into the 2016 guidance from perspective of the Stericycle synergies that you talked about in the back h
componenttext: First one just on the synergies. So you're looking at now $53 million in synergies in 2016. How does that play out over the quarters. And what is baked into the 2016 guidance from perspective of the Stericycle synergies that you talked about in the back half?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, let me kind of work with you on the synergy numbers. Our previous guidance was $51 million of synergies would be in 2016. With us pushing out these on-site to off-site conversions and reducing that by 20, we're now at $31 million will hit 2016. Tho
componenttext: Brian, let me kind of work with you on the synergy numbers. Our previous guidance was $51 million of synergies would be in 2016. With us pushing out these on-site to off-site conversions and reducing that by 20, we're now at $31 million will hit 2016. Those conversions will go throughout probably mid-2017. So we'll recognize the full $73 million in 2018.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And yes, those numbers are in the guidance.
componenttext: And yes, those numbers are in the guidance.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: And as far as the Stericycle synergies that you asked Brian, the $20 million to $30 million, we've always said those will start in 2017 but realized in '18.

componenttext: Although, you're going to start -- so really there all 2017, you're not going to realize any of that in 2016?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is it possible to provide some kind of business line detail on either revenue and profitability kind of going through the stuff outside of regulated medical waste, such as the hazardous waste, document destruction, patient, communications?
componenttext: Okay. And is it possible to provide some kind of business line detail on either revenue and profitability kind of going through the stuff outside of regulated medical waste, such as the hazardous waste, document destruction, patient, communications?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Brian, I'll address that. And make sure we follow the conversation that Charlie just had below. I can give you certain average and color, but remember I think you should look for maybe some enhanced reporting once we go through the consultant review.
componenttext: Yes. Brian, I'll address that. And make sure we follow the conversation that Charlie just had below. I can give you certain average and color, but remember I think you should look for maybe some enhanced reporting once we go through the consultant review. And how we run the business, we'll report based on a true reflection of how we run the business. I think what you have asked for and that we've given historically as businesses like [indiscernible] from a gross margin standpoint, it's running at about company average with an EBIT in the low teens, which is lower. It's more SG&A-intensive as you could imagine. Our Enviromental solutions got gross margins in about the mid-20s. And again, due to some of the costs that Charlie talked about, that's in the kind of a -- probably, just below double digits. And then Shred-it where we given you some historical on that and it's got EBIT margins in the -- we tend to look at that, though, on an EBITDA, which is 16.5 [ph]. I don't have the EBIT numbers for you, but we've always talk to you historically from an EBITDA perspective. And that's a low mid-20s business that we think over time from an EBITDA perspective. We can improve very well. So I think I don't know if there is anymore that you need on that, but I think that covers most of what we can give.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just maybe try one last one in there. On the regulated medical waste, on the domestic, it's 5% growth organic? Was there something in that price or volume and does that just -- you see that recover just gradually to the rest of the ye
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just maybe try one last one in there. On the regulated medical waste, on the domestic, it's 5% growth organic? Was there something in that price or volume and does that just -- you see that recover just gradually to the rest of the year, kind of, get into your targets? Or is there something else that was missed there?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Keep in mind Brian, the SQ growth and the LQ growth, they're not just medical waste. Over 50% of our SQ growth and 70% of our LQ growth comes from additional services, like consoles, compliant services, Rx waste disposals. So that's not just medical
componenttext: Yes. Keep in mind Brian, the SQ growth and the LQ growth, they're not just medical waste. Over 50% of our SQ growth and 70% of our LQ growth comes from additional services, like consoles, compliant services, Rx waste disposals. So that's not just medical waste. We actually did well on our growth rate, although the SQ growth rates were 6 and 4. If you adjust those growth rates for the impact of the fuel surcharge and the lower hazard waste volume, it would have been more like a 9 and a 6 in the quarter.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Isaac Ro with Goldman Sachs.

componenttext: It's actually Joel in for Isaac. Just another one on the domestic medical waste business. Any update to your strategy with some of those large providers systems and IDNs? Anything you guys may have learned from some of the deals you struck thus far that you are using to negotiate any new contracts?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you're referring to the Shred-it contracts that we signed this quarter. I'll let Brent answer that. And I'll give a little color what we're seeing. I think you also talking about IDNs, and I think we have some color there as well. But Brent c
componenttext: Yes. I think you're referring to the Shred-it contracts that we signed this quarter. I'll let Brent answer that. And I'll give a little color what we're seeing. I think you also talking about IDNs, and I think we have some color there as well. But Brent can talk to you about what we're seeing early on, on the success in the secure information destruction for some of those LQ systems.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Joel, secure information destruction fits in really well with our LQ or hospital sales force. As we talked about in previous calls, we've got an Account Manager, a sales specialist model that has served extremely well for us to add on additional serv
componenttext: Yes. Joel, secure information destruction fits in really well with our LQ or hospital sales force. As we talked about in previous calls, we've got an Account Manager, a sales specialist model that has served extremely well for us to add on additional services with our customers, whether that would be our [indiscernible] management program or pharmaceutical waste program or hazardous waste program, this will feather nicely with that as well as just one more solution we can bring our customers. We had a lot of success adding on new services within health care and integrating network. So we're very bullish and confident. We'll be able to do that very well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Joel, just to give a little color on just larger hospital systems in the U.S., we've always kept an eye on that. Obviously, you got to cover health care and you know there is a consolidation of SQ practices by hospital systems. We are starting to obse
componenttext: And Joel, just to give a little color on just larger hospital systems in the U.S., we've always kept an eye on that. Obviously, you got to cover health care and you know there is a consolidation of SQ practices by hospital systems. We are starting to observe some longer sales cycle at these hospital-affiliated SQ customers. Remember the decision-maker changes a little bit when the hospital acquires a doctor's practice, where we normally deal with an office administrator or office manager. We are now dealing with more personnel from the hospital. So we believe we'll see some pricing pressure on hospital-affiliated SQ account as these contracts come up for renewal. But on the flip side, it does create an opportunity to sell a broader suite of more LQ type services, like pharmaceutical waste disposal and our [indiscernible] management system. To give you a little bit of color on that, we estimate that about 16% of our SQ accounts are now somewhat hospital affiliated internally. Stericycle refers to that as a blend customer, and we, certainly, are keeping an eye on that consolidation and the decision-making process.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Interest was just a touch lower than guidance. And so I think, if you were to look at the year, I think if you just brought it down about $1 million from what we shared last quarter from $106 million to $105 million, I think that's a safe range to be in.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
