headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, maybe if you could give us Shred-it revenue gross profit and EBIT contribution this quarter?
componenttext: Dan, maybe if you could give us Shred-it revenue gross profit and EBIT contribution this quarter?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me take you through kind of how they performed from a revenue standpoint. In the quarter, it was about a $185 million, which is a good growth from last quarter. And remember, in that number includes acquisitions, and so I take [indiscernible] als
componenttext: Yes. Let me take you through kind of how they performed from a revenue standpoint. In the quarter, it was about a $185 million, which is a good growth from last quarter. And remember, in that number includes acquisitions, and so I take [indiscernible] also about up $177 million, which was the acquired quarterly run rate. So pleased with the growth there. As we went through the bridge, and I can share with you that they had pulled some marketing COGS forwards that effected the EBITA or EBITDA margins a little bit, and they got some higher cost. But they are largely performing pretty well I think from a guidance perspective and the rest of the year when you looking at the model. They are running at an EBIT that when we delayed the synergies now I think it will be around 13.5 [ph] because we're moving those synergies out. We are going to get to pick those out next year. And then bad accounts also for the change in paper prices. From an EBITDA perspective, just down by about same amount. I think it was 200 [ph] we gave you last time, about 184 [ph] now.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, you mentioned Communication Solutions. Could you give us an update there, I think STERICONNECT is fully implemented. When do you anticipate the growth inflection occurring in this service?
componenttext: Okay. And then, you mentioned Communication Solutions. Could you give us an update there, I think STERICONNECT is fully implemented. When do you anticipate the growth inflection occurring in this service?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the new platform is alive at STERICONNECT. Accounts, as we spoke about in the last call, are being transitioned down to the new system and this will continue throughout 2016. This is a very slow process as we said to convert these customers onto t
componenttext: Yes. So the new platform is alive at STERICONNECT. Accounts, as we spoke about in the last call, are being transitioned down to the new system and this will continue throughout 2016. This is a very slow process as we said to convert these customers onto the platform. Health care calls are very customized, and they are customized on an account-by-account basis. So it takes a long time to convert them into the new system. So far it's going well. At the same time, we'll be integrating our live voice infrastructure, that's the STERICONNECT system with our automated product portfolio. So things like automated fund reminders, scheduling, so this will include a cloud-based automated scheduling, and automated appointment reminder service. And this does put us in a very unique position vis-à-vis our competitors in the market. And actually, we had new growth for Q1 for console and it was a slightly ahead of our internal projections for the quarter. So there are off to a good start for the year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, Charlie, when you talked about secure document destruction in the past, and the kind of secular decline in paper overall. You've mentioned that what should be out there, so 10 or 15 years from now, that the company will be prov
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, Charlie, when you talked about secure document destruction in the past, and the kind of secular decline in paper overall. You've mentioned that what should be out there, so 10 or 15 years from now, that the company will be providing additional data security services. Just wondering if you can give us a broad idea of what are the non-paper-based data security services you might be able to provide.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Brent. Some services, additional services that are available now, that we look to expand as they have got hard drive destruction services. So while small that's a new adjacent market that is a very large and profitable market we can go afte
componenttext: David, this is Brent. Some services, additional services that are available now, that we look to expand as they have got hard drive destruction services. So while small that's a new adjacent market that is a very large and profitable market we can go after. And we also hope to develop the same type of compliance programs that we're very successful selling to our SQ customers and to roll that out kind of like a Steri-Safe for business, a business essentials package that we can take to those customers and hopefully sell through the large sales force they have as well as their inside sales team.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin Steinke with Barrington Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin Steinke with Barrington Research.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. I think in the past, you have talked about working to reduce your exposure to project-based industrial waste work and maybe even trying to convert that to more of a recurring model. So is that something you're still thinking abou
componenttext: Good afternoon, everyone. I think in the past, you have talked about working to reduce your exposure to project-based industrial waste work and maybe even trying to convert that to more of a recurring model. So is that something you're still thinking about or any progress on that front.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think this is a good time may be to take out a step back and think about that business. And tell you -- and really -- by taking a step back and telling you why we got into, what the strategy is for the long run. If you think about it 6 years ago, w
componenttext: Yes. I think this is a good time may be to take out a step back and think about that business. And tell you -- and really -- by taking a step back and telling you why we got into, what the strategy is for the long run. If you think about it 6 years ago, we identified 2 significant growth opportunities, retail and healthcare hazardous waste. And why do we think they were good for Stericycle, they were a route-based business, they were SQ type volumes, they came with complex regulatory issues for the generator of the waste or the customer. And we had established relationship in a lot of those markets. So we looked at it, we said that retail hazardous waste businesses was approximately $1 billion, and we still think that today. And the health care SQ has waste market, we identified it's at least $1 billion market. And we quickly become the market leader in these growing segments. But unfortunately, as we spoke about before, we needed to add our operational infrastructure to support our growth. So know we acquired PSC, we acquired other acquisitions to give us that additional facilities in order to meet the demand of the growing business. Unfortunately, these acquisitions came with other hazardous waste streams as industrial waste, other hazardous waste, project work. And obviously, we're frustrated that this base revenue is shrinking and most of this is really outside of our control and it's more market driven. But we also have to look at what can we do better on the cost escalations on that business to make it better. But we needed the infrastructure, it came with some things that we didn't want to focus on, where we are focusing, we're seeing really great growth and the health care has and retail has. So we continue to look at that as a focus for the business, and we think overtime that will become a bigger part and that will minimize the impact of this industrial and project work. And I think about why do we still think it's a good business, I mean, that's I'm sure question of should you guys be focused on this or not. And you think about recent enforcement action, recently Comcast announced a $26 million settlement in this state of California. It was related to 2 things. It was related to the improper disposal of hazardous waste and the disposal of secured information. So obviously, enforcement continues to build a awareness, and I think this is a great example of how we have the ability to cross-sell a wide variety of compliance-related services over the customer base that we have or over one customer. So that's really our strategy and continues to be our strategy, is to focus on retail, health care and SQ hazardous waste.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And have you made any changes in the assumptions within your guidance for paper prices. And do you continue to work on negotiating surcharges and contracts, I know that's kind of a longer-term initiative, but any update there and als
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And have you made any changes in the assumptions within your guidance for paper prices. And do you continue to work on negotiating surcharges and contracts, I know that's kind of a longer-term initiative, but any update there and also what you're assuming for the paper pricing?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In Q1, started off with paper pricing increase by about $7.50 a tonne from our last call. So last call it was at 126 as an average price, the end price of the quarter, at the end price of Q1, it's at 133.50, and that's what we assume now on our guid
componenttext:
Sure. In Q1, started off with paper pricing increase by about $7.50 a tonne from our last call. So last call it was at 126 as an average price, the end price of the quarter, at the end price of Q1, it's at 133.50, and that's what we assume now on our guidance going forward. 
Obviously, in Q1, you don't get the entire 133.50, because that grew incrementally over the quarter, but that's what [indiscernible] is used in the model right now as 133.50 or approximately $4 million for the rest of the year, because of that slight increase. We are starting to look at contracts, and make changes on agreements, that's on a contract-by-contract basis, we know that will take us several years to implement. And more to come on that in the coming quarters.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line Hamzah Mazari with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line Hamzah Mazari with Sterne Agee.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had one question, I know you guys are delaying some of the synergies to prevent disruption. But maybe if you could frame the upside potential, upside the synergies for investors longer-term?
componenttext: Just had one question, I know you guys are delaying some of the synergies to prevent disruption. But maybe if you could frame the upside potential, upside the synergies for investors longer-term?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me take that Hamzah. I mean, we think about one of the reasons we're going through the consultant study is that, we think there will be an opportunity down the road, when we're looking at markets that don't have density, where we might be able to
componenttext: Yes. Let me take that Hamzah. I mean, we think about one of the reasons we're going through the consultant study is that, we think there will be an opportunity down the road, when we're looking at markets that don't have density, where we might be able to combine some routes and have our drivers are the Shred-it drivers combined both medical waste and secure information on the same truck. And by definition those rural routes are not dense, they're not dense with secured information, they'll not dense for regulated medical waste. So one of the reasons we are taking our time on the study, one of the reasons we're taking time not to disrupt customers as we know there will be opportunities over the next 2, 3, 4 years to improve both the operations of our Stericycle business, and the Shred-it business. There will be things like we have a tech inside the hospital, collecting sharps containers. Our plan long-term is to make sure, if we have a hospital account to secure information destruction that tech, while they are there, will collect all the secured information bin. So will turn an account that used to take a secure information driver a long time because they [indiscernible] park their truck walk throughout the hospital, like all these bins. We will have a waiting for that driver and it'll be just another stopper they're picking up on that way. So certainly, we're still excited about that, I think as we get closer to the Shred-it business, we -- all the things we thought about and how closely it is related to Stericycle and what we do, we think there are things like that longer-term that really set us up to improve the overall margin for Stericycle going forward.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Levine with Imperial Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Levine with Imperial Capital.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to be clear, it sounds like the issues within the industrial hazardous waste are identical or very similar to the issues you experienced in 3Q of last year. I was hoping you might be able to confirm that, maybe elaborate and whether there has been
componenttext: So just to be clear, it sounds like the issues within the industrial hazardous waste are identical or very similar to the issues you experienced in 3Q of last year. I was hoping you might be able to confirm that, maybe elaborate and whether there has been any change whatsoever in either the types of customers that you're seeing to slowdown with or are there any differences between you experienced here in 1Q versus what you experienced in 3Q '15.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the big difference is what we experienced in Q3 was more fuel and energy related. And we know, we saw that we're not going to take up any part of that project or larger volumes in the foreseeable future. I think this is just -- we're seeing a
componenttext: Yes. I think the big difference is what we experienced in Q3 was more fuel and energy related. And we know, we saw that we're not going to take up any part of that project or larger volumes in the foreseeable future. I think this is just -- we're seeing a slowdown in the hazardous waste, excluding the retail and healthcare hazardous. And we already knew there is some seasonality, and we adjusted for that, we just saw an actual decrease above and beyond seasonality. So I think that's the main difference, it's not as dramatic in this quarter. I mean there is a mix issue, where on the project works we did do in Q1, we did see a higher disposal expense related to that just based on the type of projects. And to be conservative, we want to make sure that we look to Q1 and then we said if that continues what does that mean for god [ph] is for the rest of the year. Certainly, it's not as big as the drop-off in Q3. And I don't think it's related, because I think one was certainly, related to fuel energy, and this just a softer hazardous waste market in manufacturing industry.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: I'm sorry, go ahead.

componenttext: Just to add to that. Now we're facing all of that. Again, the focused areas as Charlie about, healthcare hazardous and retail continue to have great growth.

componenttext: Yes. As we gave guidance for the year, and I think Charlie already mentioned it, but it's about $0.10 to $0.11. And I would expect that to be spread evenly throughout the year.

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jason Rodgers with Great Lakes review.

componenttext: Just had a follow-up on the hazardous waste. How much revenue was left in industrial and project work. And what is the expectation by the year-end?

componenttextpreview: Yes. If you think about some of the broad buckets Jason on hazardous waste. And the larger industrial and project work is about a $100 million to $120 million, we talked about that last time. We have about $210 million to $220 million in the retail health
componenttext: Yes. If you think about some of the broad buckets Jason on hazardous waste. And the larger industrial and project work is about a $100 million to $120 million, we talked about that last time. We have about $210 million to $220 million in the retail healthcare hazardous, it's waste bucket. There is a bucket of just general hazardous waste, which is the remaining part of that, which is both small quantity, larger quantity, there is some project work in that. But I think, the thing you're getting into there, the larger industrial project work is about $100 million to $120 million.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of Barbara Noverini with Morningstar.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Barbara Noverini with Morningstar.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is something that I think about, when I think about the growth in your hazardous waste lines of business. So obviously, the beauty about your medical waste business is that it's basically a closed loop. You can pick up the waste and dispose it, if
componenttext: So this is something that I think about, when I think about the growth in your hazardous waste lines of business. So obviously, the beauty about your medical waste business is that it's basically a closed loop. You can pick up the waste and dispose it, if you're in facilities primarily. So where as an industrial has, you're lined on third-party disposal providers, which increases your cost. Are you able to leverage any of your facilities to dispose off the healthcare or retail hazardous waste, or are you also reliant on third-party disposal in those lines of business as well?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The reason we focused, if we want to focus on the retail and the healthcare hazardous waste, Barbara. There is opportunity, where we bring that material back to our TSDF facilities. We can do, we can break that waste apart, we try not to use incinera
componenttext: Yes. The reason we focused, if we want to focus on the retail and the healthcare hazardous waste, Barbara. There is opportunity, where we bring that material back to our TSDF facilities. We can do, we can break that waste apart, we try not to use incineration or even [indiscernible] that material, sometimes we can remediate that material sometimes it's used as an alternative fuel. So that's why our focus is there, because that part of the business is not as an dependent on disposal hazardous projects and larger industrial waste. And overtime, we'd like to grow that. So that the industrial and hazardous waste part of the business is just a baseline business for us and it's a small part of the larger business. And in our RX waste, all of the nonhazardous pharmaceutical waste, we actually can utilizing our medical waste facilities for that material. So we do have a closed loop on some of that non-haz pharmaceutical waste, when we sell that product to a hospital or to a doctor's office, even some of the mail box that we have and the take back program. We'll actually utilize from our own, our goal is to utilize some of our own medical waste facility. So we certainly -- that's something we consider when we got into this business. When we looked at, while we want to grow those particular segments.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Totally right. I think Barbara you fall [indiscernible] let's talk a full [ph] on time. If you go back to the early day of Stericycle, when we were mostly in LQ business and not making much profit. We had obviously, 65% to 75% of our business was the LQ medical waste. And we focused for years on the SQ side of the business. We didn't get out of the LQ business, because you need that as a baseline for your facilities, but what did we do fast forward 15 years, safety is a 65% of our business now as SQ, and LQ, which still has a low profit to it, is a smaller part of the overall business. So this is going to take time, we realize that. But I think you've seen it before, from Stericycle we're focusing on those smaller markets to have better profitability where we can control on our destiny, we're not going to walk away from this hazardous waste in the larger industrial waste market, but we do want to make it a smaller part of that business overtime.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Steve, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] VP of corporate finance, Sean McMillan, you may begin your conference.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle's First Quarter 2016  Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, ge
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle's First Quarter 2016  Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. 
Our actual results could differ significantly from the results described in the forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause such differences include: changes in governmental regulation of the collection, transportation, treatment and disposal of regulated waste or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing regulated waste collection and treatment or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; our obligations to service our substantial indebtedness and to comply with the covenants and restrictions contained in our private placement notes, term loan credit facility and revolving credit facility; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; competition and demand for services in the regulated waste and secure information destruction industries; political, economic and currency risks related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other indefinite-lived intangibles; variability in the demand for services we provide on a project or nonrecurring basis; exposure to environmental liabilities; fluctuations in the price we receive for the sale of paper; disruptions in or attacks on our information technology systems; compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements; as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K.
As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance. Investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. We make no commitments to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements.
I will now turn it over to Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us on today's call. In the first quarter, we experienced strong revenue growth, strong cash flow and solid sequential growth for the Shred-it acquisition. Results in the quarter were unfavorably impacted by the timing of the Shred-it
componenttext: Thank you for joining us on today's call. In the first quarter, we experienced strong revenue growth, strong cash flow and solid sequential growth for the Shred-it acquisition. Results in the quarter were unfavorably impacted by the timing of the Shred-it synergies and lower industrial hazardous waste revenues. Despite the challenges in the quarter, we remain confident about our business. Joining me on today's call be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and Brent Arnold, COO. I will now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Charlie. The results for the first quarter are as follows. Revenues were $874.2 million, up 31.8% from $663.3 million in Q1 2015 and internal growth excluding returns and [indiscernible] revenues with 5.6%. Domestic revenues were $649.7 million
componenttext:
Thank you, Charlie. The results for the first quarter are as follows. Revenues were $874.2 million, up 31.8% from $663.3 million in Q1 2015 and internal growth excluding returns and [indiscernible] revenues with 5.6%. Domestic revenues were $649.7 million of which $624.9 million was domestic regulated waste in compliance services and $24.8 million was recalls and returns.
First quarter domestic internal growth, excluding recalls and returns revenues was up 5%, consisting of SQ up 6%, and LQ up 4%. As anticipated, growth rates were impacted by lower fuel surcharges and lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers. International revenues were $224.5 million, and internal growth adjusted for unfavorable foreign exchange impact of $23.8 million was up 7%.
This growth rate was also impacted by lower hazardous waste volume. Acquisitions contributed to $194.5 million to growth in the quarter. Gross profit was $369.2 million or 42.2% of revenues. 
SG&A expense, including amortization was $207.3 million or 23.7% of revenues. 
Net interest expense was $24 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $66.7 million, or $0.78 per share on an as-reported basis, and $1.11 when adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjustments.
Our covenant, debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 3.41 at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $584 million. In the quarter, we repurchased 327,952 shares of common stock on the open market in an amount of $37,693,000. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 3.4 million shares.
Our CapEx was $34.2 million or 3.9% of revenues. Our DSO was 63 days. Year-to-date, cash from operations was $156.9 million, when adjusted for recall reimbursement and other items. Cash from operations was $163.6 million. I will now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 7 acquisitions, 5 domestic and 2 international. International acquisitions were 1 in Spain, and 1 in Romania. Revenues
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisitions. In the quarter, we closed 7 acquisitions, 5 domestic and 2 international. International acquisitions were 1 in Spain, and 1 in Romania. Revenues in the 7 acquisitions were approximately $1 million in the quarter, and annualized are approximately $12.4 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 million annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business.
In the quarter, the Shred-it sales team delivered strong new sales growth. As a reminder, Shred-it has over 350 sales professionals across North America focused on converting customers that either do not shred or shred themselves. This unvended market represents at $2.5 billion growth opportunity for Stericycle.
We also are encouraged by the progress the combined sales teams are having and selling Shred-it solution. This quarter, the team closed 8 health systems in multiple national accounts. Today, less than 20% of our current Stericycle health care customers use Shred-it as a secure information destruction provider, representing a nice growth opportunity for Stericycle.
Our Shred-it integration efforts remain a priority across the organization. We are confident in our ability to achieve the full $73 million in Cintas/Shred-it synergies, and our team has either completed or made solid progress on many of the integration projects. 
However, we have reassessed the original time line associated with the re-routes and on-site to on-site conversion. While several regions have successfully made this conversion, the time to convert each region is taking longer than previously anticipated.
In order to ensure high service levels and support ongoing new customer growth, we have decided to extend the rollout schedule going forward.
The new time line enables the re-route teams to provide the necessary support and assistance without negatively impacting our customers. 
Based on these changes, approximately $20 million of dollars of the anticipated re-route and on-site to off-site synergies will be extended into 2017, with a full impact in 2018.
And our retail and healthcare hazardous waste compliance program, we continue to experience strong growth. The growth is fueled by increase in enforcement of existing regulation and by Stericycle strong customer relationships in both retail and the healthcare industry. 
Looking ahead, we continue to see expanding growth opportunities, as Stericycle provides multiple services that help our customers improve their operations and achieve their goal. 
As we execute on the strategy, we can more than triple our customer's revenues.
We would like to congratulate Stericycle's partners for West Virginia facility for receiving congressional recognition as a star status site in Osho's voluntary protection program. This was the first medical waste facility to earn the VPP award, and it demonstrates the team's dedication to our corporate values.
In closing, I want to thank each member of our worldwide team for their continued commitment to our customers, our shareholders and our core values. I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016.Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related expen
componenttext:
Thanks, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016.
Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration, acquisition-related expenses and other adjusted items. As a reminder, our 2016 EPS guidance is adjusted for amortization expense.
For 2016, we believe analyst EPS estimates will be in the range of $4.90 to $5.05, reflecting the unfavorable impact of the timing of the Shred-it synergies, software industrial hazardous waste volume and higher costs associated with our international operations.
We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2016 will be in the range of $3.6 billion to $3.66 billion, depending on assumptions for growth and the impact of foreign exchange rates. 
We anticipate 2016 internal growth rates to be: SQ, 7% to 9%; LQ 4% to 7%; International, 6% to 9%; and recall and returns revenues between $95 million and $115 million.
We believe analyst who have estimates for free cash flow in 2016 between $435 million and $455 million.
2016 CapEx is anticipated to be between $125 million to $135 million. We expect the 2016 full year as reported tax rate to be approximately 35.5%.
In closing, although disappointed with our results in Q1, we are confident about the long-term fundamentals in our business and remain excited about the growth opportunities in 2016 and beyond.
Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. Steve, you can open the queue.

componenttext: Yes. Ryan, I'd be happy to do that. So the prior guidance was $5.26 to $5.33. We had a $0.05 miss in the quarter, so that's obviously going to roll into the next guidance. There were some strength in paper prices and slightly lower interest rates, and we had some acquisition contribution, and that was offset by some higher depreciation expense, and that nets to about $0.01 to $0.02 of favorable expense -- favorable EPS. The delay as -- Brent mentioned in his dialogue in recognition of Shred-it synergy is anywhere between $0.07 to $0.12 unfavorable. International, cost pressures in Latin America and the U.K. is between $0.07 to $0.10 unfavorable. And we had some softness in the industrial market and a mix of customers in eSol [ph] business, that will be anywhere from $0.10 to $0.11 on the year unfavorable. So the new guidance from there will bridge to $4.90 to $5.05. And I think when you're looking at Q2, I think it's best to pick a range between $1.16 and $1.20, and I think you'd be in good position for the quarter.

componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, as my follow-up, can you go into a little bit more detail on the elongation of the Shred-it synergies. Do you think that's just going through 2 separate mergers, it's kind of distracting that workforce? Or is it as you pushed some of the c
componenttext: Okay. And then, as my follow-up, can you go into a little bit more detail on the elongation of the Shred-it synergies. Do you think that's just going through 2 separate mergers, it's kind of distracting that workforce? Or is it as you pushed some of the changes to route density improvements and moving to off-site, it's impacted customer churn or anything of that nature, such that you're trying to slow it down and kind of elongate that? Just any color there would be helpful.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, this is Brent. Absolutely. This is not about if we can get the on-site to off-site and re-route synergies, but rather when we will get these. All of us either want to get these synergies as soon as possible. We just need to make sure we do it in a t
componenttext: Ryan, this is Brent. Absolutely. This is not about if we can get the on-site to off-site and re-route synergies, but rather when we will get these. All of us either want to get these synergies as soon as possible. We just need to make sure we do it in a time frame that does not negatively impact our customers. It probably makes sense to give a little bit of description of what we're talking about, and what really goes into and on-site to off-site conversion. First, with all of the conversions of this type, you have to have clean data, you need to know things like service location, number of consoles, hours of operation, key contact information. Let me remind you that the team recently went through a merger of operating systems, when Cintas joined Shred-it. And while that went well, they're definitely some items that still need to be cleaned up as part of that data cleanup. Then you notify the customers. So you're notifying all the customers that are currently on-site, and you're letting to know that we're going to be switching their service from on-site shredding with a truck that has a shredder on it. To taking that back to our facility and shredding it back at our facility. So you have to make sure you have all the right supplies, right, because you're switching trucks. So you have to have the right number of box trucks, liftgates, consoles, to transport the materials. So all of those things needed to be in place. Ultimately though -- and this is really where we're noticing the biggest challenge is when you make the change, our team members now are going to new sites. So imagine, Ryan, if a CSR is coming to your facility, the number of consoles you have across William Blair, they've not serviced it before, you now are -- while they have a description of location in the handheld, you still need to find those. We needed to find you the best way to kind of route through your office to find all those consoles. So there is a learning curve that our CSRs or drivers need to go through, when we make these changes around. Believe it or not, the first probably several weeks after a re-route, we're actually less efficient than we were before the re-route. But as they go to their learning cover and that settles down, we start to get efficiencies, and we ultimately, we'll do a final kind of polishing re-route to really put as many stops on those routes as possible. So again, our focus here is about how do we do this without impacting the customer, recognizing the synergies and ultimately doing it in the way that allows us to continue to close new business. The reason we're confident that we're going to get that $73 million, we've done this many times before. Our pilot market in Toronto, in Cleveland, in Charlotte, in Boston, in Detroit is the number of markets where we have successfully done this, but what we've decided to do is, you know what, this needs to be more of a 16-week process than an 8-week process, and the time line, was just too aggressive. So when assessing that, we decided to extended out ultimately, because we do not want to disrupt the service with our customers.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Charlie. I'll take that. I think when you think about how is this waste with Stericycle roughly 80% is domestic, 20% is international, but if we dig down to the Q1 impact on what we call our environmental solutions business, hazardous waste v
componenttext: Yes. This is Charlie. I'll take that. I think when you think about how is this waste with Stericycle roughly 80% is domestic, 20% is international, but if we dig down to the Q1 impact on what we call our environmental solutions business, hazardous waste volumes that is excluding retail hazard waste and healthcare hazard waste, we're anticipating that to grow at seasonally -- seasonably adjusted rate of about 3%. It actually came in at a negative 4% for the quarter. So roughly speaking about $5.5 million soft on our industrial or hazardous waste volumes. In addition, the mix of the waste that we did actually pick up in our project resulting in a higher-anticipated disposal expense of roughly about $1.5 million, and that has to do with some of the larger projects we did where direct disposal and we have direct disposal as opposed going through our facilities we do incur a higher disposal expense for those accounts, and that's what Dan was referring to when he was talking about mix in the environmental solutions business or hazardous waste business. So certainly, we did see a lower hazardous waste volume. The good news I think though, and Brent talked about in his opening is, where we are focused, that's the healthcare hazardous waste, that's the retail hazardous waste, that's the SQ hazardous waste. We had really strong growth there, but unfortunately, we have a mix issue when it comes to the facilities that we've acquired to support this growth. And that has a very high fixed cost to it and that's what you see hurting us not only on the revenue line but also on the profit line.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I just want to ask about the international business. Just looking at the 10-K, you indicated [indiscernible] obviously you have given more detail, and the margins there relative to U.S. business are like less than 1/3 the amount. I know that got
componenttext: I guess, I just want to ask about the international business. Just looking at the 10-K, you indicated [indiscernible] obviously you have given more detail, and the margins there relative to U.S. business are like less than 1/3 the amount. I know that got hurt last year by [indiscernible] like the U.S. did, but I guess the question is this, is there a credible plan and strategy to narrow that gap in the next 2 to 3 years. And for years, you've talked about, if you can move the mix more to SQ that will take care of it, but it doesn't seem to me that you had much success with that at least overall, because those margins are down several years in a row. And that level of profitability, can you justify continue to do M&A in the international waste business. It just seems like there's no way you're getting good returns if you can't really improve the profitability?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think I'm going to take that 2 sets. I want to walk you through what are some of the pressures that we're facing currently Gary, and then walking out I'll take a stab at your question around long term what I think we can do there. But the pressure
componenttext: Yes. I think I'm going to take that 2 sets. I want to walk you through what are some of the pressures that we're facing currently Gary, and then walking out I'll take a stab at your question around long term what I think we can do there. But the pressure points -- and we feel will be the pressure points for the rest of the year are in 2 distinct lines. It's first of all, that's the view with our patient transport business in the U.K., and obviously, that's been one of our biggest contributors to our international cost pressures because it has rapidly grown over the last several years. We continued to experience an increase in the cost to operate certain contracts. And as a result, that has had a pressure on the overall international margins. Just to educate everybody, most of that work was previously performed by the hospital, and as a result, it was difficult to get historical data prior to bidding. And what we're doing about that, how we're going to try to work on that? Well, the team is working diligently. They are working on these cost overrides. They are working on a contract-by-contract basis, to see if these costs some of them to be passed to our customers and we may look at exiting some of those agreements. So that's certainly is something that's been a headwind in Q1. We think it will be a headwind for the rest of the year. The other issue we're facing is in Latin America, obviously, the economic pressures in Latin America, especially in Brazil, are impacting our business. The economic pressures are mostly in the form of now pricing pressure on government accounts. Just in Brazil alone 58% of our medical waste volumes are tied to government contracts. When you think about Latin America, kind of, a perfect storm for us. We had increased cost, we talked about that last year. Usually, in Latin America, we can pass those costs along, but now we're experiencing some headwinds with respect to government accounts and being able to pass along those prices. So we'll continue to work on that certainly. The team is working on all fronts to improve margins over a longer period of time. Acquisitions, we looked at certain markets, and we'll take a cautious stand on acquisitions. If it's a good tuck-in acquisition that has a good return in our core business, certainly, we'll look to complete that. To add, we're not looking to add any new services though at this point until we can get the base business stabilized in some of the international countries.

I think the formula would say be more like 93.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me take you through that, because I can see how you can get to that number. Remember, as a mandatory convertible there is a range on this. So anything below $136 or let's put it this way, a $136.25 is the maximum dilution of this, and that transl
componenttext: Yes. Let me take you through that, because I can see how you can get to that number. Remember, as a mandatory convertible there is a range on this. So anything below $136 or let's put it this way, a $136.25 is the maximum dilution of this, and that translates into 5.6 million shares. No matter where the price is below that, you will not see a greater converted share count, anything above $136 up until $170, we'll then being to become less diluted, and can actually go to low as 4.5 million shares, and never less diluted than that. So Gary, at the level we're at right now, you will see no greater dilution with that in 91.8 million shares for the year as a good estimate to you.

componenttext: Kind of segueing in the discussion on international and acquisition. You made 2 in Europe, is this just predominantly a Latin American issue, where we wouldn't see acquisitions in that region for a while, but you're still active in I guess, ex U.K., the continent of Europe. headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Scott. The 2 acquisitions in Spain and Romania, I would read anything into that with respect to Europe versus Latin America. There were 2 small tuck-in acquisitions around related medical waste. We look at acquisitions like we always have on a countr
componenttext: Yes. Scott. The 2 acquisitions in Spain and Romania, I would read anything into that with respect to Europe versus Latin America. There were 2 small tuck-in acquisitions around related medical waste. We look at acquisitions like we always have on a country-by-country basis, and if you feel that we need to do more integration work and improve more than before we do deals, then certainly, that will come into our decisions. So I wouldn't look at acquisition LATAM versus Europe. For the quarter, we had 7 acquisitions that were 5 domestic, 2 international. Brent gave you the Spain, Romania. Of the 5 domestic, 1 was regulated medical waste, 4 were secure information destruction. And as I said before, the 2 international were regulated medical waste tuck-in acquisitions in Spain and Romania.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could ask, kind of, a 2-part follow-up. The -- Could you speak to RMS in the quarter. It looked like nothing too dramatic there versus trend. I saw you took down the high-end of the guidance range for the year by $5 million. Just what trend
componenttext: Okay. And if I could ask, kind of, a 2-part follow-up. The -- Could you speak to RMS in the quarter. It looked like nothing too dramatic there versus trend. I saw you took down the high-end of the guidance range for the year by $5 million. Just what trends you're seeing. And then I'll ask my third question now with it. Just with what -- what should we expect to hear on the second quarter call, when you talk about working with the consultants and what you're assessing. What type of outputs are we going to hear? I know you're not going to quantify today, but what are the changes that are coming, just if you could give us a taste?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Scott. On the your recall and returns question. We had solid growth this quarter versus the prior year's quarter, greater than 20% year-over-year. So the 24 compared to 20 in Q1 of last year, so the team had a very good quarter. Obviously, it contin
componenttext: Sure, Scott. On the your recall and returns question. We had solid growth this quarter versus the prior year's quarter, greater than 20% year-over-year. So the 24 compared to 20 in Q1 of last year, so the team had a very good quarter. Obviously, it continues to be an uneven business, difficult for us to even forecast. The only reason to your question of why we brought the top end of the range now, we just -- after 1 quarter, still haven't seen that one blockbuster really large recall. We need a couple of those to get to the high end of the range, so we probably just to shave the top end of the range down a little bit. But the team delivered solid quarter on all the industries, auto, food and beverage, Pharma, med devices, consumer products. The team continues to do a really good job for us there, and we're exited about the opportunities in the quarters ahead. With respect to the consultant -- and we'll talk about on Q2. I mean, obviously, we are looking at how best or organized the North American business. And it's all the business, it is console and expert, it's environmental solutions, and more importantly, how do we take Shred-it and integrate that into all of our businesses and leverage, the infrastructure that we have and really set us up for long-term growth. So I think when the Q2 call comes along we'll talk about what the final outcome was, how did we structure ourselves, how we're going to have a better go-to-market strategy to utilize a better way to cross-sell our businesses. And at the same time, Dan and the finance team will look at, well, how are we measuring success in the new organizational structure internally, and then how externally will we talk to our shareholders and our analysts about the different matrix on our business. So that's our anticipation I will track for. I think we are set up well to talk about that on the July call, and those will be some of the topics we touch upon on our next earnings call.

componenttext: Brian, let me kind of work with you on the synergy numbers. Our previous guidance was $51 million of synergies would be in 2016. So we'll recognize the full $73 million in 2018.

And how we run the business, we'll report based on a true reflection of how we run the business. I think what you have asked for and that we've given historically as businesses like Console from a gross margin standpoint, it's running at about company average with an EBIT in the low teens, which is lower. It's more SG&A-intensive as you could imagine. Our Enviromental solutions got gross margins in about the mid-20s. And again, due to some of the costs that Charlie talked about, that's in the kind of a -- probably, just below double digits. And then Shred-it where we given you some historical on that and it's got EBIT margins in the -- we tend to look at that, though, on an EBITDA, which is 16.5 [ph]. I don't have the EBIT numbers for you, but we've always talk to you historically from an EBITDA perspective. And that's a low mid-20s business that we think over time from an EBITDA perspective. We can improve very well. So I think I don't know if there is anymore that you need on that, but I think that covers most of what we can give, really.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And if I could just maybe try one last one in there. On the regulated medical waste, on the domestic, it's 5% growth organic? headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Keep in mind Brian, the SQ growth and the LQ growth, they're not just medical waste. Over 50% of our SQ growth and 70% of our LQ growth comes from additional services, like consoles, compliant services, Rx waste disposals. So that's not just medical
componenttext: Yes. Keep in mind Brian, the SQ growth and the LQ growth, they're not just medical waste. Over 50% of our SQ growth and 70% of our LQ growth comes from additional services, like consoles, compliant services, Rx waste disposals. So that's not just medical waste. We actually did well on our growth rate, although the SQ growth rates were 6 and 4. If you adjust those growth rates for the impact of the fuel surcharge and the lower hazard waste volume, it would have been more like a 9 and a 6 in the quarter.

componenttext: Yes. I think you're referring to the Shred-it contracts that we signed this quarter. I'll let Brent answer that. And I'll give a little color what we're seeing. I think you also talking about IDNs, and I think we have some color there as well. But Brent can talk to you about what we're seeing early on, on the success in the secure information destruction for some of those LQ systems.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Joel, secure information destruction fits in really well with our LQ or hospital sales force. As we talked about in previous calls, we've got an Account Manager, a sales specialist model that has served extremely well for us to add on additional serv
componenttext: Yes. Joel, secure information destruction fits in really well with our LQ or hospital sales force. As we talked about in previous calls, we've got an Account Manager, a sales specialist model that has served extremely well for us to add on additional services with our customers, whether that would be our sharps management program or pharmaceutical waste program or hazardous waste program, this will feather nicely with that as well as just one more solution we can bring our customers. We had a lot of success adding on new services within health care and integrating network. So we're very bullish and confident. We'll be able to do that very well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Joel, just to give a little color on just larger hospital systems in the U.S., we've always kept an eye on that. Obviously, you got to cover health care and you know there is a consolidation of SQ practices by hospital systems. We are starting to obse
componenttext: And Joel, just to give a little color on just larger hospital systems in the U.S., we've always kept an eye on that. Obviously, you got to cover health care and you know there is a consolidation of SQ practices by hospital systems. We are starting to observe some longer sales cycle at these hospital-affiliated SQ customers. Remember the decision-maker changes a little bit when the hospital acquires a doctor's practice, where we normally deal with an office administrator or office manager. We are now dealing with more personnel from the hospital. So we believe we'll see some pricing pressure on hospital-affiliated SQ account as these contracts come up for renewal. But on the flip side, it does create an opportunity to sell a broader suite of more LQ type services, like pharmaceutical waste disposal and our sharps management system. And again, to give you a little bit of color on that, we estimate that about 16% of our SQ accounts are now somewhat hospital affiliated internally. Stericycle refers to that as a blend customer, and we certainly are keeping an eye on that consolidation and the decision-making process.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Interest was just a touch lower than guidance. And so I think, if you were to look at the year, I think if you just brought it down about $1 million from what we shared last quarter from $106 million to $105 million, I think that's a safe range to be in.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me take you through kind of how they performed from a revenue standpoint. In the quarter, it was about a $185 million, which is a good growth from last quarter. And remember, in that number includes acquisitions, and so I say growth ebbs up -- ab
componenttext: Yes. Let me take you through kind of how they performed from a revenue standpoint. In the quarter, it was about a $185 million, which is a good growth from last quarter. And remember, in that number includes acquisitions, and so I say growth ebbs up -- about up $177 million, which was the acquired quarterly run rate. So pleased with the growth there. As we went through the bridge, and I can share with you that they had pulled some marketing COGS forwards that effected the EBITA or EBITDA margins a little bit, and they got some higher cost. But they are largely performing pretty well I think from a guidance perspective and the rest of the year when you looking at the model. They are running at an EBIT that when we delayed the synergies now I think it will be around 13.5 [ph] because we're moving those synergies out. We are going to get to those up [ph] next year. And then bad accounts also for the change in paper prices. From an EBITDA perspective, just dwn by about same amount. I think it was 200 [ph] we gave you last time, about 184 [ph] now.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, you mentioned Communication Solutions. Could you give us an update there, I think STERICONNECT is fully implemented. When do you anticipate the growth inflection occurring in this service?
componenttext: Okay. And then, you mentioned Communication Solutions. Could you give us an update there, I think STERICONNECT is fully implemented. When do you anticipate the growth inflection occurring in this service?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the new platform is alive at STERICONNECT. Accounts, as we spoke about in the last call, are being transitioned down to the new system and this will continue throughout 2016. This is a very slow process as we said to convert these customers onto t
componenttext: Yes. So the new platform is alive at STERICONNECT. Accounts, as we spoke about in the last call, are being transitioned down to the new system and this will continue throughout 2016. This is a very slow process as we said to convert these customers onto the platform. Health care calls are very customized, and they are customized on an account-by-account basis. So it takes a long time to convert them into the new system. So far it's going well. At the same time, we'll be integrating our live voice infrastructure, that's the STERICONNECT system with our automated product portfolio. So things like automated fund reminders, scheduling, so this will include a cloud-based automated scheduling, and automated appointment reminder service. And this does put us in a very unique position vis-à-vis our competitors in the market. And actually, we had new growth for Q1 for console and it was a slightly ahead of our internal projections for the quarter. So there are off to a good start for the year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, Charlie, when you talked about secure document destruction in the past, and the kind of secular decline in paper overall. You've mentioned that what should be out there, so 10 or 15 years from now, that the company will be prov
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, Charlie, when you talked about secure document destruction in the past, and the kind of secular decline in paper overall. You've mentioned that what should be out there, so 10 or 15 years from now, that the company will be providing additional data security services. Just wondering if you can give us a broad idea of what are the non-paper-based data security services you might be able to provide.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Brent. Some services, additional services that are available now, that we look to expand as they have got hard drive destruction services. So while small that's a new adjacent market that is a very large and profitable market we can go afte
componenttext: David, this is Brent. Some services, additional services that are available now, that we look to expand as they have got hard drive destruction services. So while small that's a new adjacent market that is a very large and profitable market we can go after. And we also hope to develop the same type of compliance programs that we're very successful selling to our SQ customers and to roll that out kind of like a Steri-Safe for business, a business essentials package that we can take to those customers and hopefully sell through the large sales force they have as well as their inside sales team.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin Steinke with Barrington Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin Steinke with Barrington Research.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. I think in the past, you have talked about working to reduce your exposure to project-based industrial waste work and maybe even trying to convert that to more of a recurring model. So is that something you're still thinking abou
componenttext: Good afternoon, everyone. I think in the past, you have talked about working to reduce your exposure to project-based industrial waste work and maybe even trying to convert that to more of a recurring model. So is that something you're still thinking about or any progress on that front.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think this is a good time may be to take out a step back and think about that business. And tell you -- and really -- by taking a step back and telling you why we got into, what the strategy is for the long run. If you think about it 6 years ago, w
componenttext: Yes. I think this is a good time may be to take out a step back and think about that business. And tell you -- and really -- by taking a step back and telling you why we got into, what the strategy is for the long run. If you think about it 6 years ago, we identified 2 significant growth opportunities, retail and healthcare hazardous waste. And why do we think they were good for Stericycle, they were a route-based business, they were SQ type volumes, they came with complex regulatory issues for the generator of the waste or the customer. And we had established relationship in a lot of those markets. So we looked at it, we said that retail hazardous waste businesses was approximately $1 billion, and we still think that today. And the health care SQ has waste market, we identified it's at least $1 billion market. And we quickly become the market leader in these growing segments. But unfortunately, as we spoke about before, we needed to add our operational infrastructure to support our growth. So know we acquired PSC, we acquired other acquisitions to give us that additional facilities in order to meet the demand of the growing business. Unfortunately, these acquisitions came with other hazardous waste streams as industrial waste, other hazardous waste, project work. And obviously, we're frustrated that this base revenue is shrinking and most of this is really outside of our control and it's more market driven. But we also have to look at what can we do better on the cost escalations on that business to make it better. But we needed the infrastructure, it came with some things that we didn't want to focus on, where we are focusing, we're seeing really great growth in the health care haz and retail haz. So we continue to look at that as a focus for the business, and we think overtime that will become a bigger part and that will minimize the impact of this industrial and project work. And I think about why do we still think it's a good business, I mean, that's I'm sure question of should you guys be focused on this or not. And you think about recent enforcement action, recently Comcast announced a $26 million settlement in the state of California. It was related to 2 things. It was related to the improper disposal of hazardous waste and the disposal of secure information. So obviously, enforcement continues to build a awareness, and I think this is a great example of how we have the ability to cross-sell a wide variety of compliance-related services over the customer base that we have or over one customer. So that's really our strategy and continues to be our strategy, is to focus on retail, health care and SQ hazardous waste.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And have you made any changes in the assumptions within your guidance for paper prices. And do you continue to work on negotiating surcharges and contracts, I know that's kind of a longer-term initiative, but any update there and als
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And have you made any changes in the assumptions within your guidance for paper prices. And do you continue to work on negotiating surcharges and contracts, I know that's kind of a longer-term initiative, but any update there and also what you're assuming for the paper pricing?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In Q1, started off with paper pricing increase by about $7.50 a tonne from our last call. So last call it was at 126 as an average price, the end price of the quarter, at the end price of Q1, it's at 133.50, and that's what we assume now on our guid
componenttext:
Sure. In Q1, started off with paper pricing increase by about $7.50 a tonne from our last call. So last call it was at 126 as an average price, the end price of the quarter, at the end price of Q1, it's at 133.50, and that's what we assume now on our guidance going forward. 
Obviously, in Q1, you don't get the entire 133.50, because that grew incrementally over the quarter, but that's what Dan has used in the model right now is 133.50 or approximately $4 million for the rest of the year, because of that slight increase. We are starting to look at contracts, and make changes on agreements, that's now on a contract-by-contract basis, we know that will take us several years to implement. And more to come on that in the coming quarters.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line Hamzah Mazari with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line Hamzah Mazari with Sterne Agee.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had one question, I know you guys are delaying some of the synergies to prevent disruption. But maybe if you could frame the upside potential, upside to synergies for investors longer-term?
componenttext: Just had one question, I know you guys are delaying some of the synergies to prevent disruption. But maybe if you could frame the upside potential, upside to synergies for investors longer-term?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me take that Hamzah. I mean, we think about one of the reasons we're going through the consultant study is that, we think there will be an opportunity down the road, when we're looking at markets that don't have density, where we might be able to
componenttext: Yes. Let me take that Hamzah. I mean, we think about one of the reasons we're going through the consultant study is that, we think there will be an opportunity down the road, when we're looking at markets that don't have density, where we might be able to combine some routes and have our drivers or the Shred-it drivers combined both medical waste and secure information on the same truck. And by definition those rural routes are not dense, they're not dense with secured information, they'll not dense with regulated medical waste. So one of the reasons we are taking our time on the study, one of the reasons we're taking time not to disrupt customers as we know there will be opportunities over the next 2, 3, 4 years to improve both the operations of our Stericycle business, and the Shred-it business. There will be things like we have a tech inside the hospital, collecting sharps containers. Our plan long-term is to make sure, if we have a hospital account to secure information destruction that tech, while they are there, we'll collect all the secured information bins. So will turn an account that used to take a secure information driver a long time because they used to have to park their truck walk throughout the hospital, like all these bins. We will have a waiting for that driver and it'll be just another stopper they're picking up on their route. So certainly, we're still excited about that, I think as we get closer to the Shred-it business, we -- all the things we thought about and how closely it is related to Stericycle and what we do, we think there are things like that longer-term that really set us up to improve the overall margin for Stericycle going forward.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Levine with Imperial Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Levine with Imperial Capital.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to be clear, it sounds like the issues within the industrial haz-waste are identical or very similar to the issues you experienced in 3Q of last year. I was hoping you might be able to confirm that, maybe elaborate and whether there has been any c
componenttext: So just to be clear, it sounds like the issues within the industrial haz-waste are identical or very similar to the issues you experienced in 3Q of last year. I was hoping you might be able to confirm that, maybe elaborate and whether there has been any change whatsoever in either the types of customers that you're seeing slowdown with or are there any differences between what you experienced here in 1Q versus what you experienced in 3Q '15.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the big difference is what we experienced in Q3 was more fuel and energy related. And we know, we saw that we're not going to take up any part of that project or larger volumes in the foreseeable future. I think this is just -- we're seeing a
componenttext: Yes. I think the big difference is what we experienced in Q3 was more fuel and energy related. And we know, we saw that we're not going to take up any part of that project or larger volumes in the foreseeable future. I think this is just -- we're seeing a slowdown in the hazardous waste, excluding the retail and healthcare hazardous. And we already knew there is some seasonality, and we adjusted for that, we just saw an actual decrease above and beyond seasonality. So I think that's the main difference, it's not as dramatic in this quarter. And then there is a mix issue, where on the project works we did do in Q1, we did see a higher disposal expense related to that just based on the type of projects. And to be conservative, we want to make sure that we look to Q1 and then we said if that continues what does that mean for guidance for the rest of the year. Certainly, it's not as big as the drop-off in Q3. And I don't think it's related, because I think one was certainly, related to fuel energy, and this just a softer hazardous waste market in manufacturing industry.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is something that I think about, when I think about the growth in your hazardous waste lines of business. So obviously, the beauty about your medical waste business is that it's basically a closed loop. You can pick up the waste and dispose it at
componenttext: So this is something that I think about, when I think about the growth in your hazardous waste lines of business. So obviously, the beauty about your medical waste business is that it's basically a closed loop. You can pick up the waste and dispose it at your own facilities primarily. So whereas in industrial haz, you're reliant on third-party disposal providers, which increases your cost. Are you able to leverage any of your facilities to dispose of the healthcare or retail hazardous waste, or are you also reliant on third-party disposal in those lines of business as well?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The reason we focused, if we want to focus on the retail and the healthcare hazardous waste, Barbara. There is opportunity, where we bring that material back to our TSDF facilities. We can do, we can break that waste apart, we try not to use incinera
componenttext: Yes. The reason we focused, if we want to focus on the retail and the healthcare hazardous waste, Barbara. There is opportunity, where we bring that material back to our TSDF facilities. We can do, we can break that waste apart, we try not to use incineration or even landfilling that material, sometimes we can remediate that material sometimes it's used as an alternative fuel. So that's why our focus is there, because that part of the business is not as an dependent on disposal as is projects and larger industrial waste. And overtime, we'd like to grow that. So that the industrial and hazardous waste part of the business is just a baseline business for us and it's a small part of the larger business. And in our RX waste, all of the nonhazardous pharmaceutical waste, we actually can utilizing our medical waste facilities for that material. So we do have a closed loop on some of that non-haz pharmaceutical waste, when we sell that product to a hospital or to a doctor's office, even some of the mail backs that we have and the take back program will actually utilize from our own, our goal is to utilize some of our own medical waste facility. So we certainly -- that's something we considered we got into this business. When we looked at, why we want to grow those particular segments.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, great. That's good to hear. So going forward we could reasonably expect that, there will be opportunities still, let's call, display some of that industrial waste that's going through your systems at present. Maybe you'll be able to allow us some o
componenttext: Great, great. That's good to hear. So going forward we could reasonably expect that, there will be opportunities still, let's call, display some of that industrial waste that's going through your systems at present. Maybe you'll be able to allow us some of those contracts to , I don't know, roll off or something like that, but the goal would be to sort of use that capacity with the -- that other type of waste, because it seems to me that your advantages are just stronger there.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Totally right. I think Barbara you followed Stericycle for a long  time, so if you go back to the early day of Stericycle, when we were mostly in LQ business and not making much profit. We had obviously, 65% to 75% of our business was the LQ medical waste
componenttext: Totally right. I think Barbara you followed Stericycle for a long  time, so if you go back to the early day of Stericycle, when we were mostly in LQ business and not making much profit. We had obviously, 65% to 75% of our business was the LQ medical waste. And we focused for years on the SQ side of the business. We didn't get out of the LQ business, because you need that as a baseline for your facilities, but what did we do fast forward 15 years, 60% to 65% of our business now as SQ, and LQ, which still has a low profit to it, is a smaller part of the overall business. So this is going to take time, we realize that. But I think you've seen it before, from Stericycle we're focusing on those smaller markets to have better profitability where we can control on our destiny, we're not going to walk away from this hazardous waste in the larger industrial waste market, but we do want to make it a smaller part of that business overtime.
