headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example,
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. 
This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. Our actual results could differ significantly from the results described in the forward-looking statements. 
Factors that could cause such differences include: changes in governmental regulation of the collection, transportation, treatment and disposal of regular waste or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing regulated waste collection and treatment or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; our obligation to service our substantial indebtedness and to comply with the covenants and restrictions contained in our private placement notes, term loan credit facility and revolving credit facility; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; the competition and demand for services in the regulated waste and secure information destruction industries; political, economic and currency risks related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other indefinite live [ph] intangibles; variability in the demand for services we provide on a project or nonrecurring basis; exposure to environmental liabilities; fluctuations in the price we receive for the sale of paper; disruptions in or attacks on our information technology systems; compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements; as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recent filed annual report on Form 10-K. As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance and investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. We make no commitment to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn it over to Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sean. Thank you for joining us on today's call. In the second quarter, despite softness in anticipated revenues, the team was able to provide strong sequential increases of profitability which allowed us to deliver a solid quarter. We are pleased
componenttext:
Thanks, Sean. Thank you for joining us on today's call. In the second quarter, despite softness in anticipated revenues, the team was able to provide strong sequential increases of profitability which allowed us to deliver a solid quarter. We are pleased with the results given the time and effort that our team members invested in both running our business and implementing our recently announced organizational redesign. 
Joining me on today's call will be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and the Brent Arnold, COO. I'll now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Charlie. Before I give the numbers, I'd like to highlight some of the changes that will enhance our reporting and disclosure to our internal and our external stakeholders. Our Q2 press release included a global revenue table and additional non-
componenttext:
Thank you, Charlie. Before I give the numbers, I'd like to highlight some of the changes that will enhance our reporting and disclosure to our internal and our external stakeholders. Our Q2 press release included a global revenue table and additional non-GAAP disclosures. In our second quarter 10-Q, we will have changes to our operating segment. Our new operating segments are as follows. We will have a direct -- domestic regulated waste in Compliance Solution segment. This includes our compliance and logistics related services. We will have a domestic Communication and Related Services segment. This includes our Communication Solutions and Recall businesses. International Regulated Waste and Compliance Solutions is another segment and there's no change to this operating segment. 
Now for the numbers. The results for the second quarter are as follows.  Global revenues were $891.6 million, up 24.6% from $715.7 million in Q2 2015. In internal growth, excluding the impact of foreign exchange, acquisitions and manufacturing and industrial services was up 3.3%. Domestic revenues were $651.1 million. Excluding the impact of acquisitions and manufacturing and industrials revenues, internal growth was 2.3%. 
For consistency of your models, we will continue to report the following for the remainder of the year: Domestic Regulated Waste and Compliant Service revenues was $486.1 million, up 1%. SQ revenue was up 2%. LQ was up 1%. Growth rates were impacted by lower fuel surcharges and lower manufacturing and industrial waste revenues. Recalls and returns revenues was $20.9 million. International revenues were $234.5 million excluding the impact of foreign exchange, acquisitions and manufacturing and industrial services, internal growth was 5.8%. 
Acquisitions contributed $185.9 million to growth in the quarter. Gross profit was $381.6 million or 42.8% of revenues. SG&A expense excluding amortization was $189.5 million or 21.3% of revenues. Net interest expense was $24.4 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $37.3 million or $0.43 per share on an as-reported basis and $1.18 when adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjustments. 
Now for the balance sheet. Our covenant debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 3.45 at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $506 million. In the quarter, we repurchased 32,962 shares of common stock on the open market in the amount of $3.1 million. And we repurchased 65,000 shares of mandatory convertible shares on the open market in the amount of $5 million. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 3.3 million shares. Our CapEx was $32.9 million or 3.7% of revenues. Our DSO was 64 days. Year-to-date, as reported -- year-to-date cash from operations was $245.4 million. And when adjusted for recall reimbursement and other items, cash from operations was $282.9 million. 
Today, we filed a Form 8-K reporting our decision to amend Stericycle's timing of quarterly accruals from legal settlements in 2015. The amendments will have no effect on our 2015 year-end financial results. 
I will now turn it over to Brent

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisition. In the quarter, we closed 10 acquisitions, 6 domestic and 4 international. The international acquisitions were 1 in Spain, 1 in Romania, 1 in Sou
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Worldwide, we continue to use our strong free cash flow to drive our growth through acquisition. In the quarter, we closed 10 acquisitions, 6 domestic and 4 international. The international acquisitions were 1 in Spain, 1 in Romania, 1 in South Korea and 1 in the U.K. Revenues from the 10 acquisitions were approximately $1.5 million in the quarter and annualized for approximately $10.6 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust, with well over $100 million in annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business. 
In the quarter, we saw strong performance from the Secure Information Destruction business. The sales team set a record for new sales and closed several major national accounts. In addition, we continue to make progress toward our synergy plan and we remain on track with previous guidance. Overall, we are pleased with the momentum we are building in this new service line. 
As you all well aware, over the last 6 months, we've been working with a consulting firm to optimize our organizational structure in the U.S. and Canada. In Q2, we began implementing the new structure. First, our sales organization was realigned to focus on growing our healthcare customer base, expanding national account relationships, converting the [indiscernible] Secured Information Destruction market and expanding our multiple services across new and existing customers. 
Next, we established 1 field operations management organization for our Regulated Waste, Compliant Services and Secured Information Destruction businesses. By having these operations aligned under one leadership team, we will drive best practices across the organization and provide best-in-class service to our customers. This will also enable us to drive long-term efficiencies and margin improvement. 
In addition, we have combined our Recall and Communication Solutions businesses under one operating segment. This is the large, since a large portion of our Recall business is call center related, we have consolidated the operations, sales and marketing and client service functions under one leadership team. 
Finally, we are developing a long-term plan to expand our shared services model across all of our businesses. Some of these shared services include IT, financial support, human resources and continuous improvement. When fully implemented, this plan will enable us to better leverage best practices and SG&A. 
We are excited about this new organizational structure. We believe this will allow us to drive team member engagement, better serve our customers and provide long-term sustainable growth. 
In closing, we would like to thank all of those team members who contributed their time, effort and input to this important organizational redesign. 
I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration and acquisition-related
componenttext:
Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration and acquisition-related expenses and other adjusted items. Our guidance is adjusted for the impact of foreign exchange and the following factors. Currently, the overall hazardous waste market remains challenging. This has led to increased competition for available volume. These market conditions have further reduced the revenue and profitability of our manufacturing and industrial waste business. 
We're also seeing increased pricing pressure on our SQ customer base. This is a result of the consolidation of physician practices by hospitals and the overall healthcare cost pressures resulting from managed care. To counter the SQ pricing pressure, we'll be making incremental SG&A investments to drive new customer growth. 
With respect to our international business, we have a negotiated plan to aid to 2 patient transport contracts in the U.K. later this year. We will still incur costs while we transition out of these contracts. 
As a reminder, our 2016 EPS guidance is adjusted for amortization expense. For 2016, we believe the analyst EPS estimates will be in the range of $4.68 to $4.75. We believe analyst revenue estimates for 2016 will be in the range of $3.56 billion to $3.6 billion, depending on assumptions for growth and the impact of foreign exchange rates. We anticipate 2016 internal growth rates to be: SQ, 3% to 6%, LQ, 2% to 4%; international, 3% to 5%; and recall and returns revenue between $90 million and $100 million. We believe analysts will have estimates for free cash flow in 2016 between $435 million to $450 million. 2016 CapEx is anticipated to be between $125 million to $135 million. We expect the 2016 full year as-reported tax rate to be approximately 35.5%. 
We continue to be the market leader in multiple services and geographies with a strong team and an unmatched infrastructure. We recognize the challenges that our business faces and we continue to take steps to address these challenges. We remain confident in the long-term outlook of our business. 
With that in mind, Stericycle will be hosting its first Investor Day and webcast on the morning of Thursday, November 10, to share perspectives on Stericycle's strategies, capabilities and plans to drive long-term shareholder value. More details are posted on the Events page of our Investor Relations website. We encourage investors, analysts and the public to join the live webcast or watch the meeting replay. 
Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. Sarah, you can open the Q&A queue.

componenttext: Sure, Ryan. As you know, our prior guidance was $4.90 to $5.05. Acquisitions will contribute about $0.005 to $0.01 of EPS. Increased paper prices will add anywhere from $0.025 to $0.03 to EPS. Lower guidance on our recalls for the year will be unfavorable of about $0.02 to $0.04. FX, largely due to the Brexit will be a headwind of about $0.02. International, mostly due to the exit of the patient transportation contracts, will be anywhere from $0.02 to $0.04 unfavorable. M&A, manufacturing and industrial, lower revenues, customer mix and an Argentinian facility closure or issue will be anywhere from $0.09 to $0.11 for the rest of the year and our Regulated Waste and Compliant Services will be about $0.10 to $0.13. That will bring you to $4.68 to $4.75 for the year. I think it would be best for your models in Q3 to have a range of about $1.17 to $1.21.

componenttext: Okay, great. Thanks for all the color. What's the corporate goal there?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ryan, this is a good question. Overall, when we implemented the savings, we saw about a $5 million savings associated with the changes that we've made in the second quarter. That was already in our previous guidance. And we're also looking to reinves
componenttext: Yes, Ryan, this is a good question. Overall, when we implemented the savings, we saw about a $5 million savings associated with the changes that we've made in the second quarter. That was already in our previous guidance. And we're also looking to reinvest some of that, as you've heard, with some of the additional resources we're going to put into the back half. We do think though that that organizational redesign sets us up to continue to achieve the $31 million that we're on track to achieve in 2016 as well as the follow-on $20 [ph] million in the next year. So again, we do think that the re-org is going to set us up for long-term growth and the ability to drive the necessary synergies and cost improvements in the operation.

componenttext: Yes, Ryan, this is Charlie, just to add a little bit to that, there was very little -- On your question around, was there any savings in Q2 related to the study and the implementation, I would say that very little was in Q2, the $5 million that Brent alluded to was already in our guidance, previous guidance and we're going to invest now in the healthcare compliance business. And at the end of the day, the McKenzie study is going to help us, hopefully, exceed the $20 million to $30 million in the Stericycle Shred-it synergies that we discussed when we did the Shred-it deal.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Sean, this is Brent. I'll go ahead and take that one. Yes, this is not a new trend, right? We've been tracking this for quite some time. Really, managed care is having an impact in two areas with us. And as we've been following closely, at first, we
componenttext: Hey, Sean, this is Brent. I'll go ahead and take that one. Yes, this is not a new trend, right? We've been tracking this for quite some time. Really, managed care is having an impact in two areas with us. And as we've been following closely, at first, we did not anticipate or see it having a major impact initially. But the challenge is that now that these doctors practices that have been acquired by hospitals are starting to get integrated into their networks, we are starting to see continued pressures. Those contracts come up and they put those up for a large RFPs, we're starting to see increased pricing pressure associated with that. There's no having a material impact on our business. Secondly, we are seeing, while to a lesser extent, were also seeing the same trend now in our SQ business. As we go to renew those contracts we're also seeing pricing pressure and the need to do discounts to get new renewals.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: It's 2 factors, Sean. It's the price that Brent has spoke about, but remember we're also taking down, we talked about the softness in the M&I business. So it's an impact of both the M&I and the future M&I for the rest of the year and the items that Brent has discussed.

componenttext: Yes, the regulated waste will include -- and compliant services includes our regulated waste, it includes the additional services that we have been selling to our healthcare community, it also includes our hazardous waste. We did break out for you the M&I that we thought that was important for the shareholders. Is has gotten a lot of focus. Seems to be the one that's experiencing the headwinds and the volatility in the project work and the industrials. Our secure information destruction, obviously with the new acquisition, we look at that very closely. We thought it would be important also for our analysts and shareholders to be able to see the growth of that business and how it's contributing to the growth, overall growth of Stericycle. And then, communication solutions and recall coming together, it's really been a natural, over the last year or so, as we've seen more and more recall that we're doing, really call center type work and we've been able to leverage our call center agents and we thought it was really important to make that one group.

I guess, Charlie, at what point do you decide that some of these businesses you ventured into are just not up to the historical Stericycle quality around profitability potential or stability of revenue and look to maybe consider other exits than those British contracts? Is that on the table? Have you thought about it before considering these things? Or do you feel like in a reasonable timeline, you can start to fix some of the damaged businesses, not just grow your way out of it by growing [indiscernible]

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Gary. Obviously, we continue. We've always looked at the businesses and whether or not they fit the long-term strategy, I mean, certainly, in this quarter, you saw that we started taking steps, at least in the patient transport business in the U.K. al
componenttext: No, Gary. Obviously, we continue. We've always looked at the businesses and whether or not they fit the long-term strategy, I mean, certainly, in this quarter, you saw that we started taking steps, at least in the patient transport business in the U.K. although we're still in that business, we're able to exit 2 contracts. We'll continue to look at that on a contract-by-contract basis and then we'll review whether or not that business fits in the long-term strategy. And I think really, the focus has been on the manufacturer and industrial business and whether or not we would stay in that business, I want to maybe take a step back before I answer that one. I mean, we got into that business. We needed to build the infrastructures we said before to support our core strategy around retail, healthcare, SQ, hazardous waste. And those services continue to grow and they do fit the Stericycle model. They are predictable and stable. We made the PSC acquisition and a few of our acquisitions overseas, we did the hazardous waste dynamic at that time were good. They were growing M&I, it was strong. However, since the market divisions obviously have deteriorated, we are currently evaluating all options there. And that's an option around do we need the infrastructure we currently have to support the predictable and stable part of that business? Or are there parts of that business that don't belong in the portfolio and we will look at that over the next 2 quarters. Certainly, we will look at that.

componenttext: [indiscernible] Like you may have seen the be been at the beginning of the year, look at things from an EBITA perspective. It's appropriate for us to look at SG&A as an amortization. And at the same time, reduce the period over which we amortize that. That's why you saw a onetime spike in amortization. But even prior to that, we began looking at the business aspect of that. And I think you've seen a little bit of improvement in the SG&A number and I think you should show what you're looking at is pretty stable. headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess can we talk international? The trend is decelerating in the second half and year-over-year comps. You've addressed it kind of broadly. Could you address kind of international? And then a little bit more color on patient transportation? And then th
componenttext: I guess can we talk international? The trend is decelerating in the second half and year-over-year comps. You've addressed it kind of broadly. Could you address kind of international? And then a little bit more color on patient transportation? And then the third part of this question would be in Latin America, you said something in Argentina I missed. And then kind of an update on how you're doing with your Latin American government related customers and what's occurring with them, that was a headwind noted in the last call --

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jump in if I missed anything, you had a couple of part of that question. International growth rates for the quarter were approximately 6% and that was driven higher in the quarter by a good communication solution and recall activity overseas. We did bring
componenttext: Jump in if I missed anything, you had a couple of part of that question. International growth rates for the quarter were approximately 6% and that was driven higher in the quarter by a good communication solution and recall activity overseas. We did bring down a full-year guidance there and that is directly related to the exit of the patient transport contracts in the second half of the year. A little more color on the patient transport business and what that meant with respect to the quarter or guidance is we have negotiated an exit on 2 contracts later this year. We are going to still incur costs though while we transition out of these contracts and if you think about what is the headwind for that, particular, Dan, I think addressed earlier on the bridge there about $0.02 to $0.04 to EPS for the rest of the year. As far as you had a question about Argentina. We do have a facility that's -- would shutdown -- will be shut down for most of the rest of the year, had to do with heavy rains in the Buenos Aires area earlier on, that facility shutdown I think around April. So it did have some impact a little bit for us in Q2. And your last question related to government contracts in Brazil. And we talked about that as we're having issues taking some of the increases we have on wages and passing that. So there's nothing new there that hasn't worked and we didn't think it was going to get better that's why we guided down a little bit on that on the last call. But there's really no update there. It's still a tough situation with respect to Latin America. We continue to try to work the best we can contract by contract and getting increases passed through. I believe I caught all of your questions.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You did. Great. You covered them all. A follow-up on the patient transportation in the U.K. Exiting 2 contracts, what is left and what's I assume everything will be exited ultimately? What's the timeframe?
componenttext: You did. Great. You covered them all. A follow-up on the patient transportation in the U.K. Exiting 2 contracts, what is left and what's I assume everything will be exited ultimately? What's the timeframe?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have not necessarily made a decision on the ultimate exit of that business. Yes, we did exit 2 agreements. We're left with about $65 million to $75 million in annualized revenue after the exit. That number though has also come down with the exchange ra
componenttext: We have not necessarily made a decision on the ultimate exit of that business. Yes, we did exit 2 agreements. We're left with about $65 million to $75 million in annualized revenue after the exit. That number though has also come down with the exchange rate headwind in the U.K. Remember, the last call, I talked about that business being $85 million to $95 million. So about half of the reduction that I just spoke to came from foreign exchange. The other half came from the exit of those contracts. There are about 30 contracts in total. Again, we're looking at this on a contract by contract basis. Certainly, we're looking at some contracts that are unprofitable that we're looking to exit and then we'll make a decision on the long-term strategic fit of that business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay, thanks. And just one final quick follow-up. Is the restructure over now for the redesign or whatever you guys, the McKinsey study and the diagnostics, what does -- what should we anticipate looking ahead? I assume you're still going to guide the out year on the third quarter call. I'm just kind of curious what additional changes will we see in reporting going forward and just operational fundamental is all the consultants gone and the new processes in place? Thanks.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the major changes, we tried to bucket those together. Obviously from an organizational perspective, you don't want to have change after change happening. So we try to bucket as many of those together. But at Stericycle, one of our core values is
componenttext: As far as the major changes, we tried to bucket those together. Obviously from an organizational perspective, you don't want to have change after change happening. So we try to bucket as many of those together. But at Stericycle, one of our core values is continuous improvement. So we'll always be looking to make the necessary changes to continue to improve and drive our business. With regard to upcoming changes that you'll start to see, I referenced the consolidation or virtualization of our inside sales team. That's something we are working on. We are currently working on also using all the expertise we have in customer service to bring all that together, use our technology around call quality, call routing, intelligent work distribution, all of those things. So these are things that we're just a few years ahead in our journey. That Shred-it was. I think we have a lot of opportunities to continue to make margin improvements as we take the expertise we have and having over the logistics base of business that used to be decentralized and really pulling all of this and using that same expertise and best practices and taking that to Shred-it. The final thing I'll add is we are continuing a couple of engagements with the consultants, some around sourcing and some around customer data and information and we're excited about both of those projects.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Manthey from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at the declines in the SQ, LQ, international growth rates, is that all volume and fuel surcharges? Or is there a component of price declines also?
componenttext: When you look at the declines in the SQ, LQ, international growth rates, is that all volume and fuel surcharges? Or is there a component of price declines also?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'll take that, David. So again, I think when you're looking at growth rates, you should look at the full year. Because I think that takes out the comparable issues. So I'll answer it with that view in mind. So we obviously had a big influx of rev
componenttext: Yes, so I'll take that, David. So again, I think when you're looking at growth rates, you should look at the full year. Because I think that takes out the comparable issues. So I'll answer it with that view in mind. So we obviously had a big influx of revenue in Q2 of last year. So the main contributors are lower M&I and lower fuel surcharges. Certainly, we've seen the SQ pricing start to build now. So there's a component of that in Q2. When you adjust though for all of those impacts, the impacts around M&I and lower fuel surcharges, we would have been at a comparative of about 6 SQ and 4 LQ. And then I think it makes the question around well, what does that mean going forward into 2017? So when we -- obviously, we're going to provide our exact guidance on 2017 on the October call. However, some of the headwinds we've discussed here today around M&I and around our regulated compliance solutions business will continue into next year. So we anticipate that 2017 growth rates will be lower than the historical averages.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you talked about M&I and potentially thinking about getting out of that business or somehow stripping out those revenues and not being in the business anymore. If that were to happen though, wouldn't it stand to reason that what was left of
componenttext: Okay. And then you talked about M&I and potentially thinking about getting out of that business or somehow stripping out those revenues and not being in the business anymore. If that were to happen though, wouldn't it stand to reason that what was left of PSC would be underutilized, you might have to close facility, you should further to get there? I'm just trying to understand how that would happen, because at the conference back in June, Dan had talked about the volume and sort of indicated that you would take those volumes day of the week because they were helping you maximize the utilization of your facilities?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, so good question. First of all, no assumptions right now. We have not made any decisions to sell any part of our hazardous waste business. That includes obviously our retail, healthcare and SQ or our M&I business, our manufacturing and industr
componenttext: Yes, David, so good question. First of all, no assumptions right now. We have not made any decisions to sell any part of our hazardous waste business. That includes obviously our retail, healthcare and SQ or our M&I business, our manufacturing and industrial. One of the reasons to call that on the table is that obviously has a lot of unpredictability to it. So from an analyst and shareholder perspective, we wanted to call that out. If we made a decision to sell or to move away from a business, we'll certainly look at what's left from operational infrastructure and make the proper adjustments to make sure that we can run a very predictable, stable and profitable business. We wouldn't just leave and then try to figure out what the infrastructure will look like afterwards. That would all be part of the overall decision.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then somewhat related, as it relates to these, the structures of these businesses, you've talked about the difficulty in converting on-site shredding customers to off-site and if there is a handful of holdout customers that can hold up the entir
componenttext: Okay. And then somewhat related, as it relates to these, the structures of these businesses, you've talked about the difficulty in converting on-site shredding customers to off-site and if there is a handful of holdout customers that can hold up the entire process of gaining synergies given the structure of your trucks and things like that. Is it wrong to think that that would extend beyond the initial integration for example, if you acquire a document destruction target a year from now, 2 years from now, won't you have the same difficulty integrating that route into an existing route if there's a number of customers that want their paper to be shredded on-site?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, maybe I didn't communicate this as well on the past, we will always have on-site customers and we're going to offer both services going forward. So for those customers who want their documents destroyed on site, we'll always have those resourc
componenttext: Yes, David, maybe I didn't communicate this as well on the past, we will always have on-site customers and we're going to offer both services going forward. So for those customers who want their documents destroyed on site, we'll always have those resources and assets. Our focus has been at just moving a percentage of those to where more of them are off site versus on site. So yes, we'll always be going to this process ask letting customers know, the 2 different ways that we can handle their documents and then helping guide them to the most appropriate one that meet their need. This will be an ongoing process. Clearly, it's more efficient for us to do it off-site that if they wanted on site, we'll continue to do that as well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a more color on that, David, remember, office business have both on-site and off-site, they had about 60% of their customers offsite but they offered on-site I think, 40%. All we're seeing now is the combined entity during the integration period will
componenttext: Just a more color on that, David, remember, office business have both on-site and off-site, they had about 60% of their customers offsite but they offered on-site I think, 40%. All we're seeing now is the combined entity during the integration period will get the combined entity to 60% off site and the remainder on site. But I think it's a key point, I've seen some articles out there about Stericycle getting out of the on-site, but that is not accurate. That is not part of the plan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then final question. Are the consultants still there or are they gone?
componenttext: Okay. And then final question. Are the consultants still there or are they gone?

componenttext: No, as I mentioned earlier consultants now have moved onto a sourcing project as well as a data projects. So we are definitely moved on two other smaller projects. But ones are very interested in.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Barbara Noverini from MorningStar.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Barbara Noverini from MorningStar.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's interesting to see organic revenue decline for the quarter in the communications segment and I assume much of that is related to the recall business. But given that recall is such a lumpy business, including it in this segment sort of masks the un
componenttext: So it's interesting to see organic revenue decline for the quarter in the communications segment and I assume much of that is related to the recall business. But given that recall is such a lumpy business, including it in this segment sort of masks the underlying growth of com-sol which you talked about in the past is a nice growth platform for you. So I understand that that's a pretty steady recurring revenue stream kind of business. So if you were to exclude recall, how does that com-sol business performed and what could we expect for that going forward?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a few things I'll point out in that I think you brought some good questions that, Barb. First of all, when we look at combining the business, the first thing we looked at was that 60% of recalls revenues were call center related. As you know, reca
componenttext: There's a few things I'll point out in that I think you brought some good questions that, Barb. First of all, when we look at combining the business, the first thing we looked at was that 60% of recalls revenues were call center related. As you know, recalls consisted of retrieval, disposal, notification and call center. But the lion's share of the work there was call center. So there was a lot of synergies and we have been working for more than a year trying to figure out how do we leverage our Communication Solutions team to take those recall works which is lumpy in nature. So that was one of the thought process of bringing the two together. Secondly, on your question around well, what is the growth rate that we exclude some things. And recall certainly, was down this quarter, it was $20.9 million. It was down to 26% year-over-year. So let's remove the noise there on the number. I think the team, the com-sol team and the recall team did a good job of winning all our call-center contracts which we utilized to Communication Solutions team for us. So they assist in vehicle buybacks and customer care related work. So when you strip out the noise and you exclude the U.S. recall, the Europe recalls and acquisitions, year-to-date growth in com-sol was actually about 11%. I caution you a little bit about moving forward there, we have some year-over-year comps in Q3. But we are -- we think about it, how did we get that work in com-sol in the auto space, it started with an acquisition that we made of a company that had a relationship with all our manufacturers. They were able to pass along where we've got some smaller recall events at auto. But really then, we're able to work with Communication Solutions and we're now doing some large work for auto manufacturers, like I said, in the area of vehicle buybacks and customer care work. So if you think about it, it's worked very well. We took an acquisition, we extended the services they can offer and it is paying off nicely for that part of the business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Isaac Ro from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Isaac Ro from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Joel in for Isaac. So can you guys give any color in terms of what you're seeing in the pricing with the document destruction side of the business and maybe any insights on your plans to integrate paper pricing surcharges into any of the new
componenttext: It's actually Joel in for Isaac. So can you guys give any color in terms of what you're seeing in the pricing with the document destruction side of the business and maybe any insights on your plans to integrate paper pricing surcharges into any of the newer contracts that you've been signing?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Joe, this is Brent. With regard to pricing, with regard to market pricing, again, haven't noticed any major changes or differences in the trends we guided in the business. One thing that we're really excited about though is the size of the unbid mark
componenttext: Hey, Joe, this is Brent. With regard to pricing, with regard to market pricing, again, haven't noticed any major changes or differences in the trends we guided in the business. One thing that we're really excited about though is the size of the unbid market and the ability for our team to go out there and convert it and convince those customers that it is better to outsource that service as opposed to be noncompliant or to shred it themselves. So obviously, when we go out and convert that business, we're able to kind of, assess the value with the customer and we do really well there. With regard to the paper pricing, we're happy to come back. And so hopefully, we'll continue to see it come back tomorrow, that $150 million historical level. But so far, it's on the right trend.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, right now, I mean, it's about $146 million. So it's not that far off of that 10-year, we talked about that 5 to 10 year average of $152 million. So we're pleased it has come back. Dan talked about created a little bit of a tailwind for us in that bus
componenttext: Yes, right now, I mean, it's about $146 million. So it's not that far off of that 10-year, we talked about that 5 to 10 year average of $152 million. So we're pleased it has come back. Dan talked about created a little bit of a tailwind for us in that business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think you are also asking about getting language into the contract and as we mentioned, that will be, in the contract cycle about 4 years, will be migrating. So That will take time to implement over the whole contract.
componenttext: And I think you are also asking about getting language into the contract and as we mentioned, that will be, in the contract cycle about 4 years, will be migrating. So That will take time to implement over the whole contract.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the good news is the team [indiscernible] to get the new language and the new agreement that we're signing so are moving forward on that front.
componenttext: And the good news is the team [indiscernible] to get the new language and the new agreement that we're signing so are moving forward on that front.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Maybe just to clarify, on the SG&A investments, you guys discussed in the context of offsetting some of the pricing pressure in SQ. Was that a back half of the 2016 phenomenon or was that something that you guys implementing over the longer term?
componenttext: Great. Maybe just to clarify, on the SG&A investments, you guys discussed in the context of offsetting some of the pricing pressure in SQ. Was that a back half of the 2016 phenomenon or was that something that you guys implementing over the longer term?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. That's going to be over the -- the initial investments will be in the back half of about $4 million to $5 million in the back half of '16 and where we going to put that is incremental sales and marketing. And we're really focused that on driving
componenttext: Correct. That's going to be over the -- the initial investments will be in the back half of about $4 million to $5 million in the back half of '16 and where we going to put that is incremental sales and marketing. And we're really focused that on driving additional services and the SQs that had been acquired by hospitals. The reality is that they still need the services that we have, whether that be pharmaceutical waste or our compliance training services. So our Sharps Management Service. We just feel like we need additional resources to help get out there and push that forward and then the second part will be a new part for us which is really exciting. As you think about it, most of our sales process in the past has been upselling existing customers to additional compliance services. We have a large market opportunity with regard to incremental sites in the SQ market. And so we're excited by proactively approaching and gaining those site with the sales investment.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Steinke with Barrington Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Steinke with Barrington Research.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you provide the bridge from prior revenue guidance to the updated revenue guidance as you did for EPS? And also, what's the full year impact of currency incorporated into guidance now?
componenttext: Could you provide the bridge from prior revenue guidance to the updated revenue guidance as you did for EPS? And also, what's the full year impact of currency incorporated into guidance now?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll be happy to do that. So revenue, as you know, before the prior guidance was $3.6 billion to $3.66 billion. The Q2 lower revenues will create unfavorable, about $10 million for the guidance going forward. The lower export [ph] guidance will be $5
componenttext: Yes, I'll be happy to do that. So revenue, as you know, before the prior guidance was $3.6 billion to $3.66 billion. The Q2 lower revenues will create unfavorable, about $10 million for the guidance going forward. The lower export [ph] guidance will be $5 million to $15 million. The environmental solutions will be about $10 million in the back half of the year. SQ growth that we've talked about is anywhere from $10 million to $15 million in the back half of the year. Exiting that patient, those 2 patient transportation contracts will be between $7 million and $12 million on the back half. And then the acquisitions that we did will contribute about $5 million. Foreign exchange, and I think I'm going to answer both of your questions with this one. The Brexit will create about $10 million in foreign exchange headwinds, most of it had to do with the Brexit. And then the improvement in paper prices is about $5 million. If you look at that, bringing you to about $3.56 billion to $3.60 billion in revenue for the year guidance.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, got it. Thank you very much. And then I'm not sure if you touched on this earlier. But you mentioned that last quarter that you had some good success cross selling document destruction services to some health care customers and you also cited s
componenttext: All right, got it. Thank you very much. And then I'm not sure if you touched on this earlier. But you mentioned that last quarter that you had some good success cross selling document destruction services to some health care customers and you also cited some new wins this quarter. So where do we stand on the cross-selling efforts of information destruction to healthcare? And are you now setting up the team to sell those services more aggressively to the legacy Stericycle customer base?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kevin, Charlie commented a little bit on those earlier. I'll just reiterate, the sales pilots are going well. We did have to keep them relatively smaller in scale just with the magnitude of things that we had going on with the organizational redesign
componenttext: Yes, Kevin, Charlie commented a little bit on those earlier. I'll just reiterate, the sales pilots are going well. We did have to keep them relatively smaller in scale just with the magnitude of things that we had going on with the organizational redesign. But they have contributed to the success in new revenue, or new sales that Shred-it had in Q2. And overall, we are very pleased with the progress Shred-it's organic growth is making. it's anywhere from 3% to 5%, which is high, [indiscernible] higher than historical averages. We look to accelerate that, the investments with regard to cross selling. I think that's the way the new sales organization setup to sell all services. It's going to be a great plus there. So again, we're still in the process of learning lessons and continuing the pilot, the ones that work best, we will fund and we will accelerate those in the back half of the year and into next year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just add a little color, I'll give you an example, Kevin, on the LQ. One part of the redesign, on the organizational redesign is that our hospital group which is led by -- that's one of the segments that Brent talked about, they will have embedded special
componenttext: Just add a little color, I'll give you an example, Kevin, on the LQ. One part of the redesign, on the organizational redesign is that our hospital group which is led by -- that's one of the segments that Brent talked about, they will have embedded specialists that can sell secure information destruction to our customers. It's a similar model that we follow for Sharps Management, for Rx Waste, that team has always delivered solid results. When we use the major account executives relationships with hospitals to bring in those specialists to get that cross-selling activity signed and brought into the company. So we're excited about that. That was part of the focus. Certainly, as we get through the redesign and now we're gearing up, that team to be within the hospital sales team for Stericycle.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Larry Keusch from Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Larry Keusch from Raymond James.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to start on the patient transport and the $65 million to $75 million in revenue that you mentioned after you exit the two contracts. How do we think about sort of the economics of that remaining revenue? So in other words, is there a portion of t
componenttext: I wanted to start on the patient transport and the $65 million to $75 million in revenue that you mentioned after you exit the two contracts. How do we think about sort of the economics of that remaining revenue? So in other words, is there a portion of that business that makes sense? Or should we really be thinking about you looking to exit these contracts over time because again, just the overall economics don't make sense and are not going to change?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will tell you that about 4 years ago is when we were in -- we started to get in the patient transport business in the U.K., it came with a med waste acquisition. And for a couple of years in some of the smaller contracts that we were winning in the nort
componenttext: I will tell you that about 4 years ago is when we were in -- we started to get in the patient transport business in the U.K., it came with a med waste acquisition. And for a couple of years in some of the smaller contracts that we were winning in the north of England and in other parts of the U.K., they were profitable. We are profitable, it were very similar to our med waste business. And as we discussed we went into this business thinking that the NHS was going to outsource this in the large tranches of contract. We were correct on that although we have difficulty setting up and delivering on a profitable bases in that marketplace. So you're right. As we start to look at the unprofitable contracts, there are some contracts, legacy contracts and contracts -- smaller contracts that we've won over the last several years that are profitable. And that's why we'll take a step back at that point to figure out what do we do next? Do we sell that business? Do we stay in that business? We really need to look at it -- we always thought that this was a U.K. centric approach and we're going to spend to the other markets. We just had to make sure that it fits the long-term strategy with that business given the fact that we will remain small and probably won't grow.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. That's helpful. And then I just wanted to come back and just see if we can deconstruct a little bit the comment around the pressure being driven by managed care. So I understand the dynamics of former SQ customers now,  if you will, being n
componenttext: Okay, perfect. That's helpful. And then I just wanted to come back and just see if we can deconstruct a little bit the comment around the pressure being driven by managed care. So I understand the dynamics of former SQ customers now,  if you will, being negotiated under LQ contracts. But where does specifically managed care hit the business?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think where managed care hit the business the most, right, is the trend of the -- the physicians practice being acquired by hospitals. So right, early stages when that happened, we didn't see a material impact. But naturally, as you can imagine, right,
componenttext: I think where managed care hit the business the most, right, is the trend of the -- the physicians practice being acquired by hospitals. So right, early stages when that happened, we didn't see a material impact. But naturally, as you can imagine, right, renegotiating the med waste contract was not the first thing on those hospital administrators listed to do when they bought those 300 doctors practices. We're finding now, they getting around to that part of the integration. And as those renewals come up, you can imagine, right, the purchasing power of our IDN, as they put those out to bid, can be significant. So that's one aspect of it. The other is just with the local and regional competition and just the unaffiliated SQ looking to save more money as their reimbursements going down, we are noticing an increasing amount of discounting that we need to make to renew those agreements. So again, it's not like the business is declining. This is just cutting into our overall SQ growth.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. So -- so I think, the disconnect was, it sounds like you're talking about the trend of hospitals acquiring physicians, private practices and making them employees versus I thought there was some true managed care from a managed care provider
componenttext: Okay, got it. So -- so I think, the disconnect was, it sounds like you're talking about the trend of hospitals acquiring physicians, private practices and making them employees versus I thought there was some true managed care from a managed care provider angle which doesn't sound like that?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. Good clarification, that's not the case. This is a matter I'm Hospital XYZ, over time, I'll acquire 100 Dr. Practice as those agreements come up, they look to put on all-out for RPP. Were usually well positioned because we had very good servic
componenttext: No, no, no. Good clarification, that's not the case. This is a matter I'm Hospital XYZ, over time, I'll acquire 100 Dr. Practice as those agreements come up, they look to put on all-out for RPP. Were usually well positioned because we had very good service and are fully integrated to win those. But it's just a matter of puts pricing pressure from the previous price to the now the new negotiated price from the hospital system.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Larry, I think that, part of the investment that Brent spoke about is we have other additional services that we think play well in hospital-affiliated accounts, things they care about, pharmaceutical waste disposal, reasonable sharps. Part of that inv
componenttext: And Larry, I think that, part of the investment that Brent spoke about is we have other additional services that we think play well in hospital-affiliated accounts, things they care about, pharmaceutical waste disposal, reasonable sharps. Part of that investment is to make sure that even though the decision might be delayed because it's not made by office managers, it's made by a hospital that we want to make sure from a marketing and sales perspective that we have an opportunity to drive the additional services to that hospital group.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that make sense. And then last one for me, I don't know how much you can help me on this. But I think you mentioned in the past that perhaps that if you looked at the SQ group that was now again sort of being negotiated under LQ terms, it was around
componenttext: Okay, that make sense. And then last one for me, I don't know how much you can help me on this. But I think you mentioned in the past that perhaps that if you looked at the SQ group that was now again sort of being negotiated under LQ terms, it was around 16% and I guess what I'm just trying to wrap my our arms around a little bit, it sounds like this may be -- you'll try to offset this and sell more services. But sounds like this could be a headwind for certainly foreseeable future.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it will be an ongoing headwind until we get further renewal pace obviously but I think the number was more like 18% to 20%. And the reason this range, Larry, is sometimes the doctors gets acquired and we don't know. We continue to service the
componenttext: Yes, I think it will be an ongoing headwind until we get further renewal pace obviously but I think the number was more like 18% to 20%. And the reason this range, Larry, is sometimes the doctors gets acquired and we don't know. We continue to service the account under that contract. And when the renewal comes up or further down the line maybe a year after the hospital is acquired, as to Brent's point, this is not something that's top on their list then we get a notification. So one thing that we do have in our favor is the data that we have seen is that the consolidation seems to repeat at this point. And I don't think this will be growing every year or becomes 25%, 50%, at least based on the data that we see today.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Levine from Imperial Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Levine from Imperial Capital.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to push on that last point a little bit more and just make sure I understand this correctly because it would seem like the kind of issue that would develop over time and it seems like it's all kind of hitting home pretty quickly. In one shot,
componenttext: I just want to push on that last point a little bit more and just make sure I understand this correctly because it would seem like the kind of issue that would develop over time and it seems like it's all kind of hitting home pretty quickly. In one shot, am I thinking about it correctly? Or is this a trend that has been developing for a period of time? It's really coming to a head here in the second quarter? Maybe just a little bit more color on how this issue has evolved affecting the pricing in particular in the core business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think if you look at it, certainly, this has been something that we've looked out for many years. We actually -- within the company, we call it blended accounts, hospital affiliated accounts. Certainly, it's been a trend. We've seen over the years some
componenttext: I think if you look at it, certainly, this has been something that we've looked out for many years. We actually -- within the company, we call it blended accounts, hospital affiliated accounts. Certainly, it's been a trend. We've seen over the years some pricing pressure, not really material to the overall numbers. We did see it increasing in Q1 and that's why we kind of spoke about it on the last call. We saw that trend continue and more contracts get renegotiated in Q2. And we're taking that data that we have now, Q1 building Q2 and now we're applying it in our guidance on a go forward because we feel Q1 we weren't sure. We wanted to look a little bit more. we called out potential issue and certainly, we see a little bit of acceleration there in Q2. And if that acceleration continues then we're going to see that headwind. And the proactive SG&A is that we don't want to wait to react. We want to make sure that we get out in front of it with respect to investments and mitigate this on a go forward basis.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then may be one just follow up, sticking with that SQ business. I know you guys used to give metrics for additions in Steri-Safe and also [indiscernible]. Just maybe qualitatively, are you still seeing kind of the same success in general with
componenttext: Got it. And then may be one just follow up, sticking with that SQ business. I know you guys used to give metrics for additions in Steri-Safe and also [indiscernible]. Just maybe qualitatively, are you still seeing kind of the same success in general with the penetration rates in some of the more -- these older call it, complementary services within the SQ and LQ businesses? Or is that flowing at all?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we continue to see nice adoption of whether it's our [indiscernible] compliance program, we have a really strong growth in our pharmaceutical waste program and SQ. On the LQ side, we continue to close -- charge management accounts as well as our Rx Ph
componenttext: No, we continue to see nice adoption of whether it's our [indiscernible] compliance program, we have a really strong growth in our pharmaceutical waste program and SQ. On the LQ side, we continue to close -- charge management accounts as well as our Rx Pharmaceutical Waste Compliance service. So all of those, we continue to see nice progress. So no, I wouldn't say those are falling off.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Rodgers from Great Lakes Review.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: The accounts being acquired by hospitals, the SQ accounts, do you still consider them as SQ accounts? Or are you now classifying them as LQ accounts?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as Charlie mentioned, we call them blend accounts. So they're either SQ affiliated or blend accounts. But...
componenttext: Well, as Charlie mentioned, we call them blend accounts. So they're either SQ affiliated or blend accounts. But...

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they are SQ numbers. They've always been in the SQ numbers. We've always track them because we've been monitoring this for many years. And I think you've raised a good point. What is the LQ, what is in LQ now? And what's an SQ. And given the fact tha
componenttext: Yes, they are SQ numbers. They've always been in the SQ numbers. We've always track them because we've been monitoring this for many years. And I think you've raised a good point. What is the LQ, what is in LQ now? And what's an SQ. And given the fact that we've now gone to a revenue table with different services, it's likely when we give guidance, we'll continue. I know you guys all have modeled SQ, LQ and recall. We'll continue to give guidance -- we continue to give numbers for that through the end of the year. It's most likely where we give guidance next year and we talk about the lines of business services. The growth rates will be bucketed by that. And because what do you call a hospital on SQ? You're still going to that location, you still getting a small amount of waste, it is historically been in our SQ numbers but it would probably be at the entity, SQ, LQ metrics that we get out going into 2017.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as you cross sell Shred-it are you selling that as bundled medical hazardous waste Shred-it contract or are you keeping them separate?
componenttext: And as you cross sell Shred-it are you selling that as bundled medical hazardous waste Shred-it contract or are you keeping them separate?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: I would say we're doing both, just depends on the customer and what they're looking for. So we can factor them together an overall package and compliant services as well as removal of medical waste as well as their secure information destruction or we can sell them all apart.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sarah. I'd like to take a moment and share with listeners that Stericycle will celebrate the 20th anniversary of its Initial Public Offering in August. 1996 was a record year for IPOs. More than 1,200 companies went public that year. 20 years l
componenttext:
Thank you, Sarah. I'd like to take a moment and share with listeners that Stericycle will celebrate the 20th anniversary of its Initial Public Offering in August. 1996 was a record year for IPOs. More than 1,200 companies went public that year. 20 years later, approximately 100 of those companies remain listed, among all of the 1996 IPOs, Stericycle is one of the top success stories. We are very proud of that accomplishment and we'll continue to build on our strength which include the hard work and dedication of our team members, they have one team, one goal mentality. Our operational excellence and continued improved focus the ability to close and integrate acquisitions and not being afraid to try new things. 
I want to thank all of those team members, past and present, that have contributed to our success this last 20 years and we look forward to all of the opportunities the next 20 years will bring. Thank you all and have a great evening.
