componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as we're reporting right now, you are getting a 1-year look back. And on Q4 is you would get 2 additional years. So at the end of year, you would get '16, '15 and '14. We'll continue to look at that, Gary. This is a brand-new report out there
componenttext: Yes, I think as we're reporting right now, you are getting a 1-year look back. And on Q4 is you would get 2 additional years. So at the end of year, you would get '16, '15 and '14. We'll continue to look at that, Gary. This is a brand-new report out there. And so, as we're out there, we'll provide feedback when we can. But as of right now, it's a year-over-year and at the end of the year, you get a 3-year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And I had just one other -- and by the way, we appreciate the extra color look into that revenue. And then just one operational one. I guess, Charlie, at what point do you decide that some of these businesses you've ventured into just are not up to
componenttext: Great. And I had just one other -- and by the way, we appreciate the extra color look into that revenue. And then just one operational one. I guess, Charlie, at what point do you decide that some of these businesses you've ventured into just are not up to the historical Stericycle quality around profitability potential or stability of revenue and look to maybe consider other exits than those British contracts? Is that on the table? Have you thought about it? Is the board considering these things? Or do you feel like in a reasonable timeline, you can start to fix some of the damaged businesses and not just grow your way out of it by growing Shred-it?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Thanks, Gary. I mean, obviously, we continue. We've always looked at the businesses and whether or not they fit in the long-term strategy. I mean, certainly, in this quarter, you saw that we started taking steps, at least in the patient transport busi
componenttext: No. Thanks, Gary. I mean, obviously, we continue. We've always looked at the businesses and whether or not they fit in the long-term strategy. I mean, certainly, in this quarter, you saw that we started taking steps, at least in the patient transport business in the U.K. Although we're still in that business, we were able to exit 2 contracts. We'll continue to look at that on a contract-by-contract basis, and then we'll review whether or not that business fits in the long-term strategy. And I think, really, the focus has been on the manufacturer and industrial business. And whether or not do we stay in that business, I want to maybe take a step back before I answer that one. I mean, we got into that business. So we needed to build the infrastructures we said before to support our core strategy around retail, health care, SQ, hazardous waste. And those services continue to grow and they do fit the Stericycle model. They are predictable and stable. We've made the PSC acquisition and a few of our acquisitions overseas. We did -- the hazardous waste dynamic at that time were good. They were growing. M&I was strong. However, since the market divisions obviously have deteriorated, we are currently evaluating all options there. And that's an option around do we need the infrastructure we currently have to support the predictable and stable parts of that business? Are there parts of that business that don't belong in the portfolio? And we will look at that over the next 2 quarters. Certainly, we'll look at that.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: So just to be able to work through the model. Dan, you gave a SG&A number, which I'm assuming is net of amortization and adjustments. So that's what I'd call a core SG&A. That was about $180 million, is that 0.9? Is that the way to think about is it's going to be $180 million a quarter for a while? And then I had a...

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you will -- Michael, as you've seen then, we begin to, really, at the beginning of the year, look at things from an EBITA perspective. It's appropriate for us to look at SG&A as an amortization. I'm sure that in the quarter, when you looked at it and
componenttext: Yes, you will -- Michael, as you've seen then, we begin to, really, at the beginning of the year, look at things from an EBITA perspective. It's appropriate for us to look at SG&A as an amortization. I'm sure that in the quarter, when you looked at it and you did see a spike up in amortization expense, I think it's probably appropriate to address that since you've asked that question. And that as we finalize the purchase accounting for the Shred-it deal, there was a recommendation by the third party that we utilized due to the purchase accounting to increase the value of our customer relations. And at the same time, reduce the period over which we amortize that. And that's why you saw a onetime spike in amortization. But even prior to that, we began looking at the business aspect of that. So I do think it's appropriate when looking at it to continue to do that. And I think you've seen a little bit of improvement in the SG&A number and I think you should show what you're looking at is pretty stable. But as Brent mentioned, we are going to make investments in SG&A to be able to ramp up the growth in the areas that Brent discussed.

Having just really announced this restructure in May, which is largely due in the integrating 2 very impressive companies. componenttext: No, because I think if you -- there's a few things, Michael, I think you got to think about when you're looking at the recent quarter. And then I think if you adjust for the lower fuel surcharges, I don't think it's accurate to say we had a net decline. It wasn't like historical numbers, but there was a positive increase in that business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Scott. Jump in if I missed anything because you had a couple of parts to that question. So international growth rates for the quarter were approximately 6% and that was driven higher in the quarter by a good communication solution and recall activit
componenttext: Sure, Scott. Jump in if I missed anything because you had a couple of parts to that question. So international growth rates for the quarter were approximately 6% and that was driven higher in the quarter by a good communication solution and recall activity overseas. We did bring down a full-year guidance there and that is directly related to the exit of the patient transport contracts in the second half of the year. A little more color on the patient transport business and what that meant with respect to the quarter or guidance is we have negotiated an exit on 2 contracts later this year. We are going to still incur costs, though, while we transition out of these contracts and if you think about what is the headwind for that particular one, I think Dan addressed it earlier on, the bridge there of about $0.02 to $0.04 to EPS for the rest of the year. As far as -- you had a question about Argentina. We do have a facility that was shut down -- will be shut down for most of the rest of the year. It had to do with heavy rains in the Buenos Aires area earlier on. That facility shut down I think around April. So it did have some impact a little bit for us in Q2. And your last question related to government contracts in Brazil, and we talked about that, that we are having issues taking some of the increases we have on wages and passing that through. There's nothing new there. It hasn't worsened. We didn't think it was going to get better; that's why we guided down a little bit on that on the last call. But there's really no update there. It’s still a tough situation with respect to Latin America. We continue to try to work the best we can contract by contract in getting increases passed through. I believe I caught all of your questions.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You did. Yes, great. You covered them all. A follow-up on the patient transportation in the U.K. Exiting 2 contracts, what is left and what's -- I assume everything will be exited ultimately. What's the time frame?
componenttext: You did. Yes, great. You covered them all. A follow-up on the patient transportation in the U.K. Exiting 2 contracts, what is left and what's -- I assume everything will be exited ultimately. What's the time frame?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't necessarily made a decision on the ultimate exit of that business. Yes, we did exit 2 agreements. We're left with about $65 million to $75 million in annualized revenue after the exit. That number, though, has also come down with the exchange r
componenttext: We haven't necessarily made a decision on the ultimate exit of that business. Yes, we did exit 2 agreements. We're left with about $65 million to $75 million in annualized revenue after the exit. That number, though, has also come down with the exchange rate headwind in the U.K. Remember, the last call, I talked about that business being $85 million to $95 million. So about half of the reduction that I just spoke to came from foreign exchange. The other half came from the exit of those contracts. There are about 30 contracts in total. Again, we're looking at this on a contract by contract basis. Certainly, we're looking at some contracts that are unprofitable that we're looking to exit and then we'll make a decision on the long-term strategic fit of that business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one final quick follow-up. Is the restructure over now or the redesign or whatever you guys -- the McKinsey Study and the diagnostics? What do -- what should we anticipate looking ahead? I assume you're still going to guide the out year on
componenttext: Okay. And just one final quick follow-up. Is the restructure over now or the redesign or whatever you guys -- the McKinsey Study and the diagnostics? What do -- what should we anticipate looking ahead? I assume you're still going to guide the out year on the third quarter call. So just kind of curious what additional changes we'll see in reporting going forward and just operational fundamental is all the consultants gone and the new processes in place?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as the major changes, we tried, Scott, to bucket those together. Obviously, from an organizational perspective, you don't want to just have change after change happening. So we tried to bucket as many of those together. But Stericycle is where
componenttext: Yes, as far as the major changes, we tried, Scott, to bucket those together. Obviously, from an organizational perspective, you don't want to just have change after change happening. So we tried to bucket as many of those together. But Stericycle is where -- one of our core values is continuous improvement. So we'll always be looking to make the necessary changes to continue to improve and drive our business. With regard to upcoming changes that you'll start to see, I referenced the consolidation or virtualization of our inside sales team. That's something we're working on. We're currently working on also using all the expertise we have in customer service to bring all of that together, use our technology around call quality, call routing, intelligent work distribution, all of those things. So these are things that we're just a few years ahead in our journey than Shred-it was, and I think we have a lot of opportunities to continue to make margin improvements as we take the expertise we've had in having all the logistics-based business that used to be decentralized and really pulling all of this and using that same expertise and best practice and taking that to Shred-it. But the final thing I'll add is we are continuing a couple of engagements with the consultants, some around sourcing and some around customer data and information and we're excited about both those projects.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just to quickly sneak in, any thoughts on segment reporting changes in the third quarter, I guess, Dan, for you, on the guide that we should think about now?
componenttext: Okay. And just to quickly sneak in, any thoughts on segment reporting changes in the third quarter, I guess, Dan, for you, on the guide that we should think about now?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I think we showed you what we're prepared to do, what we think fits. Obviously, it's a representation of how we're running the business. As far as the revenue table, it's not only how we run the business but it's also providing information that w
componenttext: Yes. No, I think we showed you what we're prepared to do, what we think fits. Obviously, it's a representation of how we're running the business. As far as the revenue table, it's not only how we run the business but it's also providing information that we thought would be meaningful for you, too. I think everything that we have at least in the near term is laid out the way we planned for it to be.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Manthey from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Manthey from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at the declines in the SQ, LQ, international growth rates, is that all volume and fuel surcharges? Or is there a component of price declines also?
componenttext: When you look at the declines in the SQ, LQ, international growth rates, is that all volume and fuel surcharges? Or is there a component of price declines also?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'll take that, David. So again, I think when you're looking at growth rates, you should look at the full year. Because I think that takes out the comparable issues. So I'll answer it with that view in mind. So we're -- we obviously had a big infl
componenttext: Yes, so I'll take that, David. So again, I think when you're looking at growth rates, you should look at the full year. Because I think that takes out the comparable issues. So I'll answer it with that view in mind. So we're -- we obviously had a big influx of revenue in Q2 of last year. So the main contributors are lower M&I and lower fuel surcharges. Certainly, we've seen some of this SQ pricing start to build now. So there is a component of that in Q2. When you adjust, though, for all of those impacts, the impacts around M&I and lower fuel surcharges, we would have been at a comparative of about 6 SQ and 4 LQ. And then I think it begs the question around, well, what does that mean going forward into 2017? So when we -- well, obviously, we're going to provide our exact guidance on 2017 on the October call. However, some of the headwinds we've discussed here today around M&I and around our regulated compliance solutions business will continue into next year. So we anticipate that 2017 growth rates will be lower than the historical averages.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you talked about M&I and potentially thinking about getting out of that business or somehow stripping out those revenues and not being in the business anymore. If that were to happen, though, wouldn't it stand to reason that what was left o
componenttext: Okay. And then you talked about M&I and potentially thinking about getting out of that business or somehow stripping out those revenues and not being in the business anymore. If that were to happen, though, wouldn't it stand to reason that what was left of PSC would be underutilized, you might have to close facility, you ship further to get there? I'm just trying to understand how that would happen, because at a conference back in June, Dan had talked about the volume have sort of indicated that you would take those volumes day of the week because they were helping you maximize the utilization of your facilities?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, so a good question. First of all, no assumptions right now. We have not made any decisions to sell any part of our hazardous waste business. That includes obviously our retail, health care and SQ or our M&I business, our manufacturing and indu
componenttext: Yes, David, so a good question. First of all, no assumptions right now. We have not made any decisions to sell any part of our hazardous waste business. That includes obviously our retail, health care and SQ or our M&I business, our manufacturing and industrial. One of the reasons to call it out on the table is that, obviously, has a lot of unpredictabilities to it. So from an analyst and a shareholder perspective, we wanted to call that out. If we made a decision to sell or to move away from a business, we certainly look at what's left from an operational infrastructure and make the proper adjustments to make sure that we can run a very predictable, stable and profitable business. We wouldn't just leave and then try to figure out what the infrastructure would look like afterwards. That would all be part of the overall decision.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then somewhat related, as it relates to these -- the structures of these businesses, you've talked about the difficulty in converting on-site shredding customers to off-site, and if there's a handful of holdout customers that could hold up the e
componenttext: Okay. And then somewhat related, as it relates to these -- the structures of these businesses, you've talked about the difficulty in converting on-site shredding customers to off-site, and if there's a handful of holdout customers that could hold up the entire process of gaining synergies given the structure of your trucks and things like that. Is it wrong to think that, that would extend beyond the initial integration? For example, if you acquire a document destruction target a year from now, 2 years from now, won't you have the same difficulty integrating that route into an existing route if there's a number of customers that want their paper to be shredded on-site?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, maybe I didn't communicate this as well on the past. We will always have on-site customers and we're going to offer both services going forward. So for those customers who want their documents destroyed on site, we'll always have those resourc
componenttext: Yes, David, maybe I didn't communicate this as well on the past. We will always have on-site customers and we're going to offer both services going forward. So for those customers who want their documents destroyed on site, we'll always have those resources and assets. Our focus has been at just moving a percentage of those to where more of them are on-site versus on-site. So yes, we'll always be going to this process of ask, letting customers know the 2 different ways that we can handle their documents and then helping guide them to the most appropriate one that meets their needs. So this will be an ongoing process. Clearly, it's more efficient for us to do it off-site, but if they wanted on-site, we'll continue to do that as well.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just a little more color there, David. And remember, since office business was both on-site and off-site, they had about 60% of their customers off-site, but they offered on-site and they had 40%. All we're saying now is the combined entity during th
componenttext: Yes, just a little more color there, David. And remember, since office business was both on-site and off-site, they had about 60% of their customers off-site, but they offered on-site and they had 40%. All we're saying now is the combined entity during the integration period will get the combined entity to 60% off-site and the remainder on-site. But I think it's a key point. I've seen some articles out there about Stericycle's getting out of the on-site business. That is not accurate. That is not part of the plan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then final question. Are the consultants still there? Or are they gone?
componenttext: Okay. And then final question. Are the consultants still there? Or are they gone?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. As I mentioned earlier, consultants now have moved onto a sourcing project as well as the data projects. So we are -- we've moved onto 2 other smaller projects, but ones that we're very interested in.
componenttext: No. As I mentioned earlier, consultants now have moved onto a sourcing project as well as the data projects. So we are -- we've moved onto 2 other smaller projects, but ones that we're very interested in.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Barbara Noverini from MorningStar.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Barbara Noverini from MorningStar.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's interesting to see organic revenue decline for the quarter in the new communications segment, and I assume much of that is related to the recall business. But given that recall is such a lumpy business, including it in this segment sort of masks t
componenttext: So it's interesting to see organic revenue decline for the quarter in the new communications segment, and I assume much of that is related to the recall business. But given that recall is such a lumpy business, including it in this segment sort of masks the underlying growth of com-sol, which you've talked about in the past as a nice growth platform for you. So I understand that's a pretty steady recurring revenue stream kind of business. So if you were to exclude recall, how did that com-sol business perform? And what could we expect for that going forward?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so there's a few things I'll point out in that. And I think you brought up some good questions there, Barb. First of all, when we look at combining the businesses, the first thing we look at was that 60% of recalls revenues were call center-related.
componenttext: Yes, so there's a few things I'll point out in that. And I think you brought up some good questions there, Barb. First of all, when we look at combining the businesses, the first thing we look at was that 60% of recalls revenues were call center-related. As you know, recalls consisted of retrieval, disposal, notification and call center. But the lion's share of the work there was call center. So there was a lot of synergies and we have been working for more than a year trying to figure out how do we leverage our Communication Solutions team to take those recall works which is lumpy in nature. So that was one of the thought process of bringing the two together. Secondly, on your question around, well, what is the growth rate if we exclude some things. And recall, certainly, was down this quarter. It was $20.9 million. It was down to 26% year-over-year. So let's remove the noise there on the number. I think the team -- the com-sol team and the recall team did a good job of winning auto call center contracts which we utilized the Communication Solutions team for. So they assist in vehicle buybacks and customer care-related work. So when you strip out the noise and you exclude the U.S. recalls, the Europe recalls and acquisitions, year-to-date growth in com-sol was actually about 11%. I cautioned you a little bit about moving forward there. We have some year-over-year comps in Q3. But we are -- we think about it, how did we get that work in com-sol in the auto space? It started with an acquisition that we made of a company that had a relationship with auto manufacturers. They were able to pass along where we got some small recall events in auto. But really then, we're able to work with Communication Solutions and we're now doing some large work for auto manufacturers, like I said, in the area of vehicle buybacks and customer care work. So if you think about it, it's worked very well. We took an acquisition. We extended the services they can offer, and it's paying off nicely for that part of the business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Isaac Ro from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Isaac Ro from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Joel in for Isaac. So could we get any color on what you guys are seeing in terms of pricing with the document destruction side of the business? And then maybe any insights on your plans to integrate paper pricing surcharges into any of the
componenttext: It's actually Joel in for Isaac. So could we get any color on what you guys are seeing in terms of pricing with the document destruction side of the business? And then maybe any insights on your plans to integrate paper pricing surcharges into any of the newer contracts that you've been signing?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, this is Brent. With regard to pricing -- it's with regard to market pricing, again, haven't noticed any major changes or differences in the trends from what -- when we got into the business. One thing that we're really excited about, though, is the s
componenttext: Joe, this is Brent. With regard to pricing -- it's with regard to market pricing, again, haven't noticed any major changes or differences in the trends from what -- when we got into the business. One thing that we're really excited about, though, is the size of the unbid market and the ability for our team to go out there and convert it and convince those customers that it is better to outsource that service as opposed to, to be noncompliant or to shred it themselves. So obviously, when we go out and convert that business, we're able to kind of assess the value with the customer and we do really well there. With regard to the paper pricing, we're happy to come back. And so, hopefully, we'll continue to see it come back tomorrow, that $150 million historical level. But so far, it's on the right trend.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and right now, I mean, it's about $146 million. So it's not that far off of that 10-year. We talked about that 5- to 10-year average of $152 million. So we're pleased that has come back. Dan talked about how that created a little bit of a tailwind fo
componenttext: Yes, and right now, I mean, it's about $146 million. So it's not that far off of that 10-year. We talked about that 5- to 10-year average of $152 million. So we're pleased that has come back. Dan talked about how that created a little bit of a tailwind for us in that business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think as you're also asking about questions about getting language into the contracts.  And as we mentioned that, that would be -- as the contract cycle of about 4 years, we would be migrating that in. So that will take time to implement over the wh
componenttext: And I think as you're also asking about questions about getting language into the contracts.  And as we mentioned that, that would be -- as the contract cycle of about 4 years, we would be migrating that in. So that will take time to implement over the whole contract base.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the good news there is that the team has made strides in getting that language in the new agreements that we're signing. So we're moving forward on that front.
componenttext: And the good news there is that the team has made strides in getting that language in the new agreements that we're signing. So we're moving forward on that front.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then maybe just to clarify, on the SG&A investments, you guys discussed in the context of offsetting some of the pricing pressure in SQ. Was that a back half of 2016 phenomenon? Or was that something that you guys would be implementing over the
componenttext: Great. And then maybe just to clarify, on the SG&A investments, you guys discussed in the context of offsetting some of the pricing pressure in SQ. Was that a back half of 2016 phenomenon? Or was that something that you guys would be implementing over the longer term?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. That's going to be over the -- the initial investments will be in the back half of about $4 million to $5 million in the back half of '16, and where we're going to put that is incremental sales and marketing. And we're going to really focus that
componenttext: Correct. That's going to be over the -- the initial investments will be in the back half of about $4 million to $5 million in the back half of '16, and where we're going to put that is incremental sales and marketing. And we're going to really focus that on driving additional services and the SQs that have been acquired by hospitals. The reality is that they still need the services that we have, whether that be pharmaceutical waste or our compliance training services so -- or our Sharps Management Service. We just feel like we need additional resources to help get out there and push that forward. And then the second part will be a new part for us, which is real exciting. As you think about it, most of our sales process in the past has been up-selling existing customers to additional compliance services. We have a large market opportunity with regard to incremental sites in the SQ market, and so we're excited about proactively approaching and gaining those sites with this sales investment.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Steinke from Barrington Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Steinke from Barrington Research.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you provide the bridge from prior revenue guidance to the updated revenue guidance as you did for EPS? And also, what's the full year impact of currency incorporated into guidance now?
componenttext: Could you provide the bridge from prior revenue guidance to the updated revenue guidance as you did for EPS? And also, what's the full year impact of currency incorporated into guidance now?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll be happy to do that. So revenue, as you know before, the prior guidance was $3.6 billion to $3.66 billion. The Q2 lower revenues will create unfavorable, about $10 million for the guidance going forward. The lower expert guidance will be $5 mill
componenttext: Yes, I'll be happy to do that. So revenue, as you know before, the prior guidance was $3.6 billion to $3.66 billion. The Q2 lower revenues will create unfavorable, about $10 million for the guidance going forward. The lower expert guidance will be $5 million to $15 million. The environmental solutions will be about $10 million in the back half of the year. SQ growth that we've talked about is anywhere from $10 million to $15 million in the back half of the year. Exiting that patient, those 2 patient transportation contracts will be between $7 million and $12 million on the back half. And then the acquisitions that we did will contribute about $5 million foreign exchange, and I think I'm going to answer both questions with this one. The Brexit will create about $10 million in foreign exchange headwinds. Most of it had to do with the Brexit. And then the improvement in paper prices is about $5 million. If you look at that, it will bring you to about $3.56 billion to $3.60 billion in revenue for the year guidance.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Got it. And I am not sure if you touched on this earlier. But you mentioned that last quarter that you had some good success cross-selling document destruction services to some health care customers and you also cited some new wins this quarter
componenttext: All right. Got it. And I am not sure if you touched on this earlier. But you mentioned that last quarter that you had some good success cross-selling document destruction services to some health care customers and you also cited some new wins this quarter. So where do we stand on the cross-selling efforts of information destruction to health care? And are you now setting up the team to sell those services more aggressively to the legacy Stericycle customer base?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kevin. Charlie commented a little bit on those earlier. But I'll just reiterate, the sales pilots are going well. We did have to keep them relatively smaller in scale just with the magnitude of things that we had going on with the organizational rede
componenttext: Yes, Kevin. Charlie commented a little bit on those earlier. But I'll just reiterate, the sales pilots are going well. We did have to keep them relatively smaller in scale just with the magnitude of things that we had going on with the organizational redesign. But they have contributed to the success in new revenue or new sales that Shred-it had in Q2. And we're -- overall, we're very pleased with the progress Shred-it's organic growth is making. It's anywhere from 3% to 5%, which is high -- slightly higher than historical averages. We look to accelerate that -- the investments with regard to cross-selling. I think that's the way the new sales organization we'd set it up to sell all services. It's going to be a great plus there. So again, we're still in the process of learning lessons and continuing the pilot. The ones that work best, we will fund and we will accelerate those in the back half of the year and into next year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to add a little color, I'll give you an example, Kevin, on the LQ. One part of the redesign, on the organizational redesign is that our hospital group, which is led by -- that's one of the segments that Brent talked about, they will have embedded
componenttext: And just to add a little color, I'll give you an example, Kevin, on the LQ. One part of the redesign, on the organizational redesign is that our hospital group, which is led by -- that's one of the segments that Brent talked about, they will have embedded specialists that can sell secure information destruction to those customers. It's a similar model that we followed for Sharps Management, for Rx Waste. That team has always delivered solid results when we use the major account executives' relationships with hospitals to bring in those specialists to get that cross-selling activity signed and brought into the company. So we're excited about that. That was part of the focus, certainly, as we get through the redesign. And now we're gearing up that team to be within the hospital sales team for Stericycle.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Larry Keusch from Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Larry Keusch from Raymond James.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to start on the patient transport and the $65 million to $75 million in revenues that you mentioned after you exit the 2 contracts. How do we think about sort of the economics of that remaining revenue? So in other words, is there a portion of th
componenttext: I wanted to start on the patient transport and the $65 million to $75 million in revenues that you mentioned after you exit the 2 contracts. How do we think about sort of the economics of that remaining revenue? So in other words, is there a portion of that business that makes sense? Or should we really be thinking about you looking to exit these contracts over time? Because again, just the overall economics just don't make sense and aren't going to change.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Larry. I would tell you that about 4 years ago is when we were in the -- we started to get in the patient transport business in the U.K. It came with a med waste acquisition. And for a couple of years, in some of the smaller contracts that we're winn
componenttext: Yes, Larry. I would tell you that about 4 years ago is when we were in the -- we started to get in the patient transport business in the U.K. It came with a med waste acquisition. And for a couple of years, in some of the smaller contracts that we're winning in the north of England and other parts of the U.K., they were profitable. And that profitability was very similar to our med waste business. And as we discussed, we went into this business thinking that the NHS was going to outsource this in a large tranches of contract. We were correct on that call, but we've had difficulty setting up and delivering on a profitable basis in that marketplace. So you're right. As we start to look at the unprofitable contracts, there are some contracts, legacy contracts and contracts -- smaller contracts that we've won over the last several years that are profitable. And that's why we'll take a step back at that point to figure out what do we do next. Do we sell that business? Do we stay in that business? We really need to look at it on a -- we always thought that this was a U.K.-centric approach and wasn't going to expand to other markets. And we just have to make sure that it fits in the long-term strategy of that business given the fact that we will remain small and probably won't grow.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. That's helpful. And then I just wanted to come back and just see if we can deconstruct a little bit the comment around the pressures being driven by managed care. So I understand the dynamics of former SQ customers now, if you will, being n
componenttext: Okay, perfect. That's helpful. And then I just wanted to come back and just see if we can deconstruct a little bit the comment around the pressures being driven by managed care. So I understand the dynamics of former SQ customers now, if you will, being negotiated under LQ contracts. But where does specifically managed care hit the business?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think where managed care hits the business the most, right, is the trend of the physicians' practice being acquired by hospitals. So right -- early stages when that happened, we didn't see a material impact. But naturally, as you can imagine, righ
componenttext: Well, I think where managed care hits the business the most, right, is the trend of the physicians' practice being acquired by hospitals. So right -- early stages when that happened, we didn't see a material impact. But naturally, as you can imagine, right, renegotiating the med waste contract was not the first thing on those hospital administrators' list of to dos is when they bought those 300 doctors' practices. We're finding now, they're getting around to that part of the integration. And as those renewals come up, you can imagine, right, the purchasing power of our IDNs, as they put those out to bid, can be significant. So that's one aspect of it. The other is just with the local and regional competition and just the unaffiliated SQ looking to save more money as their reimbursement is going down, we are noticing an increasing amount of discounting that we need to make to renew those agreements. So again, it's not like the business is declining. This is just cutting into our overall SQ growth.

componenttext: Okay, got you. So -- okay. I think the disconnect was it sounds like you're talking about the trend of hospitals acquiring physicians, private practices and making them employees versus I thought there was some true managed care from a managed care provider angle, which doesn't sound like that is the case.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. No, no. Good clarification. No, that's not the case. This is just a matter of I'm Hospital XYZ, I, over time, have acquired 100 doctors' practices. As those agreements come up, they look to put them out, all-out for RFP. We're usually well positioned
componenttext: No. No, no. Good clarification. No, that's not the case. This is just a matter of I'm Hospital XYZ, I, over time, have acquired 100 doctors' practices. As those agreements come up, they look to put them out, all-out for RFP. We're usually well positioned because we have very good service and are fully integrated to win those. But it's just a matter of it puts pricing pressure from their previous price to now the new negotiated price from the hospital system.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think, Larry, part of the investment that Brent spoke about is we have other additional services that we think play well in a hospital-affiliated account, things they care about, pharmaceutical waste disposal, reusable sharps. Part of that investmen
componenttext: And I think, Larry, part of the investment that Brent spoke about is we have other additional services that we think play well in a hospital-affiliated account, things they care about, pharmaceutical waste disposal, reusable sharps. Part of that investment is to make sure that even though the decision might be delayed because now it's not made by an office manager, it's made by a hospital, that we want to make sure from a marketing and a sales perspective that we have an opportunity to drive the additional services to that hospital group.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. And then last one for you, and I don't know how much you can help on this. But I think you mentioned in the past that perhaps that if you looked at the SQ group that was now again sort of being negotiated under LQ terms, it was aro
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. And then last one for you, and I don't know how much you can help on this. But I think you mentioned in the past that perhaps that if you looked at the SQ group that was now again sort of being negotiated under LQ terms, it was around 16%. And I guess what I'm just trying to wrap my arms around a little bit is, it sounds like this might be -- you'll try to offset this and sell more services. But sounds like this could be a headwind for certainly a foreseeable future.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it'll be an ongoing headwind till we get through the renewal phase, obviously. But I think the number was more like 18% to 20%. And the reason it's a range, Larry, is that sometimes the doctor gets acquired, and we don't know. We continue to
componenttext: Yes, I think it'll be an ongoing headwind till we get through the renewal phase, obviously. But I think the number was more like 18% to 20%. And the reason it's a range, Larry, is that sometimes the doctor gets acquired, and we don't know. We continue to service the account under that contract. And when the renewal comes up or further down the line maybe a year after the hospital has acquired it, as to Brent's point, they don't really -- this is not something that's top on their list, then we get a notification. So one thing that we do have in our favor is the data that we have seen is that the consolidation seems to have peaked at this point. And I don't think this will be growing every year where it becomes 25%, 50%, at least based on the data that we see today.

componenttext: So I just want to push on that last point a little bit more and just make sure I understand this correctly because it would seem like the kind of issue that would develop over time and it seems like it's all kind of hitting home pretty quickly. And in one shot, am I thinking about it correctly? Or is this a trend that has been developing for a period of time that's really coming to a head here in the second quarter? Maybe just a little bit more color on how this issue has evolved affecting the pricing in particular in the core business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you look at this, I mean, this certainly has been something that we've looked out for many years. We've had -- we actually -- within the company, we call it blend accounts, hospital-affiliated accounts. Certainly, it's been a trend. We've
componenttext: Yes, I think if you look at this, I mean, this certainly has been something that we've looked out for many years. We've had -- we actually -- within the company, we call it blend accounts, hospital-affiliated accounts. Certainly, it's been a trend. We've seen, over the years, some pricing pressure, not really material to the overall numbers. We did see it increasing in Q1 and that's why we kind of spoke about it on the last call. We saw all that trends continue and more contracts get renegotiated in Q2. And we're taking that data that we have now, Q1 and building Q2, and now we're applying it in our guidance on a go forward because we feel Q1 we weren't sure. We wanted to look a little bit more. We called it out as a potential issue, and certainly, we see a little bit of acceleration there in Q2. And if that acceleration continues, then we're going to see that headwind. And the proactive SG&A is that we don't want to wait to react. We want to make sure that we get out in front of this with respect to investments and mitigate this on a go-forward basis.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And then maybe one just follow-up, sticking with that SQ business. I know you guys used to give metrics for additions in Steri-Safe and also Bio Systems and the like. componenttext: No, we continue to see nice adoption of whether it's our OSHA Compliance Program. We have a really strong growth in our pharmaceutical waste program in SQ. On the LQ side, we continue to close -- charge management accounts as well as Rx or Pharmaceutical Waste Compliance program. So all of those, we continue to see nice progress. So no, I wouldn't say those are falling off.

componenttext: Yes, I think, Jason, they are in the SQ numbers. They've always been in the SQ numbers. We've always tracked them because we've been monitoring this for many years. We'll continue to give -- we'll continue to give numbers for that through the end of the year. It's most likely where we give guidance next year, that when we talk about the alliance of business services, the growth rates will be bucketed by that. And because what do you call a hospital on SQ? You still go into that location. You're still getting a small amount of waste. It has historically been in our SQ numbers, but it'll probably be the end to the LQ-SQ matrix that we give out going into 2017.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sarah. I'd like to take a moment and share with listeners that Stericycle will celebrate the 20th anniversary of its Initial Public Offering in August. 1996 was a record year for IPOs. More than 1,200 companies went public that year. 20 years l
componenttext:
Thank you, Sarah. I'd like to take a moment and share with listeners that Stericycle will celebrate the 20th anniversary of its Initial Public Offering in August. 1996 was a record year for IPOs. More than 1,200 companies went public that year. 20 years later, approximately 100 of those companies remain listed. Among all of the 1996 IPOs, Stericycle is one of the top success stories. We are very proud of that accomplishment and we'll continue to build on our strength which include the hard work and dedication of our team members. They're a one-team, one-goal mentality. Our operational excellence and continuous improvement focus builds the ability to close and integrate acquisitions and not being afraid to try new things. 
I want to thank all of those team members, past and present, that have contributed to our success these last 20 years. And we look forward to all the opportunities the next 20 years will bring. Thank you all and have a great evening.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Amanda, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Sean McMillan, Vice President of Corporate Finance, you may
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Amanda, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Sean McMillan, Vice President of Corporate Finance, you may begin your conference.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle's Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, g
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle's Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. 
This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. Our actual results could differ significantly from the results described in the forward-looking statements. 
Factors that could cause such differences include: changes in governmental regulation of the collection, transportation, treatment and disposal of regulated waste or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing regulated waste collection and treatment or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; our obligation to service our substantial indebtedness and to comply with the covenants and restrictions contained in our private placement notes, term loan credit facility and revolving credit facility; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; competition and demand for services in the regulated waste and Secure Information Destruction industries; political, economic and currency risks that's related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other indefinite lived intangibles; variability in the demand for services we provide on a project or nonrecurring basis; exposure to environmental liabilities; fluctuations in the price we receive for the sale of paper; disruptions in or attacks on our information technology systems; compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements; as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-Ka. As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance and investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. 
We make no commitment to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn it over to  Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sean. Good afternoon, everybody, thank you for joining us on today's call. We were able to maintain consistent margin performance in the quarter despite revenue headwinds from previously discussed pricing pressure and softness in the manufactur
componenttext:
Thank you, Sean. Good afternoon, everybody, thank you for joining us on today's call. We were able to maintain consistent margin performance in the quarter despite revenue headwinds from previously discussed pricing pressure and softness in the manufacturing and industrial market. Our EPS exceeded expectations, in part driven by the use of our record free cash flow to accelerate our stock repurchase of mandatory preferred convertible shares. 
Joining me on today's call to discuss our Q3 results and 2017 preliminary guidance will be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and Brent Arnold, COO. I will now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Charlie. The results for the third quarter are as follows: Global revenues were $890.1 million, up 23.9% from $718.6 million in Q3 2015; an internal growth excluding the impact of foreign exchange, acquisitions and manufacturing and industrial ser
componenttext:
Thanks, Charlie. The results for the third quarter are as follows: Global revenues were $890.1 million, up 23.9% from $718.6 million in Q3 2015; an internal growth excluding the impact of foreign exchange, acquisitions and manufacturing and industrial services was up 1.6%; domestic revenues were $664.1 million; excluding the impact of acquisitions and manufacturing and industrial revenues, internal growth was 1.6%. 
For consistency of your models, we're providing the following for the remainder of the year. Domestic revenues were $664.1 million, of which $637.1 million was regulated waste and compliant services revenues and $26.9 million was recall and returns. Domestic internal growth, excluding recalls and returns revenues, was up 1%, consisting of SQ up 1% and LQ flat. As anticipated, growth rates were impacted by SQ pricing pressure, lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers and lower fuel surcharges. 
International revenues were $226.1 million or 3% internal growth when adjusted for foreign exchange impact. As anticipated, international growth rates were impacted by the exiting of certain patient transportation contracts. Acquisitions contributed $184.7 million to growth in the quarter. Gross profits were $381 million or 42.8% of revenues. SG&A expense, excluding amortization was $189.3 million or 21.3% of revenues. Adjusted income from operations or EBITA was $191.7 million or 21.5% of revenues. Net interest expense was $24.7 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $61.5 million or $0.72 per share on an as-reported basis and $1.24 when adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjustments. 
Now for the balance sheet. Our debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 3.35 at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $607 million. In the quarter, we repurchased 265,000 shares of the mandatory preferred convertible on the open market in the amount of $19.2 million. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 3.1 million shares. Our CapEx was $33.8 million or 3.8% of revenues. Our DSO was 65 days. Year-to-date, as-reported, cash from operations was $417.8 million. And when adjusted for recall reimbursement and other items, cash from operations was $467.6 million. 
I will now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. In the quarter, we closed 5 tuck-in acquisitions, all domestic. Revenues from the 5 acquisitions were approximately $0.4 million in the quarter and annualized for approximately $4 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with we
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. In the quarter, we closed 5 tuck-in acquisitions, all domestic. Revenues from the 5 acquisitions were approximately $0.4 million in the quarter and annualized for approximately $4 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 million annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business. 
The SQ pricing pressure discussed previously continued in the quarter and will remain for the foreseeable future. To address these pressures, we are making incremental strategic investments in sales, marketing and data analytics. These investments will enable us to pinpoint and execute on opportunities to grow our business and improve our overall performance. 
Despite the SQ headwinds, we are able to maintain our operating margin profile as well as deliver positive revenue growth in other services. For example, in our hospital customer base, we successfully completed several large charge [ph] management and pharmaceutical compliance installation. We saw strong growth in retail waste services, driven by our high level of service and detailed reporting capability. The combination of our customer relationships and our multiple compliance solutions provides a strong foundation for future growth. 
In the Secure Information Destruction Service, we continued to see strong sales resulting from the conversion of unbended customers to ongoing service. In addition, the national accounts team continues to make progress, securing new large customers. 
Our synergies remain on track with recent progress in streamlining back-office processes and implementing new technology to optimize our inside sales and customer service. 
In closing, we would like to thank all of our worldwide team members for their continued commitment to our customers, our shareholders and our core values. 
I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016 and preliminary guidance for 2017. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, in
componenttext:
Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016 and preliminary guidance for 2017. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration and acquisition-related expenses and other adjusted items. 
As a reminder, our 2016 EPS guidance is adjusted for amortization expense. For 2016, we believe EPS will be in the range of $4.74 to $4.76. This includes the benefit of our ongoing strategy for repurchase of mandatory preferred convertible shares. 
We expect revenue for 2016 will be in the range of $3.56 billion to $3.58 billion, depending on assumptions for growth and the impact of foreign exchange rates. 
Internal growth rates are expected to be: SQ, 3% to 5%; LQ, 2% to 3%; international, 4% to 5%; and recall and returns revenue between $95 million and $105 million. We have estimates for free cash flow in 2016 between $450 million and $470 million. 2016 CapEx is anticipated to be between $130 million to $135 million. We expect that 2016 full year as-reported tax rate to be approximately 36%. 
Now I'd like to provide preliminary guidance for 2017. For 2017, we believe EPS estimates will be in the range of $4.57 to $4.77, using a share count of approximately 91.1 million. This includes the unfavorable impact of approximately $0.19 from the normalization of performance compensation and additional SG&A investments to drive future growth and profitability. This is partially offset by approximately $0.17 of benefit from ongoing strategy to repurchase the mandatory preferred convertible shares. 
We believe revenues for 2017 will be in the range of $3.54 billion to $3.67 billion, depending on assumptions of foreign exchange and internal rates of flat to 3%. The worldwide revenue guidance for each of our service lines is as follows: regulated waste and compliant services will be in the range of $2.03 billion to $2.09 billion; Secure Information Destruction Services will be in the range of $780 million to $810 million; communications and related services will be in the range of $340 million to $370 million, depending on recall revenues; and manufacturing and industrial services will be in the range of $380 million to $400 million. 
We have estimates for free cash flow in 2017 between $450 million to $470 million. 2017 CapEx is anticipated to be between $125 million to $150 million. We expect the 2017 full year as-reported tax rate to be approximately 36.5%. 
Stericycle continues to be the market leader in multiple services and geographies. We have a strong team and an unmatched infrastructure. We are confident in the long-term outlook of our business. 
As a reminder, Stericycle will be hosting its first Investor Day and webcast on the morning of Thursday, November 10, to share perspectives on Stericycle's strategies, capabilities and plans to drive long-term shareholder value. More details are posted on the Events page of our Investor Relations website. We encourage investors, analysts and the public to join the live webcast or watch the meeting replay. 
Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. Amanda, you can open the Q&A.

componenttext: Okay. And then final question and I'll hop off. Also on pricing, have you given any thought to maybe going back to your customers even prior to renewal? componenttextpreview: No, absolutely, Ryan. I think, part of the investment we're making in SG&A both in resources and in the data analytics, that Brent mentioned in his opening, certainly is the strategy that we want to be proactive in the renewals and that is part of our own
componenttext: No, absolutely, Ryan. I think, part of the investment we're making in SG&A both in resources and in the data analytics, that Brent mentioned in his opening, certainly is the strategy that we want to be proactive in the renewals and that is part of our own ongoing strategy. So it's too early to tell the impact, but certainly, that is part of the strategy. Thanks, Ryan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: So following up on that question about being proactive on renewals. I think you've also discussed, as part of your investment, looking to cross sell more services to the SQ accounts that are seeing the pricing pressure. And I'm wondering if you're trying to make that more part of your renewal discussions. And if you think that can have any offsetting impact on the pricing pressure you're experiencing?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kevin, this is Brent. As we talked about on our last call, we were making a number of investments, both marketing and sales to try to offset some of these headwinds that we're seeing. A part of it, you remember correctly, right, we've got more sales
componenttext: Yes, Kevin, this is Brent. As we talked about on our last call, we were making a number of investments, both marketing and sales to try to offset some of these headwinds that we're seeing. A part of it, you remember correctly, right, we've got more sales reps that have been hired, and we're working to have them -- have a bigger impact with regard to influencing that renewal, emphasizing the value of our Series A [ph] services and overall, try to approach that situation proactively. Obviously, it's too early to see any returns on that. But that is definitely one of our strategies as well as trying to grow new sites in SQ with another strategy to offset that headwind and will drive new growth that in turn will help us offset that in the long term. So you're correct, those are some of the things that we're doing. It's just a little too early right now to see if that's having an effect.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

So I'm just wondering if you've started on that analysis and any initial thoughts on that work that you're doing there?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Sure, Kevin. We continue to evaluate multiple businesses, not just the M&I business, for their long-term strategic fit in our portfolio of services. We have not made any definitive decision yet on M&I or any assets within Stericycle.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, the first question I'd ask is on Shred-it. Just diving into the guidance and how we think about profitability. Can you give us a sense what you're expecting for synergies and profit growth at Shred-it? Or are we getting back to how you thought ab
componenttext: I guess, the first question I'd ask is on Shred-it. Just diving into the guidance and how we think about profitability. Can you give us a sense what you're expecting for synergies and profit growth at Shred-it? Or are we getting back to how you thought about the initial margin ramp at the time of acquisition? I know that was pushed out. Or should we think that, that continues to be somewhat lower? And I guess I'm trying to understand, is that a big factor that offsets pricing or -- that you've talked about in SQ? Or how do we think about Shred-it?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Gary. I'll touch a little bit on what we have as far as synergies built in [ph]. And it will be what we shared all along. The $20 million of synergies that we deferred from 2016, we fully anticipate that we're going to be able to capture thro
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Gary. I'll touch a little bit on what we have as far as synergies built in [ph]. And it will be what we shared all along. The $20 million of synergies that we deferred from 2016, we fully anticipate that we're going to be able to capture throughout 2017, which will certainly contribute to the profitability growth. And we've already began to join [ph] in the last years since we've owned Shred-it. So I think, Brent can probably talk about some of the steps that were taken to achieve the numbers that we have in the guidance.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] Gary, this is Brent. So no new activities here, but just continue to focus on integration activities associated with the re-routes, switching from on-site to off-site, continuing to look at back-office processes. The team actually had a re
componenttext: [indiscernible] Gary, this is Brent. So no new activities here, but just continue to focus on integration activities associated with the re-routes, switching from on-site to off-site, continuing to look at back-office processes. The team actually had a really busy quarter this quarter as we looked to automate and integrate all of our customer service. So we put them all on a national platform. We're in the process of doing that this quarter. We're doing the same thing with inside sales. We also have kicked off automation for several of our back-office processes, around collection, cash applications as well as AP [ph]. So a lot of those things will contribute to continue to drive cost out of the business to help us hit those synergies.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess just to follow up, on your international business where the profitability has really struggled. Can you give us an update on what's going on there? And what the strategy is to improve it? I guess, are you exiting more U.K. contracts
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess just to follow up, on your international business where the profitability has really struggled. Can you give us an update on what's going on there? And what the strategy is to improve it? I guess, are you exiting more U.K. contracts? Any update on the cost situation in Brazil? Whatever you're thinking is a relevant update.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gary. On the international, we discussed this previously, I think. What's driving some negative impact in these national markets certainly is the LatAm pricing pressures in our patient transport business, so let me address those separately. On the p
componenttext: Sure, Gary. On the international, we discussed this previously, I think. What's driving some negative impact in these national markets certainly is the LatAm pricing pressures in our patient transport business, so let me address those separately. On the patient transport business, we continue to exit certain contracts. Once we do that, we'll evaluate the strategic value of this business. We anticipate exiting or contracts ending in 2017. So the 2017 revenue for patient transport will be roughly USD 50 million to USD 60 million. And then on the LatAm, certainly, we're facing inflation and pricing pressure on our large government contracts, and we are looking at this on a contract-by-contract basis. So if you just take our sequential Q2 to Q3, we saw a modest increase on the EBITA line [ph].  So we made a little of progress, but there's more work to be done. Right now, the focus is on Latin America and the patient transport business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one last one for me. Both Charlie and Dan, I think, you both highlighted the strong cash flow of the business. Can you give us a sense how you're thinking about reinvesting that cash flow going forward? And is it different from how we though
componenttext: And then just one last one for me. Both Charlie and Dan, I think, you both highlighted the strong cash flow of the business. Can you give us a sense how you're thinking about reinvesting that cash flow going forward? And is it different from how we thought about the last few years? I mean, if that's really the key asset and you're not forecasting much growth, how are you going to be reinvesting in 2017 [ph] to bring back growth longer term?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, definitely we're pleased with the record-collection quarter and record free cash flow for the quarter. [indiscernible] capital allocation strategy remains similar that in has in the past where we will shift buckets from quarter-to-quarter depending o
componenttext: Yes, definitely we're pleased with the record-collection quarter and record free cash flow for the quarter. [indiscernible] capital allocation strategy remains similar that in has in the past where we will shift buckets from quarter-to-quarter depending on the cash flow and the opportunity that exists. And that will remain to be acquisitions, a top priority of ours. Certainly, following our largest acquisition in the company history and the debt level that we're at, we're going to be proactive in reducing debt when appropriate. And certainly, we remain opportunistic taking advantage of many a quarter where we have made U.S. acquisitions, we'll be opportunistic in purchasing the mandatory preferred convertible. An appropriate balance is necessary at this point in time while we both utilize the cash to grow the business as well as be able to pay down debt.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I'm going to have Dan answer your first [indiscernible], Al, because you're [indiscernible] '16 headwinds, it's not $30 million to $40 million in '16 and that's what I'll let Dan answer that for you. I'll make a comment on where we are on the renewal process on that.

componenttext: On the last call, we expected $10 million to $15 million of pricing headwinds in the second half of the year. We're certainly within that range, I would anticipate maybe on the higher end of that range. With expectation that you would be plus or minus $40 million in 2017.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as far as the contract renewals, obviously, this is something that's come up this year. So this is something new facing us. So I think it's certainly something that will be with us through '17. And then we're making investments to be proactive to the
componenttext: And as far as the contract renewals, obviously, this is something that's come up this year. So this is something new facing us. So I think it's certainly something that will be with us through '17. And then we're making investments to be proactive to the question we answered earlier, it's just too early to tell what kind of impact that will have. Obviously, we don't want this to be something that lasts 3 to 5 years which is our normal contract renewals at all of our agreements. So we're making those investments to shorten that time period. And that time horizon is just a little bit too early to tell you at this point when we think this headwind goes away.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: So I'm going to come back to this SQ issue. If I understand it correctly, it's about $750 million is what's defined as SQ. Have you gotten a sense in your own mind how much of that $750 million before you offset with the new salesforce cross-selling and then things of those initiatives, how big you think that total price compression is going to be?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think it's changed from what we talked about in the last call. We said that about -- of that $700 million to $750 million of SQ revenue, about 18% to 20% of that is SQ that is hospital affiliated. So it's owned by a hospital, affiliated with
componenttext: Yes, I don't think it's changed from what we talked about in the last call. We said that about -- of that $700 million to $750 million of SQ revenue, about 18% to 20% of that is SQ that is hospital affiliated. So it's owned by a hospital, affiliated with a hospital. We're seeing obviously more pricing pressure there, up to 30% to 35%, as they bid out multiple locations. So we're aggressive in trying to renew that. We want to keep that route density. And then we're seeing general pricing as we have national account, as we've talked about, Michael, in that 7 70 -- $700 million to $750 million of that, roughly 25% to 30% are national account. There's been no change in that business. Obviously, there's preferential pricing in there with contract, good contract [indiscernible] and fees. So that really does not impact revenue rate renewal a [ph] year on our national account. And then the remainder will be all of the SQ that are not affiliated with any large groups or hospitals or national accounts. And we're seeing general pricing pressure, we talked about a 10% to 15% on that. So I think we've bucketed really well, Michael. I think we understand. And listen, we're not trying to get away from SQ, right? We've got 20% of our SQ customers that are owned by LQ. So they are not truly SQ, because they are independently making decisions. But I think we have a good handle on the SQ business and the different buckets. And then to Brent's point, we'll use data analytics that help us get through how we should look at pricing. Maybe we don't have the discount as much as proactive. May be we throw in additional services and we can work through that. But obviously, we're going to make some investments to make smart decisions on that SQ business for us.

componenttext: I just want to make sure I heard the numbers correct. So out of $750 million, approximately 20% is owned by LQ, 25% is national, all the rest -- is the rest of SQ that has some pricing pressure. So the 20% that's LQ, has got 30%, 35% national and all the rest is 10% to 15%.

componenttext: Going back to gross margins for a moment. Third quarter was flat sequentially despite the pricing pressures. I know Brent said it was still early for the benefits from some of the new sealed investments. can you talk about what did help you offset those drags in the quarter?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. I will take you through the quarter-to-quarter gross margin bridge. Q2 was $42.8 million. We had the anticipated pricing pressures in the LQ business as well as the temporary impact from exit of patient transportation contracts. Those com
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. I will take you through the quarter-to-quarter gross margin bridge. Q2 was $42.8 million. We had the anticipated pricing pressures in the LQ business as well as the temporary impact from exit of patient transportation contracts. Those combined were about 54 basis points of headwinds. However, we were favorably and directly offset by improvements in gross margins from foreign exchange, increased paper prices and we saw higher recall revenues, those combined were about 35 basis points and by improvements in all of other lines of revenues that provided an additional 19 basis points of gross margins. So to the puts and takes directly offset each other in the quarter.

componenttext: I'll take the couple of questions. You're right, we had a solid quarter for recall. It was $26.9 million. But it actually declined year-over-year, [indiscernible] by about 11.2%. That's just the U.S. number. So when you look at the communication and related services decline sequentially year-over-year, it's most of it is due to worldwide recalls were actually lower this Q3 than they were last Q3. As far as we did, we did raise guidance though for 2016. We raised it to $95 million to $105 million. That's [indiscernible] because we saw a lot of activity towards the end of the quarter and it continued into Q4. So we thought it was best to raise guidance for 2016. Related to your question about guidance for 2017 in that communication related service line of $340 million to $370 million, that has roughly $90 million to $120 million in recall revenue guidance in that number.
