componenttext: Got it, got it. Thanks. And then switching gears, in the 2017 guidance, you mentioned $0.19 -- I didn't get it down well in my notes. But it seems like some sort of investment spending which sounded bigger than what you would've told us last quarter, offset by about $0.17 of purchasing the convert preferred. So could you elaborate on one, what those investments were a little more specifically? And then just a little color around the repurchase may be in the third quarter of the convert preferred and what the $0.17 represents next year? Thanks.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. So just to be clear, we did -- none of this was from last quarter on the call. This is all new guidance for 2017. And but we did talk about a $0.19 in total recall corporate expenses. And that's made up of really 2 buckets, it's performanc
componenttext: Yes, thank you. So just to be clear, we did -- none of this was from last quarter on the call. This is all new guidance for 2017. And but we did talk about a $0.19 in total recall corporate expenses. And that's made up of really 2 buckets, it's performance compensation, which is roughly about half of that and this is primarily related to cash flow and this is tied to specific performance goals. This performance compensation was only partially accrued for in 2016 results. And as our practice has been to accrue appropriate levels throughout the year based on real-time [ph] performance. And this is our initial guidance in 2017. We historically included a full performance compensation in our guidance towards -- to reflect all expectation of not only achieving but exceeding our goals. The other half of that is really in SG&A investments for growth. And these would be in things such as IT to enhance our operational and financial systems as well as continued investments to support growth. Throughout the course of the year, we'll evaluate these projects and we'll adjust and release these funds where best appropriate. To your other question Scott, was really about the $0.17 is purchasing the mandatory preferred convertible. What we've looked at and what we're purchasing that over the [indiscernible] is really the best use of cash being that only gives us the best ability to reduce dilution by being able to buy more shares. But it also offsets the 5.25% dividend rather than hang down 2% interest. We were very successful in doing that in Q3 in the -- you would see that we purchased about $0.07 of that. And so we really built that into our guidance going into next year and even into Q4, we'll do a marginal amount. That's a conservative guidance for next year because it really has to be a balance and how we're using our revolver cash flow.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: It would be $0.08 year-to-date, we did purchase $0.01 out of it in Q2. We did $0.07 in Q3, and our guidance really for next quarter would be anywhere from $0.02 to $0.03 and we could be opportunistic depending on how the quarter shapes up from all avenues of our capital allocation strategy.

componenttextpreview: Historically, you've indicated that more than half of your organic growth comes from cross-selling services. Could you outline your expectations for volume, price and cross-selling that gets you to that 0% to 3% next year?
componenttext: Historically, you've indicated that more than half of your organic growth comes from cross-selling services. Could you outline your expectations for volume, price and cross-selling that gets you to that 0% to 3% next year?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you look at, David, now, given the pricing pressure that we face, especially on our SQ business, looking at them on a historical context of SQ, LQ, we'd estimate that about 20% of our growth will come from price and volume and about 80% fr
componenttext: Yes, I think if you look at, David, now, given the pricing pressure that we face, especially on our SQ business, looking at them on a historical context of SQ, LQ, we'd estimate that about 20% of our growth will come from price and volume and about 80% from additional services. And really, we have seen no change on the LQ side of the business. So roughly 10% to 20% price and volume and the rest of the growth from additional services. So you see that has changed a little bit on the SQ profile given the pricing pressure.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the delta between your historical overall organic growth of 7% to 8% and the 0% to 3% is entirely price?
componenttext: So the delta between your historical overall organic growth of 7% to 8% and the 0% to 3% is entirely price?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I'll take you through each service line. But if you look at, going forward into next year, when you look at it purely from a revenue standpoint, as Dan said, we're down about $40 million in price concessions and it doesn't offset the growth of the bus
componenttext: No. I'll take you through each service line. But if you look at, going forward into next year, when you look at it purely from a revenue standpoint, as Dan said, we're down about $40 million in price concessions and it doesn't offset the growth of the business. There's other things we're doing with synergies and other opportunities. But we basically -- I think it's $40 million in price because it goes right to the bottom line, about $100 million to $110 million in revenue, that has to flow through. So flow-through, obviously, I think Dan, what is the EBITDA flow-through on that?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I think it would be mid to high $20 million.

componenttext: So about $25 million to $30 million. So we're certainly getting revenue from that. And then you have the impact of M&I year-over-year being flat and then obviously, exiting the PCS contracts which creates additional headwinds for the total business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay, and then finally, as you're looking at ways to target new customers and invest in getting renewals and things of that nature, are you willing to take new business or get renewals that have lower revenue and margin than you have historically to sort of recharge the growth from here forward?

componenttext: David, this is Brent. I would say absolutely. Obviously, we look at all new business carefully. But given our infrastructure, our footprint, we oftentimes can bring on new business lower than other people, given we have the biggest infrastructure and [indiscernible] density ever. So yes, we're not walking away from any new opportunities plus we have the ability to upsell once we get it, which increases the profitability. So no, I would say we're very aggressive in going after new business and new sites.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: That's Barbara Noverini. So internal LQ growth came in flat year-over-year which is also much lower than typical. Can you comment in what you've been seeing on the LQ side? And what gives you confidence that pricing pressure would accelerate in that customer category as well?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question on the LQ. In the LQ, really, Barb, it's been driven M&I, a lot M&I work. Remember, again, you take a step back, SQ and LQ is not just our medical waste services, it describes our total business in the US. So when you see the decline in
componenttext: Yes, good question on the LQ. In the LQ, really, Barb, it's been driven M&I, a lot M&I work. Remember, again, you take a step back, SQ and LQ is not just our medical waste services, it describes our total business in the US. So when you see the decline in M&I, like we faced, most of that M&I were falling into the LQ bucket. So when you look at LQ, where it was just less than 1% last quarter and flat to down a little bit this quarter, they're the one taking the brunt of the M&I hit. As far as pricing pressure in the LQ side of the business, we're doing great on the LQ side of the business. We, obviously, just look at our medical waste services, Brent touched on it early on. We had really large installations in both sharps and pharmaceuticals, waste installation from really large health care centers. The team is really doing a good job there. We've hit the ground running with respect to secure information disposal. So certainly, it's always been a category with respect to price that's why the margin has always been lower than our SQ business. I don't see any changes at all. I think, it will always be price sensitive. But we've done a really, really good job on our traditional hospital LQ business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, got it. That's actually helpful distinction. So if you were -- I know you're trying to walk away from the categorization. But if you were to disaggregate that M&I impact, would you say that LQ hospital category performed as typical in that sort of
componenttext: Got it, got it. That's actually helpful distinction. So if you were -- I know you're trying to walk away from the categorization. But if you were to disaggregate that M&I impact, would you say that LQ hospital category performed as typical in that sort of low to mid-single digit organic growth range that you've had in the past?

componenttext: It did. It was roughly 4% or 3% to 5%. So -- and we usually get a benefit of other things coming in on LQ that always would make it that 5% to 8%. But certainly, that was not there because the headwinds in M&I.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had a question on trying to understand the 10% to 15% price declines and half of the SQ customer base. Is it just systematic that the hospital affiliated accounts I understand the price declines there. But how is it spreading to the SQ -- the rest of
componenttext: Just had a question on trying to understand the 10% to 15% price declines and half of the SQ customer base. Is it just systematic that the hospital affiliated accounts I understand the price declines there. But how is it spreading to the SQ -- the rest of the SQ customer base? Is that just your estimate? Is it a bottoms-up analysis? Or is the business incrementally more competitive? I'm just trying to understand that piece.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, it's always been a competitive market, the SQ local market. So I don't think there's been any changes there. I think the one thing that's changed and you see it in the press, you see it all over that, health care is faced with reimbursement
componenttext: Yes, I think, it's always been a competitive market, the SQ local market. So I don't think there's been any changes there. I think the one thing that's changed and you see it in the press, you see it all over that, health care is faced with reimbursement cuts. So they're getting less fees for their service. And now for the [indiscernible], I think they're looking at it any way they can save even a little money. So where our contract has I think, fell over the radar, we are getting more attention there and that's why we're seeing the discounting in that marketplace. I think it's -- the competition though, I will tell you, from a market by market, I will tell you, hasn't changed much in the last couple of years.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just a follow up for Dan. The op margin -- trying to understand the op margin guidance at the midpoint. Are you guiding flat op margins for '17 at the EPS pinpoint? Is that the right way to think about sort of operating margins? Just tryi
componenttext: Got it. And then just a follow up for Dan. The op margin -- trying to understand the op margin guidance at the midpoint. Are you guiding flat op margins for '17 at the EPS pinpoint? Is that the right way to think about sort of operating margins? Just trying to -- the reason of ask is I'm trying to understand what the offsets on the margin side are due to the $40 million pricing pressure you're going to see next year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean if I were thinking about operating margins for 2017, I will be in the mid-$21 million range. So it is really flat to this year. Certainly, there are a number of puts and takes. And I think as Charlie, Brent, myself, we've seen some of them. Ce
componenttext: Yes, I mean if I were thinking about operating margins for 2017, I will be in the mid-$21 million range. So it is really flat to this year. Certainly, there are a number of puts and takes. And I think as Charlie, Brent, myself, we've seen some of them. Certainly, the synergies that will be only partially offsetting the price concessions we'll have next year. So -- and then the growth that doesn't come through at the same percent, that pricing goes out. So you're going to see a little bit of pricing there, probability headwind. We're also going to be experiencing some FX exiting our patient contracts. That can temporarily affect margins until you're fully out of that. And then we're going to make investments in the business. And that's important as we do that from [indiscernible] Brent talked about in those investments, we know we bring return over the long term. But initially in the beginning of the year, investment will be early investments to set that infrastructure in the stage should be able to grow the business. So that's going to be some of the headwinds.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: It's actually Joel in for Isaac. Maybe back to the consolidation theme from a slightly different angle, can you talk about how you're thinking about the potential for increased decision fees may be on the route density side, just given your consolidated customer base?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joel. So I think certainly, route density, Brent mentioned it before, we want to be able to be in the low-cost provider, low expense provider in the marketplace. So we've utilized better technology over the last few years. The team continues to make
componenttext: Yes, Joel. So I think certainly, route density, Brent mentioned it before, we want to be able to be in the low-cost provider, low expense provider in the marketplace. So we've utilized better technology over the last few years. The team continues to make strides in that area. The focus now it really is on secure information destruction side of the business to get that same level of service, high level of service with the best route density that you can get. So -- and is one of the reasons I think the strategy and Brent answered before, will be -- would we be billing to renew customers at a lower rate? Yes, because we don't want to lose that competitive advantage that we have in the marketplace which is route density. So it does play into it, certainly. Hopefully, that answers your question.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joel, this is Brent. Just wanted you to think about a lot of times when these SQs are being rolled up into an integrated delivery network, their [indiscernible] often times don't even change, right? It's just the name or the sign of the building changes.
componenttext: Joel, this is Brent. Just wanted you to think about a lot of times when these SQs are being rolled up into an integrated delivery network, their [indiscernible] often times don't even change, right? It's just the name or the sign of the building changes. So not all the time does that provide us kind of more centralized spot to pick it up. We oftentimes are still covering the same footprint that we were before.

componenttext: Great. Thanks. And then maybe to Haz. Can you help us out the margin profile of the energy sort of project-based work or just the general M&I? Just trying to understand the impact of profitability if we happen to see a resurgence in demand in either of those markets?

componenttext: We still haven't broken out M&I in its own kind of service line and profitability at this point, Joel. Certainly, that includes the whole portfolio. So that health care adds, retail adds, and M&I. M&I does have a lower profitability, M&I and Project has a lower profitability than retail and health care has would have.

componenttext: We did not. We're not going to be hitting SQ, LQ, be broken up by service line. Regulated waste and compliance will be $2.04 billion to $2.09 billion. componenttext: Yes, we continue to look at this market by market. We have success recently in Western Europe, Spain and Portugal as we've coupled it with the Dosimetry services. componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Amanda, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Sean McMillan, Vice President of Corporate Finance, you may begin your conference.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle's Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, g
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle's Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. 
This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. Our actual results could differ significantly from the results described in the forward-looking statements. 
Factors that could cause such differences include: changes in governmental regulation of the collection, transportation, treatment and disposal of regulated waste or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing regulated waste collection and treatment or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; our obligation to service our substantial indebtedness and to comply with the covenants and restrictions contained in our private placement notes, term loan credit facility and revolving credit facility; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; competition and demand for services in the regulated waste and Secure Information Destruction industries; political, economic and currency risks that's related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other indefinite lived intangibles; variability in the demand for services we provide on a project or nonrecurring basis; exposure to environmental liabilities; fluctuations in the price we receive for the sale of paper; disruptions in or attacks on our information technology systems; compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements; as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-Ka. As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance and investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. 
We make no commitment to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn it over to  Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sean. Good afternoon, everybody, thank you for joining us on today's call. We were able to maintain consistent margin performance in the quarter despite revenue headwinds from previously discussed pricing pressure and softness in the manufactur
componenttext:
Thank you, Sean. Good afternoon, everybody, thank you for joining us on today's call. We were able to maintain consistent margin performance in the quarter despite revenue headwinds from previously discussed pricing pressure and softness in the manufacturing and industrial market. Our EPS exceeded expectations, in part driven by the use of our record free cash flow to accelerate our stock repurchase of mandatory preferred convertible shares. 
Joining me on today's call to discuss our Q3 results and 2017 preliminary guidance will be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and Brent Arnold, COO. I will now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Charlie. The results for the third quarter are as follows: Global revenues were $890.1 million, up 23.9% from $718.6 million in Q3 2015; an internal growth excluding the impact of foreign exchange, acquisitions and manufacturing and industrial ser
componenttext:
Thanks, Charlie. The results for the third quarter are as follows: Global revenues were $890.1 million, up 23.9% from $718.6 million in Q3 2015; an internal growth excluding the impact of foreign exchange, acquisitions and manufacturing and industrial services was up 1.6%; domestic revenues were $664.1 million; excluding the impact of acquisitions and manufacturing and industrial revenues, internal growth was 1.6%. 
For consistency of your models, we're providing the following for the remainder of the year. Domestic revenues were $664.1 million, of which $637.1 million was regulated waste and compliant services revenues and $26.9 million was recall and returns. Domestic internal growth, excluding recalls and returns revenues, was up 1%, consisting of SQ up 1% and LQ flat. As anticipated, growth rates were impacted by SQ pricing pressure, lower hazardous waste volumes from our industrial customers and lower fuel surcharges. 
International revenues were $226.1 million or 3% internal growth when adjusted for foreign exchange impact. As anticipated, international growth rates were impacted by the exiting of certain patient transportation contracts. Acquisitions contributed $184.7 million to growth in the quarter. Gross profits were $381 million or 42.8% of revenues. SG&A expense, excluding amortization was $189.3 million or 21.3% of revenues. Adjusted income from operations or EBITA was $191.7 million or 21.5% of revenues. Net interest expense was $24.7 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $61.5 million or $0.72 per share on an as-reported basis and $1.24 when adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjustments. 
Now for the balance sheet. Our debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 3.35 at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $607 million. In the quarter, we repurchased 265,000 shares of the mandatory preferred convertible on the open market in the amount of $19.2 million. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 3.1 million shares. Our CapEx was $33.8 million or 3.8% of revenues. Our DSO was 65 days. Year-to-date, as-reported, cash from operations was $417.8 million. And when adjusted for recall reimbursement and other items, cash from operations was $467.6 million. 
I will now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. In the quarter, we closed 5 tuck-in acquisitions, all domestic. Revenues from the 5 acquisitions were approximately $0.4 million in the quarter and annualized for approximately $4 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with we
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. In the quarter, we closed 5 tuck-in acquisitions, all domestic. Revenues from the 5 acquisitions were approximately $0.4 million in the quarter and annualized for approximately $4 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 million annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business. 
The SQ pricing pressure discussed previously continued in the quarter and will remain for the foreseeable future. To address these pressures, we are making incremental strategic investments in sales, marketing and data analytics. These investments will enable us to pinpoint and execute on opportunities to grow our business and improve our overall performance. 
Despite the SQ headwinds, we are able to maintain our operating margin profile as well as deliver positive revenue growth in other services. For example, in our hospital customer base, we successfully completed several large Sharps Management and pharmaceutical compliance installation. We saw strong growth in retail waste services, driven by our high level of service and detailed reporting capability. The combination of our customer relationships and our multiple compliance solutions provides a strong foundation for future growth. 
In the Secure Information Destruction Service, we continued to see strong sales resulting from the conversion of unbended customers to ongoing service. In addition, the national accounts team continues to make progress, securing new large customers. 
Our synergies remain on track with recent progress in streamlining back-office processes and implementing new technology to optimize our inside sales and customer service. 
In closing, we would like to thank all of our worldwide team members for their continued commitment to our customers, our shareholders and our core values. 
I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016 and preliminary guidance for 2017. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, in
componenttext:
Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016 and preliminary guidance for 2017. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration and acquisition-related expenses and other adjusted items. 
As a reminder, our 2016 EPS guidance is adjusted for amortization expense. For 2016, we believe EPS will be in the range of $4.74 to $4.76. This includes the benefit of our ongoing strategy for repurchase of mandatory preferred convertible shares. 
We expect revenue for 2016 will be in the range of $3.56 billion to $3.58 billion, depending on assumptions for growth and the impact of foreign exchange rates. 
Internal growth rates are expected to be: SQ, 3% to 5%; LQ, 2% to 3%; international, 4% to 5%; and recall and returns revenue between $95 million and $105 million. We have estimates for free cash flow in 2016 between $450 million and $470 million. 2016 CapEx is anticipated to be between $130 million to $135 million. We expect that 2016 full year as-reported tax rate to be approximately 36%. 
Now I'd like to provide preliminary guidance for 2017. For 2017, we believe EPS estimates will be in the range of $4.57 to $4.77, using a share count of approximately 91.1 million. This includes the unfavorable impact of approximately $0.19 from the normalization of performance compensation and additional SG&A investments to drive future growth and profitability. This is partially offset by approximately $0.17 of benefit from ongoing strategy to repurchase the mandatory preferred convertible shares. 
We believe revenues for 2017 will be in the range of $3.54 billion to $3.67 billion, depending on assumptions of foreign exchange and internal rates of flat to 3%. The worldwide revenue guidance for each of our service lines is as follows: regulated waste and compliant services will be in the range of $2.03 billion to $2.09 billion; Secure Information Destruction Services will be in the range of $780 million to $810 million; communications and related services will be in the range of $340 million to $370 million, depending on recall revenues; and manufacturing and industrial services will be in the range of $380 million to $400 million. 
We have estimates for free cash flow in 2017 between $450 million to $470 million. 2017 CapEx is anticipated to be between $125 million to $150 million. We expect the 2017 full year as-reported tax rate to be approximately 36.5%. 
Stericycle continues to be the market leader in multiple services and geographies. We have a strong team and an unmatched infrastructure. We are confident in the long-term outlook of our business. 
As a reminder, Stericycle will be hosting its first Investor Day and webcast on the morning of Thursday, November 10, to share perspectives on Stericycle's strategies, capabilities and plans to drive long-term shareholder value. More details are posted on the Events page of our Investor Relations website. We encourage investors, analysts and the public to join the live webcast or watch the meeting replay. 
Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. Amanda, you can open the Q&A.

componenttext: And Ryan, the second part of your question, as far as a good view on that, we have long-term contracts that's spread out over 3 to 5 years. componenttext: Yes. As you know, we first started seeing, especially the hospital consolidation impact on our business earlier this year, we spoke about on the last call. I will tell you that Q3 came in as expected, meaning the pressure that we expected in Q3 came in, in line with our expectations.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then final question and I'll hop off. Also on pricing, have you given any thought to maybe going back to your customers even prior to renewal? I would think that the renewal time, that's when they maybe look at the market, look at websites, see who else is out there. So any thought about going back earlier and trying to re-extend contracts even if it -- it brings some of that pricing pressure forward? Or you're just going to let this play out over time?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. Absolutely, Ryan. I think, part of the investment we're making in SG&A both in resources and the data analytics that Brent mentioned in his opening, certainly is the strategy that we want to be proactive in the renewals and that is part of our own
componenttext: No, no. Absolutely, Ryan. I think, part of the investment we're making in SG&A both in resources and the data analytics that Brent mentioned in his opening, certainly is the strategy that we want to be proactive in the renewals and that is part of our own ongoing strategy. So it's a little early to tell the impact, but certainly, that is part of the strategy. Thanks, Ryan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Steinke from Barrington Research.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So following up on that question about being proactive on renewals. I think you've also discussed, as part of your investment, looking to cross sell more services to the SQ accounts that are seeing the pricing pressure. And I'm wondering if you're trying
componenttext: So following up on that question about being proactive on renewals. I think you've also discussed, as part of your investment, looking to cross sell more services to the SQ accounts that are seeing the pricing pressure. And I'm wondering if you're trying to make that more part of your renewal discussions. And if you think that can have any offsetting impact on the pricing pressure you're experiencing?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kevin, this is Brent. As we talked about on our last call, we were making a number of investments, both marketing and sales to try to offset some of these headwinds that we're seeing. A part of it, you remember correctly, right, we've got more sales
componenttext: Yes, Kevin, this is Brent. As we talked about on our last call, we were making a number of investments, both marketing and sales to try to offset some of these headwinds that we're seeing. A part of it, you remember correctly, right, we've got more sales reps that have been hired, and we're working to have them -- have a bigger impact with regard to influencing that renewal, emphasizing the value of our Series A services and overall, try to approach that situation proactively. Obviously, it's too early to see any returns on that. But that is definitely one of our strategies as well as trying to grow new sites in SQ was another strategy to -- but won't offset that headwind, it will drive new growth that, in turn, will help us offset that in the long term. So you're correct, those are some of the things that we're doing. It's just a little too early right now to see if that's having an effect.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I think you also talked about on your last call about maybe digging more into the manufacturing and industrial business and analyzing it over the next several quarters about long-term fit, at least for parts of that business. So I'm just wonderi
componenttext: Okay. And I think you also talked about on your last call about maybe digging more into the manufacturing and industrial business and analyzing it over the next several quarters about long-term fit, at least for parts of that business. So I'm just wondering if you've started on that analysis and any initial thoughts on that work you're doing there.

componenttextpreview: Sure, Kevin. We continue to evaluate multiple businesses, not just the M&I business, for their long-term strategic fit in our portfolio of services. We have not made any definitive decision yet on M&I or any assets within Stericycle.
componenttext: Sure, Kevin. We continue to evaluate multiple businesses, not just the M&I business, for their long-term strategic fit in our portfolio of services. We have not made any definitive decision yet on M&I or any assets within Stericycle.

componenttextpreview: I guess, the first question I'd ask is on Shred-it. Just diving into the guidance and how we think about profitability. Can you give us a sense what you're expecting for synergies and profit growth at Shred-it? Or are we getting back to how you thought ab
componenttext: I guess, the first question I'd ask is on Shred-it. Just diving into the guidance and how we think about profitability. Can you give us a sense what you're expecting for synergies and profit growth at Shred-it? Or are we getting back to how you thought about the initial margin ramp at the time of acquisition? I know that was pushed out. Or should we think that, that continues to be somewhat lower? And I guess I'm trying to understand, is that a big factor that offsets pricing or -- that you've talked about in SQ? Or how do we think about Shred-it?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Gary. I'll touch a little bit on what we have as far as synergies built in. And it will be what we shared all along. The $20 million of synergies that we deferred from 2016, we fully anticipate that we're going to be able to capture throughou
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Gary. I'll touch a little bit on what we have as far as synergies built in. And it will be what we shared all along. The $20 million of synergies that we deferred from 2016, we fully anticipate that we're going to be able to capture throughout 2017, which will certainly contribute to the profitability growth. And we've already began to join from the -- let's say, in the last years since we've owned Shred-it. And so, I think, Brent can probably talk to you about some of the steps that were taken to achieve the numbers that we have in the guidance.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And these are -- hey, Gary, this is Brent. No new activities here, but just continue to focus on integration activities associated with the re-routes, switching from on-site to off-site, continuing to look at back-office processes. The team actually had a
componenttext: And these are -- hey, Gary, this is Brent. No new activities here, but just continue to focus on integration activities associated with the re-routes, switching from on-site to off-site, continuing to look at back-office processes. The team actually had a really busy quarter this quarter as we looked to automate and integrate all of our customer service. So we put them all on a national platform. We're in the process of doing that. This quarter, we're doing the same thing with inside sales. We also have kicked off automation for several of our back-office processes, around collection, cash applications as well as AP. So a lot of those things will contribute to continue to drive cost out of the business to help us hit those synergies.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess just to follow up, on your international business where the profitability has really struggled. Can you give us an update on what's going on there? And what the strategy is to improve it? I guess, are you exiting more U.K. contracts
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess just to follow up, on your international business where the profitability has really struggled. Can you give us an update on what's going on there? And what the strategy is to improve it? I guess, are you exiting more U.K. contracts? Any update on the cost situation in Brazil? Whatever you're thinking is a relevant update.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gary. On the international, I mean, we discussed this previously, I think. What's driving some negative impact in these national markets certainly is the LatAm pricing pressures in our patient transport business, so let me address those separately.
componenttext: Sure, Gary. On the international, I mean, we discussed this previously, I think. What's driving some negative impact in these national markets certainly is the LatAm pricing pressures in our patient transport business, so let me address those separately. On the patient transport business, we continue to exit certain contracts. Once we do that, we'll evaluate the strategic value of this business. We anticipate exiting or contracts ending in 2017. So the 2017 revenue for patient transport will be roughly USD 50 million to USD 60 million. And then on the LatAm, certainly, we're facing inflation and pricing pressure on our large government contracts, and we're looking at this on a contract-by-contract basis. So if you just take our sequential Q2 to Q3, we saw a modest increase on the EBITDA line -- EBITA line. So we've made a little progress, but there's more work to be done. Right now, the focus is on Latin America and the patient transport business.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one last one from me. Both Charlie and Dan, I think, you both highlighted the strong cash flow of the business. Can you give us a sense how you're thinking about reinvesting that cash flow going forward? And is it different from how we thoug
componenttext: And then just one last one from me. Both Charlie and Dan, I think, you both highlighted the strong cash flow of the business. Can you give us a sense how you're thinking about reinvesting that cash flow going forward? And is it different from how we thought about the last few years? I mean, if that's really the key asset and you're not forecasting much growth, how are you going to be reinvesting in 27 (sic) [ 2017 ] to bring back growth longer term?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, definitely we're pleased with the record-collection quarter and record free cash flow for the quarter. Well, Gary, capital allocation strategy remains similar that it has in the past while we will shift buckets from quarter-to-quarter, depending on t
componenttext: Yes, definitely we're pleased with the record-collection quarter and record free cash flow for the quarter. Well, Gary, capital allocation strategy remains similar that it has in the past while we will shift buckets from quarter-to-quarter, depending on the cash flow and the opportunity that exists. And that will remain to be acquisitions are a top priority of ours. Certainly, following our largest acquisition in company history and the debt level that we're at, we're going to be proactive in reducing debt when appropriate. And certainly, we remain opportunistic, taking advantage of maybe a quarter where we're -- we have maybe less acquisitions, we'll be opportunistic in purchasing the mandatory preferred convertible. An appropriate balance is necessary at this point in time while we both utilize the cash to grow the business as well as be able to pay down debt.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

Said differently, if you look at the SQ business, are you at a spot where the resets that you would expect on a new competitive environment were 40% to 50% the way through? Or do we have a few more years to go through that?

componenttext: Yes, I'm going to have Dan answer your first, Al, because you're [indiscernible] '16 headwinds, it's not $30 million or $40 million in '16, and that's not what [indiscernible]. I'll let Dan levels [ph] that for you. I'll make a comment on where we are on the renewal process on that.

componenttext: Al, on the last call, we expected $10 million to $15 million of pricing headwinds in the second half of the year. We're certainly within that range, I would anticipate maybe on the higher end of that range, with expectation that you would be plus or minus $40 million in 2017.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as far as the contract renewals, we -- obviously, this is something that's come up this year. So this is something new facing us. So I think it's certainly something that will be with us through '17. And then we're making investments to be proactive t
componenttext: And as far as the contract renewals, we -- obviously, this is something that's come up this year. So this is something new facing us. So I think it's certainly something that will be with us through '17. And then we're making investments to be proactive to the question we answered earlier, it's just too early to tell what kind of impact that will have. Obviously, we don't want this to be something that will lasts 3 to 5 years, which is our normal contract renewals of all of our agreements. So we're making those investments to shorten that time period. And that time horizon is just a little bit too early to tell you at this point when we think this headwind goes away.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Hoffman from Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Hoffman from Stifel.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm going to come back to this SQ issue. If I understand it correctly, it's about $750 million is what's defined as SQ. Have you gotten a sense in your own mind how much of that $750 million before you offset with the new sales force cross-selling and
componenttext: So I'm going to come back to this SQ issue. If I understand it correctly, it's about $750 million is what's defined as SQ. Have you gotten a sense in your own mind how much of that $750 million before you offset with the new sales force cross-selling and then things of those initiatives, how big you think that total price compression is going to be?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think it's changed from what we talked about in the last call. We said that about -- of that $700 million to $750 million of SQ revenue, about 18% to 20% of that is SQ that is hospital affiliated. So it's owned by a hospital, affiliated with
componenttext: Yes, I don't think it's changed from what we talked about in the last call. We said that about -- of that $700 million to $750 million of SQ revenue, about 18% to 20% of that is SQ that is hospital affiliated. So it's owned by a hospital, affiliated with a hospital. We're seeing obviously more pricing pressure there, up to 30%, 35%, as they bid out multiple locations. So we're aggressive in trying to renew that. We want to keep that route density. And then we're seeing general pricing. We have a national account, as we've talked about, Michael, in that 770 -- $700 million to $750 million of that, roughly 25%, 30% are national account. There's been no change in that business. Obviously, there's preferential pricing in there with contract, good contract [indiscernible] and fees. So that really does not impact and, in fact, revenue had great renewal year on our national account. And then the remainder will be all of the SQ that are not affiliated with any large groups or hospitals or national accounts. And we're seeing general pricing pressure, we talked about a 10% to 15% on that business. So I think we've bucketed really well, Michael. I think we understand. And listen, I thought we're trying to get away from SQ, LQ, right? Because we've got 20% of our SQ customers that are owned by LQ. So they are not truly SQ, because they're not independently making decisions. But I think we have a good handle on the SQ business and the different buckets. And then as to Brent's point, we'll use data analytics that help us get through how we should look at pricing. Maybe we don't have to discount as much if we're proactive. Maybe we throw in additional services and we can work through that. But obviously, we're going to make some investments to make smart decisions on that SQ business for us.

componenttext: Michael, I think, we're always going to be concerned about that. The upside would be if you look or read the index, sometimes it moves and stays above the 10-year average for a short period of time, and so we have bucketed a range our guidance in order to be able to account for those things.

componenttextpreview: Going back to gross margins for a moment. Third quarter was flat sequentially despite the pricing pressures. I know Brent said it was still early for the benefits from some of the new sales [ph] investments. Can you talk about what did help you offset tho
componenttext: Going back to gross margins for a moment. Third quarter was flat sequentially despite the pricing pressures. I know Brent said it was still early for the benefits from some of the new sales [ph] investments. Can you talk about what did help you offset those drags in the quarter?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. I will just take you through the quarter-to-quarter gross margin bridge. Q2 was 42.8. We had the anticipated pricing pressures in the SQ business as well as the temporary impact from exit of patient transportation contract. Those combined
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. I will just take you through the quarter-to-quarter gross margin bridge. Q2 was 42.8. We had the anticipated pricing pressures in the SQ business as well as the temporary impact from exit of patient transportation contract. Those combined were about 54 basis points of headwinds. However, we were favorably and directly offset by improvements in gross margins from foreign exchange, increased paper prices and we saw higher recall revenues, those combined were about 35 basis points and by improvements in all other lines of revenues that provided an additional 19 basis points of gross margins. So the puts and takes directly offset each other in the quarter.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

As you know, [indiscernible] both doing acquisitions. But after they have joined forces, they've slowed down. So we think there's a great pipeline there. It's just the timing in Q3. I wouldn't read anything into the 5 deals. I think a normal quarter for us is more like what's happened in Q2.

So if you could update on what the deceleration was and if you, in fact, seeing better in recall. And then the final part of this question is what is implicit in the recall guide for next year in comm solutions?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me take the other couple of questions in there. You're right, we had a solid quarter for recalls. It was $26.9 million. But it actually declined year-over-year, it's got by about 11.2%. That's just the U.S. number. So when you look at the commun
componenttext: Sure. Let me take the other couple of questions in there. You're right, we had a solid quarter for recalls. It was $26.9 million. But it actually declined year-over-year, it's got by about 11.2%. That's just the U.S. number. So when you look at the communication and related services decline sequentially year-over-year, it's most of it is due to worldwide recalls were actually lower this Q3 than they were last Q3. As far as we did, we did raise guidance, though. For 2016, we raised it to $95 million to $105 million. That's simply because we saw a lot of activity towards the end of the quarter and it continued into Q4. So we thought it was best to raise guidance for 2016. Related to your question about guidance for 2017 in that communication-related service line of $340 million to $370 million, that has roughly $90 million to $120 million in recall revenue guidance in that number.

componenttext: Got it, got it. And then switching gears, in the 2017 guidance, you mentioned $0.19 -- I didn't get it down well in my notes. But it seems like some sort of investment spending which sounded bigger than what you would have told us last quarter, offset by about $0.17 of purchasing the convert preferred. So could you elaborate on, one, what those investments were, a little more specifically? And then just a little color around the repurchase maybe in the third quarter of the convert preferred? And what the $0.17 represents next year?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. So just to be clear, we did -- none of this was from last quarter on the call. This is all new guidance for 2017. And what we did talk about a $0.19 and total recall [ph] corporate expenses, and that's made up of really 2 buckets: it's per
componenttext: Yes, thank you. So just to be clear, we did -- none of this was from last quarter on the call. This is all new guidance for 2017. And what we did talk about a $0.19 and total recall [ph] corporate expenses, and that's made up of really 2 buckets: it's performance compensation, which is roughly about half of that; and this is primarily related to cash flow and this is tied to specific performance goals. This performance compensation was only partially accrued for in 2016 results. And as our practice has been to accrue appropriate levels throughout the year based on real-time performance. And this is our initial guidance in 2017. We historically included a full-performance compensation in our guidance to reflect all expectation of not only achieving but exceeding our goals. The other half of that is really in SG&A investments for growth. And these would be in things such as IT to enhance our operational and financial systems as well as continued investments to support growth. Throughout the course of the year, we'll evaluate these projects and we'll adjust and release these funds where best appropriate. I think to your other question, Scott, was really about the $0.17 is purchasing the mandatory preferred convertible. What we've looked at and why we're purchasing that over the common is really the best use of cash being. That only gives us the best ability to reduce dilution by being able to buy more shares. But it also offsets 5.25% dividend rather than hang down 2% interest. We were very successful in doing that in Q3 in the -- you would see that we purchased about $0.07 of that. And so we really built that into our guidance going into next year. And even into Q4, we'll do a marginal amount. It's a conservative guidance for next year because it really has to be a balance of how we're going to utilize all of our cash flow.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And just to clarify, sorry, [indiscernible] it's $0.07 year-to-date or $0.07 in the third quarter of this year?
componenttext: All right. And just to clarify, sorry, [indiscernible] it's $0.07 year-to-date or $0.07 in the third quarter of this year?

componenttext: It would be $0.08 year-to-date, we did purchase $0.01 of it in Q2. We did $0.07 in Q3, and our guidance really for next quarter would be anywhere from $0.02 to $0.03, and we could be opportunistic depending on how the quarter shapes up from all avenues of our capital allocation strategy.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Historically, you've indicated that more than half of your organic growth comes from cross-selling services. Could you outline your expectations for volume, price and cross-selling that gets you to that 0% to 3% next year?
componenttext: Historically, you've indicated that more than half of your organic growth comes from cross-selling services. Could you outline your expectations for volume, price and cross-selling that gets you to that 0% to 3% next year?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you look at, David, now, given the pricing pressure that we face, especially on our SQ business, looking at them on a historical context of SQ, LQ, we'd estimate that about 20% of our growth will come from price and volume and about 80% fr
componenttext: Yes, I think if you look at, David, now, given the pricing pressure that we face, especially on our SQ business, looking at them on a historical context of SQ, LQ, we'd estimate that about 20% of our growth will come from price and volume and about 80% from additional services. And really, we have seen no change on the LQ side of the business. So roughly 10% to 20% price and volume and the rest of the growth from additional services. So you see that has changed a little bit on the SQ profile given the pricing pressure.

componenttext: So the delta between your historical overall organic growth of 7% to 8% and the 0% to 3% is entirely price?

componenttext: No. I can take you through each service line. componenttext: So it's about $25 million to $30 million, but we are certainly getting revenue from that. And then you have the impact of M&I year-over-year being flat and then, obviously, exiting the PCS [ph] contracts which creates additional headwinds for the total business.

componenttext: Okay, and then finally, as you're looking at ways to target new customers and invest in getting renewals and things of that nature, are you willing to take new business or get renewals that have lower revenue and margin than you have historically to sort of recharge the growth from here forward?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Brent. I would say absolutely. Obviously, we look at all new business carefully. But given our infrastructure, our footprint, we oftentimes can bring on new business lower than other people, given we have the biggest infrastructure and rout
componenttext: David, this is Brent. I would say absolutely. Obviously, we look at all new business carefully. But given our infrastructure, our footprint, we oftentimes can bring on new business lower than other people, given we have the biggest infrastructure and route density everywhere. So yes, we're not walking away from any new opportunities, plus we have the ability to upsell once we get it, which increases the profitability. So no, I would say we're very aggressive in going after new business and new sites.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Barbara Noverini from Morningstar.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Barbara Noverini from Morningstar.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's Barb Noverini. So internal LQ growth came in flat year-over-year which is also much lower than typical. Can you comment in what you've been seeing on the LQ side? And what gives you confidence that pricing pressure won't accelerate on that customer
componenttext: That's Barb Noverini. So internal LQ growth came in flat year-over-year which is also much lower than typical. Can you comment in what you've been seeing on the LQ side? And what gives you confidence that pricing pressure won't accelerate on that customer category as well?

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so good question on the LQ. I mean, the LQ, really, Barb, it's been driven on the M&I, a lot M&I work. Remember, again, if you take a step back, SQ and LQ is not just our medical waste services, it describes our total business in the U.S. So when you
componenttext: Yes, so good question on the LQ. I mean, the LQ, really, Barb, it's been driven on the M&I, a lot M&I work. Remember, again, if you take a step back, SQ and LQ is not just our medical waste services, it describes our total business in the U.S. So when you see the decline in M&I, like we faced, most of that M&I were falling into the LQ bucket. So when you look at LQ, where it was just less than 1% last quarter and flat to down a little bit this quarter, they're the ones taking the brunt of the M&I hit. As far as pricing pressure in the LQ side of the business, we're doing great on the LQ side of the business. We, honestly, just look at our medical waste services, Brent touched on it early on. We had really large installations in both Sharps and pharmaceuticals waste installation from really large health care centers. The team is doing a really good job there. We've hit the ground running with respect to Secure Information disposal. So certainly, it's always been a category with respect to price that's why the margin has always been lower than our SQ business. I don't see any changes at all. I think, it will always be a price sensitive. But we've done a really, really good job on our traditional hospital LQ business.

componenttext: Just had a question on trying to understand the 10% to 15% price declines in half of the SQ customer base. Is it just systematic that the hospital-affiliated accounts, I understand, the price declines there. But how is it spreading to the SQ -- the rest of the SQ customer base? Is that just your estimate? Is it a bottoms-up analysis? Or is the business incrementally more competitive? I'm just trying to understand that piece.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Hamzah, it's always been a competitive market, the SQ local market. So I don't think there's been any changes in the dynamic there. I think the one thing that has changed and you see it in the press, you see it all over that, health care is
componenttext: Yes, I think, Hamzah, it's always been a competitive market, the SQ local market. So I don't think there's been any changes in the dynamic there. I think the one thing that has changed and you see it in the press, you see it all over that, health care is faced with reimbursement cuts. So they're getting less fees for their service. And now for the first time, I think they're looking at any way they can save even a little money. So where our contract, I think, fell over the radar, we were getting more attention there and that's why we're seeing the discounting in that marketplace. I think it's -- the competition, though, I will tell you, from a market by market, I will tell you, hasn't changed much in the last couple of years.

componenttext: Got it. And then just a follow up for Dan. The op margin -- trying to understand the op margin guidance at the midpoint. Are you guiding flat op margins for '17 at the EPS pinpoint? Is that the right way to think about sort of operating margins? Just trying to -- the reason I ask is I'm trying to understand what the offsets on the margin side are due to the $40 million pricing pressure you're going to see next year.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean if I were thinking about operating margins for 2017, I would be in the mid-$21 million range. So it is really flat to this year. Certainly, there are a number of puts and takes. And I think Charlie, Brent, myself, we've seen some of them. Cert
componenttext: Yes, I mean if I were thinking about operating margins for 2017, I would be in the mid-$21 million range. So it is really flat to this year. Certainly, there are a number of puts and takes. And I think Charlie, Brent, myself, we've seen some of them. Certainly, the synergies that will be only partially offsetting the price concessions we'll have next year. So -- and then the growth that doesn't come through at the same percent, that pricing goes out. So you're going to see a little bit of pricing there, profitability headwind. We're also going to be experiencing some FX exiting our patient contract that can temporarily affect margins until you're fully out of that. And then we are going to make investments in the business. And that's important as we do that from the things Charlie and Brent talked about. In those investments, we know we'll bring return over the long term. But initially at the beginning of the year, those investments will be really investments to set that infrastructure in the stage to be able to grow the business. So that's going to be some of the headwinds.

componenttext: Yes, Joel. So I think certainly, route density, Brent mentioned it before, we want to be able to be the low-cost provider, low-expense provider in the marketplace. So we've utilized better technology over the last few years. The team continues to make strides in that area. The focus now really is on the secure information destruction side of the business to get that same level of service, high level of service with the best route density that you can get. So -- and that's one of the reasons, I think, the strategy and Brent answered before, will be -- would we be willing to renew customers at a lower rate? Yes, because we don't want to lose that competitive advantage that we have in the marketplace which is route density. So it does play into it, certainly. Hopefully, that answers your question.

componenttext: Yes, we still haven't broken out M&I in its own kind of service line and profitability at this point, Joel. componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Amanda, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Stericycle Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Sean McMillan, Vice President of Corporate Finance, you may begin your conference.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Stericycle's Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, g
componenttext:
Welcome to Stericycle's Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I will now read the safe harbor statement. 
This conference call may contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control, for example, general economic and market conditions. Our actual results could differ significantly from the results described in the forward-looking statements. 
Factors that could cause such differences include: changes in governmental regulation of the collection, transportation, treatment and disposal of regulated waste or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; increases in transportation and other operating costs; the level of governmental enforcement of regulations governing regulated waste collection and treatment or the proper handling and protection of personal and confidential information; our obligations to service our substantial indebtedness and to comply with the covenants and restrictions contained in our private placement notes, term loan credit facility and revolving credit facility; our ability to execute our acquisition strategy and to integrate acquired businesses; competition and demand for services in the regulated waste and Secure Information Destruction industries; political, economic and currency risks related to our foreign operations; impairments of goodwill or other indefinite-lived intangibles; variability in the demand for services we provide on a project or nonrecurring basis; exposure to environmental liabilities; fluctuations in the price we receive for the sale of paper; disruptions in or attacks on our information technology systems; compliance with existing and future legal and regulatory requirements; as well as other factors described in our filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K/A. As a result, past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance and investors should not use historical trends to anticipate future results or trends. 
We make no commitment to disclose any subsequent revisions to forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn it over to  Charlie Alutto, CEO.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sean. Good afternoon, everybody, and thank you for joining us on today's call. We were able to maintain consistent margin performance in the quarter despite revenue headwinds from previously discussed pricing pressure and softness in the manufa
componenttext:
Thank you, Sean. Good afternoon, everybody, and thank you for joining us on today's call. We were able to maintain consistent margin performance in the quarter despite revenue headwinds from previously discussed pricing pressure and softness in the manufacturing and industrial market. Our EPS exceeded expectations, in part driven by the use of our record free cash flow to accelerate our stock repurchase of mandatory preferred convertible shares. 
Joining me on today's call to discuss our Q3 results and 2017 preliminary guidance will be Dan Ginnetti, CFO; and Brent Arnold, COO. I will now turn it over to Dan.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Charlie. The results for the third quarter are as follows: Global revenues were $890.1 million, up 23.9% from $718.6 million in Q3 2015; and internal growth excluding the impact of foreign exchange, acquisitions and manufacturing and industrial se
componenttext:
Thanks, Charlie. The results for the third quarter are as follows: Global revenues were $890.1 million, up 23.9% from $718.6 million in Q3 2015; and internal growth excluding the impact of foreign exchange, acquisitions and manufacturing and industrial services was up 1.6%; domestic revenues were $664.1 million; excluding the impact of acquisitions and manufacturing and industrial revenues, internal growth was 1.6%. 
For consistency of your models, we're providing the following for the remainder of the year. Domestic revenues were $664.1 million, of which $637.1 million was regulated waste and compliance services revenues and $26.9 million was recall and returns. Domestic internal growth, excluding recalls and returns revenues, was up 1%, consisting of SQ up 1% and LQ flat. As anticipated, growth rates were impacted by SQ pricing pressure, lower hazardous waste volume from our industrial customers and lower fuel surcharges. 
International revenues were $226.1 million or 3% internal growth when adjusted for foreign exchange impact. As anticipated, international growth rates were impacted by the exiting of certain patient transportation contracts. Acquisitions contributed $184.7 million to growth in the quarter. Gross profits were $381 million or 42.8% of revenues. SG&A expense, excluding amortization was $189.3 million or 21.3% of revenues. Adjusted income from operations or EBITA was $191.7 million or 21.5% of revenues. Net interest expense was $24.7 million. Net income attributable to Stericycle was $61.5 million or $0.72 per share on an as-reported basis and $1.24 when adjusted for acquisition-related expenses and other adjustments. 
Now for the balance sheet. Our debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 3.35 at the end of the quarter. The unused portion of the revolver at the end of the quarter was approximately $607 million. In the quarter, we repurchased 265,000 shares of the mandatory preferred convertible on the open market in the amount of $19.2 million. At the end of the quarter, we have authorization to purchase 3.1 million shares. Our CapEx was $33.8 million or 3.8% of revenues. Our DSO was 65 days. Year-to-date, as-reported, cash from operations was $417.8 million. And when adjusted for recall reimbursement and other items, cash from operations was $467.6 million. 
I will now turn it over to Brent.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. In the quarter, we closed 5 tuck-in acquisitions, all domestic. Revenues from the 5 acquisitions were approximately $0.4 million in the quarter and annualized are approximately $4 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with we
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. In the quarter, we closed 5 tuck-in acquisitions, all domestic. Revenues from the 5 acquisitions were approximately $0.4 million in the quarter and annualized are approximately $4 million. Our worldwide acquisition pool remains robust with well over $100 million in annualized revenues in multiple geographies and lines of business. 
The SQ pricing pressure discussed previously continued in the quarter and will remain for the foreseeable future. To address these pressures, we are making incremental strategic investments in sales, marketing and data analytics. These investments will enable us to pinpoint and execute on opportunities to grow our business and improve our overall performance. 
Despite the SQ headwinds, we were able to maintain our operating margin profile as well as deliver positive revenue growth in other services. For example, in our hospital customer base, we successfully completed several large Sharps Management and pharmaceutical compliant installations. We saw strong growth in retail waste services, driven by our high level of service and detailed reporting capabilities. The combination of our customer relationships and our multiple compliance solutions provides a strong foundation for future growth. 
In the Secure Information Destruction Service, we continued to see strong sales resulting from the conversion of unvended customers to ongoing service. In addition, the national accounts team continues to make progress, securing new large customers. 
Our synergies remain on track with recent progress in streamlining back-office processes and implementing new technologies to optimize our inside sales and customer service. 
In closing, we would like to thank all of our worldwide team members for their continued commitment to our customers, our shareholders and our core values. 
I will now turn it over to Charlie.

headline: Stericycle, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016 and preliminary guidance for 2017. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, in
componenttext:
Thank you, Brent. I would now like to provide insight on our current guidance for 2016 and preliminary guidance for 2017. Please keep in mind that these are forward-looking statements and our guidance does not include future acquisitions, divestitures, integration and acquisition-related expenses and other adjusted items. 
As a reminder, our 2016 EPS guidance is adjusted for amortization expense. For 2016, we believe EPS will be in the range of $4.74 to $4.76. This includes the benefit of our ongoing strategy to repurchase our mandatory preferred convertible shares. 
We expect revenue for 2016 will be in the range of $3.56 billion to $3.58 billion, depending on assumptions for growth and the impact of foreign exchange rates. 
Internal growth rates are expected to be: SQ, 3% to 5%; LQ, 2% to 3%; international, 4% to 5%; and recall and returns revenues between $95 million and $105 million. We have estimates for free cash flow in 2016 between $450 million and $470 million. 2016 CapEx is anticipated to be between $130 million to $135 million. We expect the 2016 full year as-reported tax rate to be approximately 36%. 
Now I'd like to provide preliminary guidance for 2017. For 2017, we believe EPS estimates will be in the range of $4.57 to $4.77, using a share count of approximately 91.1 million. This includes the unfavorable impact of approximately $0.19 from the normalization of performance compensation and additional SG&A investments to drive future growth and profitability. This is partially offset by approximately $0.17 of benefit from our ongoing strategy to repurchase the mandatory preferred convertible shares. 
We believe revenues for 2017 will be in the range of $3.54 billion to $3.67 billion, depending on assumptions, on foreign exchange and internal rates of flat to 3%. The worldwide revenue guidance for each of our service lines is as follows: regulated waste and compliance services will be in the range of $2.03 billion to $2.09 billion; Secure Information Destruction Services will be in the range of $780 million to $810 million; communications and related services will be in the range of $340 million to $370 million, depending on recall revenues; and manufacturing and industrial services will be in the range of $380 million to $400 million. 
We have estimates for free cash flow in 2017 between $450 million to $470 million. 2017 CapEx is anticipated to be between $125 million to $150 million. We expect the 2017 full year as-reported tax rate to be approximately 36.5%. 
Stericycle continues to be the market leader in multiple services and geographies. We have a strong team and an unmatched infrastructure. We are confident in the long-term outlook of our business. 
As a reminder, Stericycle will be hosting its first Investor Day and webcast on the morning of Thursday, November 10, to share perspectives on Stericycle's strategies, capabilities and plans to drive long-term shareholder value. More details are posted on the Events page of our Investor Relations website. We encourage investors, analysts and the public to join the live webcast or watch the meeting replay. 
Thank you for your time today. We'll now answer any questions. Amanda, you can open the Q&A.
